• The transport properties of nonlinear non-equilibrium dynamical systems, particularly ratchet systems, are not well understood.
• Ratchet systems are asymmetric periodic potentials where an ensemble of particles experience directed transport.
• The interest in ratchets lies in the possibility of extracting useful work from unbiased noisy fluctuations, as seen in biological systems.
• Recent studies have focused on the behavior of deterministic chaotic ratchets and Hamiltonian ratchets.
• The behavior of nonlinear systems, including the transition from regular to chaotic behavior, is sensitive to system parameters.
• Mateos conjectured a connection between current direction reversals and bifurcations from chaotic to periodic behavior in trajectory dynamics.
• Barbieri and Salerno argued against Mateos' conjecture, showing current reversals without bifurcations and proposing an alternative origin related to the stability properties of rotating periodic orbits.
• The authors of the given document investigate the impact of different ensembles of particles on the current in a chaotic deterministic ratchet and find that the current depends significantly on the details of the initial ensemble.

* The source document discusses the discovery of extrasolar planets with wide range of eccentricities.
* One method proposed to explain the origin of highly eccentric extrasolar planets is planet-planet scattering.
* This method has been proposed to explain the architecture of the HD 20782 and planetary system, which contains a hot Jupiter as well as two jovian planets in moderately eccentric orbits.
* Interactions with stellar companions are another possible way to boost a planet's eccentricity.
* The Kozai mechanism can induce large-amplitude oscillations in the eccentricity of a planet if the inclination angle between the planetary orbit and a stellar companion is large.
* This mechanism has been suggested to explain the high eccentricity of 16 Cyg BB and HD 80606b.
* The Kozai mechanism is most effective in systems with a single planet in an orbit within 5.1 AU from the host star.
* Of the 15 stars hosting a planet with high eccentricity, six are also known to possess stellar-mass companions in wide binary orbits.
* The Hobby-Eberly Telescope (HET) is a joint project of several universities and is named in honor of its principal benefactors, William P. Hobby and Robert E. Eberly.
* The document presents updated orbital fits, dynamical simulations, and detection limit computations for six highly eccentric planetary systems: HD 3651, HD 37605, HD 45350, HD 80606, HD 89744, and 16 Cyg B.

* The LEP experiments at the Z pole tested the Standard Model (SM) at the quantum level, measuring the Z decay into fermion pairs with an accuracy of one part in ten thousands.
* The good agreement of the LEP data with the SM predictions severely constrained the behavior of new physics at the Z pole.
* Taking these achievements into account, the physics of the Z boson will again play the central role in the frontier of particle physics if the next generation Z factory comes true with the generated Z events several orders of magnitude higher than that of the LEP.
* This factory can be realized in the GigaZ option of the International Linear Collider (ILC) by adding a bypass to its main beam line.
* Given the high luminosity, the cross section at the Z resonance of about 10^-34, and the expected sensitivity to the branching ratio of Z decay can be improved from 10^-8 at the LEP to 10^-9 at the GigaZ.
* In light of this, the Z-boson properties, especially its exotic or rare decays which are widely believed to be sensitive to new physics, should be investigated comprehensively to evaluate their potential in probing new physics.

* The no-scale type Kähler potential in supersymmetry (SUSY) models predicts gauge coupling unification and solves the naturalness problem.
* The only source of SUSY breaking in this scenario is gaugino masses, making it highly predictive with a small number of parameters.
* The minimal scenario, where universal gaugino masses are given at the GUT scale, is severely constrained by direct search bounds, the cosmological constraint, the Higgs mass bound, and the branching ratio for B(s)→μ+μ-.
* Other scenarios, such as non-universal gaugino masses or boundary conditions above the GUT scale, have wider allowed parameter regions, and some may be testable at the LHC or even the Tevatron.

<summary>
* Colliding plane waves (CPW) result in spacelike singularities.
* Cross polarization weakens singularities but does not remove them.
* A solution by Chandrasekhar and Xanthopoulos (CX) has a Cauchy horizon (CH) instead of a spacelike singularity.
* Yurtsever showed that the CX CH is unstable against plane-symmetric perturbations.
* Linear perturbation analysis by CX also shows instability.
* Electromagnetic (EM) field weakens singularities in CPW.
* Bell and Szekeres (BS) solution describes collision of two linearly polarized step EM waves with a CH.
* Cross polarization does not remove singularities on null boundaries in the BS solution.
* The paper investigates the stability of quasiregular (QR) singularities in the incoming region of the cross-polarized BS (CPBS) solution using test fields.
</summary>

• Chandra Deep Field-North (CDF-N) surveys have reached depths to detect normal galaxies at redshifts up to 1.5.
• Normal galaxies contribute up to 50% of the X-ray background (XRB) flux in the 0.5-2 keV band.
• The ratio of X-ray luminosity to optical luminosity in normal spiral galaxies has increased by a factor of 1.6 from the local universe to redshift 1.5.
• The average X-ray luminosity of galaxies at redshift 1.5 is 73 times higher than that of local spiral galaxies.
• Many undetected spiral galaxies contribute to the XRB, and future Chandra observations could detect them.

<summary>
* Quantum systems can exhibit non-classical correlations, with three main types: Bell-nonlocality, EPR steerability, and non-separability.
* Bell-nonlocality is the strongest type, where measurement correlations violate Bell's inequalities, demonstrating the violation of local causality.
* EPR steerability is a weaker type, where one party (Alice or Bob) can demonstrate steering by measuring their local observables, while the other party's reduced state depends on the choice of measurement made by the first party.
* Non-separability is the weakest type, where the state cannot be expressed as a mixture of product states of the constituents.
* The set of separable states is a strict subset of the set of non-EPR steerable states, which is a strict subset of the set of Bell-local states.
* EPR steerability is the only way to verify the existence of entanglement if one party (Alice or her detectors) cannot be trusted.
* The paper investigates EPR steerability of a class of two-qubit states with maximally mixed marginals (T-states) using the quantum steering ellipsoid formalism.
* The paper develops a deterministic local hidden state (LHS) model for projective measurements on T-states and conjectures that this model is optimal.
* The paper also derives two sufficient conditions for EPR steerability of T-states via EPR steering inequalities, including a new asymmetric steering inequality for the spin covariance matrix.
</summary>

<summary>
* The use of spin polarization of a single electron to encode binary information was first mentioned by Richard Feynman in casual conversations around 1985, but concrete schemes for implementing spintronic logic gates were not proposed until the mid-1990s.
* Encoding information in spin has potential advantages, such as lower power dissipation, immunity to noise, and faster operation compared to charge-based devices.
* In 1994, a scheme for realizing a classical universal logic gate (NAND) using three spins in a weak magnetic field was proposed.
* The scheme uses exchange interaction between nearest neighbor spins and anti-ferromagnetic ordering to achieve the desired logic functionality.
* However, the scheme has a severe shortcoming that precludes its use in pipelined architectures due to the bidirectional nature of exchange interaction.
* A solution to this problem was proposed in 1996, involving the use of a three-phase clock to enforce unidirectional flow of logic signals.
* Despite the interesting physics involved, these devices are not currently practical due to lithography challenges and energy dissipation.
</summary>

• Cataclysmic variables (CVs) are short-period binaries containing a white dwarf (WD) primary and a low-mass main sequence secondary. The secondary fills its Roche lobe and transfers mass to the WD through the inner Lagrangian point.
• The main features of the orbital period distribution of CVs with hydrogen-rich donors are the lack of systems in the 2-3 hour period range (the so-called period gap) and the sharp cut-off of the distribution at around 77 minutes. Theoretical models have been unable to reproduce the precise position of the observed short-period cut-off and the observed shape of the CV orbital period distribution near this cut-off.
• The orbital period evolution reflects the radius evolution of the mass donor, which is governed by two competing effects: mass transfer perturbs thermal equilibrium and expands the star, while thermal relaxation reestablishes thermal equilibrium and contracts the star back to its equilibrium radius. The minimum period occurs where the two corresponding time scales, the mass transfer time and the thermal (Kelvin-Helmholtz) time, are about equal.

• The mid-infrared spectral mapping of Stephan's Quintet using the Spitzer Space Telescope revealed a large-scale distribution of warm molecular hydrogen (H2) emission, with a lower limit luminosity of 1.0 x 10^42 erg s^-1 spread over 30 kpc.
• Another shock-excited feature, the "H2 bridge," was discovered between the main shock and NGC 7319, likely a remnant of past tidal interactions within the group.
• The spatial variation in the distribution of H2 0-0 line ratios suggests differences in temperature and excitation in the shocked system, which will be explored in detail in a follow-up paper.
• The global L(H2)/L(X-ray) ratio in the main shock is ~92, and ~62.5 in the new "bridge" feature, indicating that mid-infrared H2 lines are a stronger coolant than X-ray emission over the shock structures.
• This modifies the traditional view that X-ray emission always dominates cooling in the later stages of evolution in compact groups of galaxies.
• The observations suggest that molecular hydrogen cooling cannot be assumed to be negligible in high-redshift environments, especially in situations where strong shocks propagate into a clumpy, multiphase medium.
• The enhanced cooling due to molecular hydrogen, which has so far been neglected, will depend on the distribution and nature of the first dust grains, in concert with the formation, temperature, and abundance of gas, and the feedback effects from the first stars and AGN.

<summary>
* The short-lived radioisotope (SLRI) @xmath4al was alive during the formation of the first refractory solids in the solar nebula.
* Some SLRI may have been injected into the presolar cloud or solar nebula by a supernova or AGB star shock wave.
* The stable oxygen isotopes appear to have been spatially heterogeneous in the solar nebula during early planet formation.
* UV photodissociation of CO molecules at the surface of the outer solar nebula is the leading explanation for generating oxygen anomalies.
* Marginally gravitationally unstable (MGUI) disks can lead to rapid inward and outward transport of disk gas and small grains.
* The models presented show that a phase of MGUI in disks and stars with a variety of masses and disk temperatures can lead to relatively rapid mixing and transport of disk gas and small grains.
</summary>

<summary>
* The CDF collaboration searched for new particles decaying to dijets, using four triggers and integrated luminosities ranging from 7.5 to 69.8 pb^-1.
* Jets were defined using a fixed cone clustering algorithm and corrected for detector response, energy lost outside the cone, and underlying event.
* The two highest pT jets were required to have |η| < 2/3 and a CMS scattering angle < 2/3.
* The QCD background was determined by fitting the data to a smooth function of three parameters.
* The search was conducted for axigluons, excited quarks, color octet technirhos, new gauge bosons, and scalar diquarks.
* The data showed upward fluctuations near 200, 550, and 850 GeV/c^2, but these were not statistically significant.
* Limits were set on the production cross section for new particles, and compared to theoretical cross sections for the particles being searched for.
</summary>

<summary>
* The first observational evidence of the universe's accelerated expansion was found when supernovae type Ia were found to be fainter than expected.
* This fact has been confirmed by many independent observations such as temperature anisotropies of the cosmic microwave background (CMB), inhomogeneities in the matter distribution, the integrated Sachs-Wolfe (ISW) effect, baryon acoustic oscillations (BAO), weak lensing (WL), and gamma-ray bursts.
* Within the framework of general relativity, the accelerated expansion is driven by a new energy density component with negative pressure, termed dark energy (DE).
* The nature of this unknown matter field has given rise to a great scientific effort in order to understand its properties.
* The observational evidence is consistent with a cosmological constant being the possible origin of the dark energy (DE) driving the present epoch of the accelerated expansion of our universe and a dark matter (DM) component giving rise to galaxies and their large-scale structures distributions.
* The DM is assumed to have negligible pressure and temperature and is termed cold.
* Thanks to the agreement with observations, the model is commonly known as LambdaCDM, to indicate the nature of its main components.
* While favored by the observations, the model is not satisfactory from the theoretical point of view: the value of the cosmological constant is many orders of magnitude smaller than what it was estimated in particle physics.
* It was suggested soon that DE could be dynamic, evolving with time.
* This new cosmological model also suffers from a severe fine-tune problem known as the coincidence problem: if the time variation of matter and DE are very different, why are their current values so similar?
</summary>

• The text discusses the diversity of broad and narrow emission lines in type 1 active galactic nuclei (AGN), with a focus on the Hα line and its profile shifts and asymmetries.
• Two populations of AGN are identified based on the width of the Hα line: population A with narrow lines (FWHM Hα = 1000 - 4000 km/s) and population B with broader lines (FWHM Hα = 4000 - 12000 km/s).
• The text also mentions the presence of broad Fe II emission in type 1 quasars and its correlation with the width of the Hα line.
• The authors question the existence of a systematic redshift of Fe II emission relative to the narrow [OIII]5007 line and the broad Hα line, as previously claimed by some studies. They present evidence from their own analysis of a large sample of bright quasars that suggests no significant systematic shift exists.

• Nuclear multifragmentation is a topic of intense study, with similarities between nucleon-nucleon interaction and van der Waals forces leading to searches for a liquid-gas phase transition in nuclear matter.
• The first experimental evaluation of the nuclear caloric curve was reported in 1995 by the ALADIN group, showing a wide plateau at around 5 MeV temperature.
• Subsequent experiments by EOS and INDRA obtained different caloric curves, with the plateau-like region absent in most cases.
• Discrepancies in caloric curves are due to experimental precision and finite-size effects, with nonequilibrium parts in measured excitation energies.
• The SMMC and SMM models, widely used in statistical multifragmentation, do not strictly follow microcanonical rules.
• The present paper describes improvements to the microcanonical multifragmentation model and its application to recent ALADIN group data.
• The model's improvements include refinements in the primary break-up stage and the inclusion of secondary particle emission.
• The model successfully reproduces experimental data, indicating a phase transition and identifying a nonequilibrium part in experimentally evaluated excitation energies.

<summary>
* The solar corona is heated to about 12 million kelvins, while the visible surface is roughly 250 times cooler.
* Magnetic fields or waves play a key role in the heating of the solar corona.
* The primary energy source for coronal heating lies in the convection zone below the solar photosphere.
* The debate centers on whether the energy to heat the corona derives from dissipation of magneto-hydrodynamic (MHD) waves or from numerous small-scale magnetic reconnection events giving rise to nanoflares.
* Interaction of the magnetic field with convective flows in or below the photosphere can produce two types of magnetic disturbances in coronal structures: MHD waves and field-aligned electric currents.
* These types of magnetic heating mechanisms can be crudely classified as either wave-heating or current-heating mechanisms.
* Theoretical arguments exist for both mechanisms, but observational evidence for nano-flare heating is less convincing.
* High-frequency MHD waves are capable of significant heating and have been sought using the Fe XIV green "line at 530.3 nm and the Fe X red "line at 637.5 nm.
* Observations of high-frequency intensity oscillations of the coronal structures have been made using various instruments and techniques.
* The authors describe a setup using the Mid-Sized Coronagraph at Lomnicky Peak Observatory and the SECIS instrument to search for high-frequency coronal oscillations.
</summary>

<summary>
* Water vapor is an important molecule in interstellar and circumstellar clouds, with the 6@xmath8 - 5@xmath9 masing transition at 22 GHz used to trace high excitation gas.
* Other water lines, such as the 3@xmath11 - 2@xmath12 transition at 183 GHz, have been detected and used to map emission on large spatial scales.
* The ISO satellite has provided observations of water vapor in the mid- and far-infrared, showing it to be ubiquitous in molecular clouds with an abundance of 10@xmath7.
* The 325 GHz line of water vapor was observed to be extended, with an abundance of @xmath4 10@xmath5 in the * plateau* region.
* Ground-based observations of water vapor provide finer spatial resolution and accurate abundance estimates compared to ISO or SWAS.
* The 325 GHz line is spatially restricted to the plateau, while the 183 GHz line is also detected in the ridge, due to differences in their maser properties and physical conditions.
</summary>

<summary>
* Sequence nets are constructed from a sequence of letters and fixed rules of connectivity.
* Threshold nets are a special case of sequence nets.
* Two new classes of two-letter sequence nets were discovered.
* The class of sequence nets with rule @xmath47 can be mapped to a difference-threshold net.
* Structural properties of new classes of two-letter sequence nets can be analyzed easily.
* An ordering in ensembles of sequence nets is useful for visualizing and studying their attributes.
* 3-letter sequence nets were fully classified, and some examples were analyzed.
* The diameter of sequence nets grows linearly with the number of letters in the alphabet.
</summary>

<summary>
* The authors present a bayesian approach for nonconvex penalization problems using subordinators.
* They model latent shrinkage parameters using subordinators, which are defined as stochastic processes of regularization parameters.
* Two families of compound poisson subordinators are considered: continuous compound poisson subordinators based on a gamma random variable and discrete compound poisson subordinators based on a logarithmic random variable.
* The laplace exponent of a subordinator is a bernstein function, leading to two families of nonconvex penalty functions.
* The limiting cases of these two families of compound poisson subordinators are the nonconvex log and exp penalties.
* The authors apply the lvy processes to bayesian linear regression and devise an ecme algorithm for finding the sparse solution.
* They conduct empirical evaluations using simulated data and compare their approach with the lasso and other nonconvex penalties.
* The results show that the nonconvex penalization approach is competitive and outperforms the lasso in some cases.
* The authors also investigate the relationship between the regression variables and the local tuning parameters.
* They conclude that the subordinator is a powerful bayesian approach for variable selection.
</summary>

• The paper discusses the nonlinear current response in superconductors, focusing on two-band superconductors and the specific case of MgB2.
• The authors compare the differences between one-band and two-band superconductors in terms of their nonlinear response, which can be measured in the coefficients defined by Xu et al. and Dahm and Scalapino.
• The paper provides detailed predictions for the nonlinear coefficient of MgB2 using parameters and electron-phonon spectral functions taken from band structure calculations.

• Dynamic Time Warping (DTW) is a popular approach for time series classification, often used with 1-Nearest Neighbor (1-NN) and global constraints like Sakoe-Chiba Band (SC Band) or Ratanamahatana-Keogh Band (RK Band).
• Euclidean distance is commonly used but DTW distance is more appropriate for time series data.
• SC Band speeds up DTW calculation and acts as a global constraint, with a fixed width of 10% of the time series length.
• Recent work shows that the size of the global constraint depends on the data properties, and testing all possible widths is necessary.
• RK Band generalizes the global constraint model, allowing multi-band adjustments per class.
• The original RK Band learning algorithm uses a hill-climbing search with accuracy and distance metrics, but suffers from overfitting.
• The authors propose two new learning algorithms: Band Boundary Extraction and Iterative Learning, using Silhouette Index as a heuristic function.
• The best band is used with 1-NN and DTW distance for classification, with LB_Keogh lower bound for speed-up.
• The paper is organized into background, approach, experimental evaluation, and conclusion sections.
• The proposed approach is based on DTW, SC Band, RK Band, and Silhouette Index concepts.

• The Standard Model (SM) of elementary particles has been successful in describing nature at the electroweak scale, and the discovery of the Higgs boson at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) strengthens its correctness.
• There is no explicit evidence of physics beyond the SM from the LHC so far, but there is an anomaly in the muon anomalous magnetic moment (g-2) that could hint at new physics.
• The authors explore the possibility of a new gauge interaction for the muon beyond the SM to explain this anomaly.

• The document discusses the unique property of entanglement in quantum multipartite systems and its role in quantum information processing.
• Entanglement sudden death (ESD) and revival have been observed in qubits under Markovian decoherence.
• Some studies indicate that ESD is not always the eventual fate of qubit entanglement, and finite residual entanglement can be preserved in the long time limit.
• López et al. found that the lost entanglement of qubits is exclusively transferred to the reservoirs under Markovian amplitude-damping decoherence dynamics, and ESD of the qubits is always accompanied by the entanglement sudden birth (ESB) of the reservoirs.
• The document presents a model of two independent qubits in two local reservoirs and obtains the dynamical entanglement invariance based on the exact solution of the non-Markovian decoherence dynamics of the qubit system.
• The entanglement distribution over the subsystems when the reservoirs are photonic band gap (PBG) media is studied explicitly, and a stable entanglement distribution configuration is found in the non-Markovian dynamics.
• The entanglement dynamics and its distributions in the bipartite partitions are completely determined by the time-dependent factor of single-qubit excited-state population.
• Population trapping is responsible for the suppression of spontaneous emission and the formation of bound states between the qubit and its amplitude damping reservoir.
• The stable entanglement distribution resulted from the bound states is a general phenomenon in open quantum systems when the non-Markovian effect is taken into account.
• The work implies an active way to protect entanglement from decoherence by modifying the properties of the reservoir via quantum reservoir engineering.

• The origin of celestial gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) is still unexplained, but they are believed to be associated with gravitational wave (GW) bursts.
• The Rome group operates two resonant bar detectors, Explorer and Nautilus, to detect GW signals.
• The group launched a program to study the presence of correlations between GRB events and GW signals from these detectors.
• The analysis uses an algorithm based on cross-correlating the outputs of the two GW detectors to cope with the unknown time difference between GRB and GW bursts and unmodelled noise.
• The data are summarized by an observed average squared energy, and the standard deviation is calculated using Bayes' theorem.
• The group provides experimental upper limits for the burst intensity causing correlations of GWs with GRBs, excluding signals of amplitude 10^-21 with 95% probability, with a time window of 100 s.

• The paper presents a model to study the citation distribution of scientific publications, focusing on two research areas and their cross-referencing.
• The model considers preferential attachment and initial attractiveness of nodes, with a rate equation approach used for analysis.
• The model predicts power-law distributions for total in-degree, intra-links, and cross-links, with exponents dependent on coupling parameters.
• In the weak coupling case, the intra-link exponent matches the total link exponent, and the cross-link exponent decreases with increasing coupling.
• The model is applicable to other complex systems, such as the web of human sexual contacts, and its predictions align with some empirical findings.

• The theoretical description of hadron production at large transverse momentum involves a two-step process: hard scattering of partons followed by fragmentation to hadrons.
• The first step is calculable in perturbative QCD, while the second step uses fragmentation functions determined phenomenologically.
• Recent findings show that recombination of partons is more appropriate than fragmentation for intermediate transverse momentum in heavy-ion collisions.
• The purpose of this paper is to introduce the notion of shower partons and determine their distributions to represent fragmentation functions in terms of recombination.
• The shower parton distributions (SPDs) are determined from fragmentation functions using a recombination model and integral equations.
• The SPDs are shown to reproduce the fragmentation functions accurately and have reasonable properties.
• The SPDs are useful for problems where fragmentation functions alone are insufficient, such as when a hard parton is produced in a thermal environment or for studying dihadron distributions in a jet.
• The recombination process is considered the basic hadronization process, even for fragmentation in vacuum, and the SPDs obtained are model-dependent but useful for studying hadron production in heavy-ion collisions at intermediate transverse momentum.

<summary>
* The paper presents a new method for solving nonconvex semidefinite programming problems using inner convex approximation.
* The method is a generalization of previous work on scalar optimization and uses a regularization technique to ensure strict descent.
* The algorithm is simple to implement and does not require globalization strategies like line-search.
* The convergence of the algorithm to a stationary point is proven under mild conditions.
* Two ways to form an overestimate for bilinear matrix-valued mappings are provided.
* The method is applied to several problems in static output feedback control, including spectral abscissa optimization, H-infinity optimization, and mixed H2/H-infinity synthesis.
* The algorithm is tested on problems from the COMPETITION library and compared with existing methods.
* The paper also discusses the convergence of the algorithm and its application to more general nonconvex SDP problems.
* Future research directions include extending the method to other nonconvex SDP problems.
</summary>

• The text discusses a discrete differential geometry scheme for fermionic field theories, with a focus on the Dirac-Kähler formulation.
• The scheme uses two parallel lattices to maintain locality of the Hodge star operator and a finite element scheme to capture the properties of the wedge product.
• The text also explores the application of this scheme to staggered fermions in lattice QCD, aiming to develop non-degenerate, doubler-free fermionic field theories for the lattice.
• The authors evaluate the path integral for this formulation, considering the effects of chiral and flavor projection.

• The paper investigates secure transmission in cognitive radio networks using collaborative relay beamforming under secrecy constraints.
• It formulates the beamforming optimization as a quasiconvex optimization problem and proposes suboptimal null space beamforming schemes to reduce computational complexity.

• The paper discusses the benefits of maintaining @xmath0-invariance when quantizing the Maxwell field in conformally flat spaces (CFS).
• A new and simple two-point Wightman function for the Maxwell field in de Sitter space is found, which has the same physical content as the Allen and Jacobson two-point function.
• The paper extends the results to general CFS and clarifies the quantum structure of the formalism using Dirac's six-cone formalism and the Gupta-Bleuler quantization scheme.

• The parallel chip-firing game is a periodic automaton on graphs where vertices, each containing non-negative chips, fire one chip to each neighbor if possible.
• The game's period is the minimal positive integer such that the position repeats, and the transient length is the minimal number of steps before the period begins.
• Bitar and Goles showed that the period of any position on a tree graph is 1 or 2, and Kominers and Kominers showed that all connected graphs satisfying a certain condition have a period of 1.
• Kiwi et al. constructed a graph with a position whose period is at least 3, disproving Bitar's conjecture that all periods are 1 or 2.
• Levine proved that the period of any position on the complete graph is at most 4.

• The source document discusses the observation and analysis of GRB 090510, a gamma-ray burst detected by various space-based instruments.
• The burst was initially thought to be a long GRB but was later reclassified as a short GRB due to its lack of nesting conditions in its late x-ray emission.
• The document presents a new interpretation of GRB 090510 as a short GRB originating from the merger of a binary neutron star (NS) system, supported by the good quality of the data in both the optical-UV and x-ray ranges.
• The analysis includes a more accurate description of the prompt emission, best fitted by a convolution of thermal spectra, indicating the presence of an axially symmetric configuration of the dyadotorus emitting the thermal emission.
• The document also discusses the high-energy (GeV) emission of GRB 090510, which is similar to that of the binary-driven hypernova 130427A, suggesting that the GeV emission originates from the formation of a black hole (BH).
• The analysis estimates the energy requirement of the GeV emission by considering the accretion of mass onto a Kerr-Newman BH, dominated by its angular momentum and endowed with electromagnetic fields not influencing the geometry.
• The document concludes that the dyadotorus manifests itself by the p - GRB emission and clearly precedes the prompt emission phase, as well as the GeV emission originating from the newly-formed BH, contrasting with the usual assumption made in most works relating BHs and GRBs.

• The text discusses the prediction of the W boson mass in the Standard Model (SM) and models with physics beyond the SM.
• In the SM, the W boson mass is predicted in terms of other parameters of the theory and increases quadratically as the top quark mass is increased.
• In models with Higgs particles in representations other than SM doublets and singlets, the SM tree-level relation between the W boson mass and the top quark mass no longer holds.
• When the theory is renormalized at one loop, models of this type require extra input parameters.
• The text also discusses the possibility of a heavy Higgs boson that is consistent with precision electroweak data in the context of oblique corrections.

• The text discusses log-Riemann surfaces and exp-algebraic curves, which are certain branched coverings of the Riemann sphere given by transcendental functions of infinite degree.
• It defines spaces of functions and differential forms on these surfaces, and shows that the integrals of these differential forms along curves joining the infinite ramification points converge, giving a pairing between the cohomology group and the space of meromorphic functions.
• The text also proves a Torelli-type theorem for exp-algebraic curves, stating that the pair consisting of the underlying Riemann surface and the set of punctures determines the exp-algebraic curve.

• The text discusses a method for solving the Anderson impurity model in a general multiorbital case using a rational interpolative formula for the self-energy.
• The method uses constraints such as the hartree fock value, zero frequency value, quasiparticle mass renormalization value, and positions of hubbard bands to determine the coefficients in the interpolative formula.
• The interpolative method is compared with the quantum Monte Carlo method and shows remarkable agreement in reproducing the trends and quantitative agreement in many regions of parameters.

• The study focuses on nonequilibrium phase transitions, particularly in the surface reaction model proposed by Ziff, Gulari, and Barshad (ZGB), which describes the oxidation of CO on a catalytic surface.
• The model is modified to include a random distribution of inert sites on the catalytic surface, which affects the adsorption and reaction of CO and O2 molecules.
• The study employs mean-field (site and pair approximations) calculations and Monte Carlo simulations to determine the phase diagram, spinodal and transition lines, and hysteresis curves for different concentrations of inert sites.
• The results show that the presence of inert sites shifts the phase boundaries and reduces the width of the reactive window. The transition between the reactive and poisoned phases can be of first-order or continuous, depending on the concentration of inert sites.
• The study also examines the production rate of CO2 molecules and finds that it is maximum at the first-order transition point in the site and pair approximations, but moves towards the reactive window when the concentration of inert sites is greater than the critical value.

• The paper discusses the hydrodynamic limit for interacting particle systems on crystal lattices, which are a generalization of classical lattice structures.
• Crystal lattices have periodic global structures but inhomogeneous local structures.
• The paper formulates a symmetric simple exclusion process and a weakly asymmetric simple exclusion process on crystal lattices.
• The main theorem states that the density of particles converges to a solution of a quasi-linear parabolic equation as the scaling limit of the process.
• The paper constructs a scaling limit of the crystal lattice using discrete harmonic maps.
• The paper proves a local ergodic theorem for the crystal lattice, which is a key step in the proof of the hydrodynamic limit.
• The paper also proves the one-block estimate and the two-block estimate, which are used to prove the local ergodic theorem.
• The paper gives examples of periodic harmonic maps for the one-dimensional standard lattice, the square lattice, the hexagonal lattice, and the kagom lattice.
• The paper also discusses the relationship between the hydrodynamic limit and geometric structures of crystal lattices.

• The study of harmonic maps was initiated by F. B. Fuller, J. Nash, and J. H. Sampson.
• Harmonic maps are critical points of the energy functional defined on the space of smooth maps between Riemannian or pseudo-Riemannian manifolds.
• The trace of the second fundamental form of a harmonic map vanishes.
• The paper focuses on harmonic maps between almost para-Hermitian manifolds and para-Sasakian manifolds.
• A paraholomorphic map is a smooth map that intertwines the structures of almost para-Hermitian and para-Sasakian manifolds.
• The tension field of any paraholomorphic map between para-Sasakian manifolds lies in the vertical bundle.
• A parapluriharmonic map is a smooth map between almost paracontact metric manifolds and pseudo-Riemannian manifolds whose second fundamental form is parallel.
• The paper provides necessary and sufficient conditions for a paraholomorphic map between para-Sasakian manifolds to be parapluriharmonic.

• The star formation rate (SFR) of galaxies is a crucial measure for understanding their growth and evolution.
• Large-scale simulations have shown that unregulated star formation leads to an overabundance of high-mass galaxies.
• Some process, such as supermassive black holes (SMBHs), must be able to stop or "quench" star formation before galaxies grow too big.
• SMBHs grow through accretion of cold material, and the energy released is converted into radiation across the electromagnetic spectrum.
• The AGN (active galactic nucleus) can deposit this energy into the ISM (interstellar medium) of its host galaxy through jets or powerful outflows, heating the gas or removing it altogether.
• The AGN feedback process is thought to play a role in regulating the SFR of galaxies.
• The SFR of galaxies is often measured using IR (infrared) emission from dust heated by young stars.
• However, dust can also be heated by the AGN, making it difficult to determine the true SFR of AGN host galaxies.
• The starburst-AGN connection is an active area of research, with much work focused on measuring the SFR of AGN host galaxies using IR emission.
• The Herschel Space Observatory has pushed into the submillimeter range, providing a window into the far-IR properties of galaxies and allowing for better estimates of the SFR of AGN host galaxies.

<summary>
* Hollander was born in Brooklyn, New York, and developed an interest in math and science at an early age.
* He attended Carnegie Mellon University, where he initially majored in engineering but switched to math after his first year.
* He obtained his Ph.D. in statistics from Stanford University, where he was influenced by Lincoln E. Moses and other faculty members.
* Hollander's thesis work on rank tests for ordered alternatives in the two-way layout laid the foundation for his future research in nonparametric statistics.
* He joined the Florida State University (FSU) statistics department in 1965 and became a full professor in 1971.
* Hollander served as the department chair for nine years and recruited several prominent faculty members during his tenure.
* He has co-authored three books, including a popular nonparametrics textbook and a book on medical statistics.
* Hollander has made significant contributions to the field of nonparametric statistics, including work on bayesian nonparametrics and repair models in reliability theory.
* He has also been involved in sports statistics, including a study on rounding first base and attending spring training games with his wife Glee.
</summary>

* The fundamental group of the complement of plane curves is a very important topological invariant.
* It has applications in distinguishing connected components of the moduli space of smooth projective surfaces and in computing the fundamental groups of complements of hypersurfaces in projective space.
* It is also interesting to explore new finite non-abelian groups which serve as fundamental groups of complements of plane curves in general.

• The text discusses a model that generates non-zero complex @xmath0 and predicts non-zero CP violation in the leptonic sector, compatible with low energy neutrino data and high energy CP violation.
• The model is based on the @xmath15 symmetry and the @xmath1 symmetry, with a softly broken @xmath1 symmetry through a single parameter in a single element of @xmath2.
• The model predicts large values of @xmath107, @xmath144, and @xmath160, and generates observable lepton asymmetry compatible with the baryon asymmetry observed by WMAP.
• The model predicts the correct neutrino mass squared differences and mixing angles, and the neutrino mass spectrum is inverted.
• The model predicts a large value of @xmath144, which is the CP violating parameter in neutrino oscillations, and a large value of @xmath160, which is the CP violating phase in the leptonic sector.
• The model predicts a large value of @xmath107, which is the mixing angle between the second and third generations of neutrinos, and a large value of @xmath144, which is the CP violating parameter in neutrino oscillations.

• Organic molecular crystals are promising for nanoscale devices in electronics and optoelectronics.
• They consist of organic molecules held together by weak van der Waals forces and an inorganic component for electrical contact.
• The electronic structure of the interface between the organic and inorganic components is crucial for device performance.
• Charge transfer between the organic and inorganic components and the energies involved need to be understood.
• Upon adsorption on a substrate, the electron addition and removal energies of a molecule change from their gas phase counterparts.
• The image charge accumulated on the substrate alters the addition or removal energy of charge carriers from the molecule.
• A quasiparticle (qp) description is commonly used to calculate addition and removal energies.
• Density functional theory (DFT) is often used to calculate the energy levels of the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO).
• The Kohn-Sham orbitals in DFT cannot be associated with qp energies, but they often provide a good approximation.
• Constrained density functional theory (CDFT) is a resource-efficient alternative to calculate charge transfer energies in organic-inorganic interfaces.

<summary>
* The paper studies critical Casimir forces (CCFs) between two spherical colloids near a planar substrate.
* The colloids and substrate have different boundary conditions (BCs), leading to many-body effects.
* The system is modeled using mean-field theory and a finite element method.
* The paper focuses on the normal and lateral CCFs acting on one colloid (colloid 2) in the presence of another colloid (colloid 1) and a substrate.
* The scaling functions for the CCFs are calculated and normalized.
* The paper finds that the normal CCF can change sign, leading to unstable mechanical equilibrium configurations.
* The lateral CCF between colloids with opposite BCs can be attractive or repulsive, depending on the substrate's presence.
* The preferred arrangement of colloids depends on their BCs, leading to monolayer or three-dimensional cluster formation.
* The many-body contribution to the normal CCF can change sign, providing a quantitatively reliable description of the system's interactions.
* The paper compares its results with quantum-electrodynamic Casimir interactions and the van der Waals force between atoms near a surface.
* The paper also considers a configuration where the colloids are vertically aligned with respect to the substrate.
</summary>

* Molecular hydrogen (H2) is the most abundant molecule in the universe and plays a crucial role in the chemistry of the interstellar medium (ISM). Its formation is governed by the sticking of hydrogen atoms (H) onto dust grains, which can be weakly (physisorbed) or strongly (chemisorbed) bound to the surface.
* The authors experimentally studied the hydrogenation of coronene cations in the gas phase through exposure to hydrogen atoms using mass spectrometry. They found that odd hydrogenation states of coronene cations predominantly populate the mass spectrum, suggesting that the further hydrogenation of these cations is associated with a barrier if the number of attached H atoms is odd, and no barrier if this number is even. This alternation seems to remain with increasing hydrogenation, indicating that polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon (PAH) cations can also act as catalysts for H2 formation in the ISM.

<summary>
* The atom or atoms in the atomic clock are passive and do not 'tick', so the clock needs an active oscillator in addition to the atom(s).
* The resonance exhibited by the atom or atoms of the clock varies with the details of the clock's construction and the circumstances of its operation.
* The resonance shifts depending on the intensity of the radiation of the atoms by the oscillator.
* The si second is defined by the resonance that would be found at absolute zero temperature, implying zero radiation.
* For a clock using cesium 133 atoms, this imagined resonance is declared by the general conference of weights and measures to be 9,192,631,770 Hz.
* The wave function incorporated into the operation of an atomic clock can never be unconditionally known.
* The language of quantum theory reflects within itself a distinction between 'explanation' and 'evidence'.
* The si second is that number of cycles of the radiation at that imagined resonance.
</summary>

<summary>
* IEEE 802.15.4 is a low-power, low-data-rate wireless standard for WPANs, targeting applications like WBANs.
* It operates in 2.4 GHz, 915 MHz, and 868 MHz frequency bands, supporting star and peer-to-peer topologies.
* The standard supports beacon-enabled (slotted) and non-beacon-enabled (unslotted) modes.
* CSMA/CA is used for channel access in non-beacon-enabled mode.
* The paper focuses on analyzing IEEE 802.15.4 with non-beacon-enabled mode in a star topology using CSMA/CA.
* The study varies data rates (20, 40, and 250 kbps) and considers both ACK and no ACK conditions.
* Performance metrics include load, throughput, delay, and end-to-end delay.
* IEEE 802.15.4 performs best at 250 kbps with minimal delay and high throughput.
* Non-ACK mode performs better than ACK mode due to reduced collision probability.
</summary>

• **MOPED (Multiple Optimised Parameter Estimation and Data Compression)** is an algorithm for compressing data and speeding up likelihood function evaluations in astronomical data analysis.
• It's particularly useful when the noise covariance matrix depends on model parameters, requiring matrix inversion at each likelihood evaluation.
• MOPED maintains the Fisher matrix of the likelihood at a chosen point but may struggle with multimodal and degenerate distributions.
• It provides significant speed improvements (up to 100x) when it accurately represents the likelihood function.
• The algorithm has been successfully applied to galaxy spectra and CMB power spectrum estimation.
• A solution exists for handling "badly" behaved likelihoods in light transit analysis, allowing MOPED to still provide a large speed increase.
• The authors present an astrophysical scenario where MOPED does not accurately portray the true likelihood function.
• They expand on this scenario to include cases where MOPED works and others where it does not.
• The paper discusses criteria under which MOPED will accurately represent the likelihood and an implementation of the solution provided by Veitch et al. (2015).

* The cosmological constant problem (CCP) is a major puzzle in particle physics, consisting of three main pieces:
	+ The vacuum energy density can be the cosmological constant and has various sources, such as zero-point energy of particles and phase transitions.
	+ The vacuum energy density can receive large radiative corrections, including a cutoff scale.
	+ The experimental value of the cosmological constant is much smaller than the theoretical estimate.
* The authors suggest that a dominant part of dark energy can originate from gravitational corrections of vacuum energy, assuming that classical gravitational fields do not couple to a large portion of the vacuum energy effectively.
* The evolution of dark energy density is studied, and several possibilities for physics beyond the terascale are discussed, including no sensitive physics, miraculous cancellations, or the presence of another graviton.
* The universe dominated by dark energy might cause instability, and a phenomenologically viable model must ensure the stability of matters and a long time scale for instability.

<summary>
* The paper presents a spectroscopic technique called two-color modulation transfer spectroscopy for studying atomic properties of higher excited states.
* The method uses two lasers, a pump and a probe, counter-propagating through a thermal vapor.
* One of the lasers is modulated, either in amplitude or frequency, to connect the ground state to a resonant intermediate state while the probe scans over the desired energy manifold.
* The absorption of the pump laser is monitored as a function of probe laser detuning.
* The technique overcomes the low signal-to-noise ratio and non-availability of detectors at the desired wavelength in direct absorption spectroscopy.
* The paper illustrates the method with two ladder systems in rubidium and discusses two different applications of the modulation.
* For the first system, the amplitude of the probe laser is modulated, while for the second system, the frequency of the pump laser is modulated.
* The frequency modulation of the pump laser allows locking the probe laser to an excited atomic resonance, keeping the probe laser modulation-free.
* The method is not limited to these two cases and can be extended to other atomic levels.
</summary>

* The physics potential of forward proton tagging at the LHC has attracted significant attention, with a main focus on the central exclusive production (CEP) process.
* In CEP, the protons remain intact and the central system is separated from the outgoing protons by a large rapidity gap, constrained to be in a color singlet state.
* Observation of any particle in the CEP channel would provide a direct observation of its quantum numbers and allow for a measurement of the mass of the centrally produced particle regardless of its decay products.
* Proposals exist to install forward proton detectors at 220 m and 420 m from the interaction points of ATLAS and/or CMS, which would allow for the detection of central systems in the approximate mass range of 70 GeV to 1 TeV.

• The text discusses the zero-field hall effect in chiral @xmath0-wave superconductors (SCs) near the Kosterlitz-Thouless (KT) transition.
• The hall effect arises from the vortex dynamics of the chiral @xmath0-wave SCs.
• The main result is the presence of nonvanishing hall conductivity (@xmath44) and ac conductivity (@xmath45) near the KT transition in the bound pair dynamics description.
• The hall conductivity shows strong positive peak and sign changes in @xmath46 at suitable frequency regions above the transition temperature, as well as above @xmath9 in temperature domain at fixed frequencies.
• The shapes of two length-dependent response functions (@xmath48 and @xmath49) play a determining role on the behavior of @xmath44 and @xmath45.
• The paper also discusses the contribution of free vortex motion and the resulting total conductivity tensor.

• The rotation curves (RCs) of disk galaxies are a powerful tool to investigate the nature of dark matter (DM).
• Dwarf galaxies like the Orion dwarf provide an important test for DM density profiles.
• Recent studies suggest that the observed kinematics of dwarf galaxies are better fitted by a DM halo with a constant density core than by one that is centrally peaked.
• The Orion dwarf is one of the few known galaxies whose kinematics unambiguously point towards a cored profile.
• The Orion dwarf has a large mass discrepancy at all radii, and its baryonic components are efficiently modeled.
• The distance to the Orion dwarf is estimated to be 5.4±1.0 Mpc, but it remains a significant source of uncertainty.
• The Orion dwarf's RC is well-resolved and extends out to 5.1 r_d, with uncertainties of a few km/s.
• The Orion dwarf's kinematics are dominated by circular motion, and non-circular motions are not significant enough to hide a cusp inside an apparently solid-body RC.

• The trihydrogen dication (H3+) is a simple Coulomb system consisting of three protons and one electron.
• Its stability has been studied extensively, with Conroy's work in the 1960s and 1970s being a notable contribution.
• Conroy concluded that H3+ is not stable based on his analysis of potential energy surfaces.
• Berkowitz and Stocker searched for H3+ through charge stripping experiments but found no evidence of its stability.
• Later theoretical studies by Shoucri and Darling, and Hernandez and Carb also did not find a bound state.
• Ackermann et al. revisited the question using the finite element method and excluded the possibility of stable H3+ in the electronic ground state.
• The present study aims to address the question of H3+ stability once again.
• The study considers a Coulomb system of one electron and three protons forming an equilateral triangle.
• Two methods are used to explore the system: a specialized variational approach with physically relevant trial functions, and a standard variational approach using Gaussian trial functions.
• The results from both methods indicate that the molecular ion H3+ does not exist in an equilateral triangular configuration in the Born-Oppenheimer approximation.

<summary>
* The Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) has revealed complex relationships between galaxy properties and their environments.
* Galaxy clustering is a function of both star formation history (color and luminosity) and luminosity.
* For low luminosity galaxies, clustering is a strong function of color, while for luminous galaxies, it's a strong function of luminosity.
* For red galaxies, clustering is a non-monotonic function of luminosity, peaking at both high and low luminosities.
* Galaxy environment is independent of surface brightness and concentration at fixed color and luminosity.
* The study examines the scale dependence of these relationships to test assumptions of the "halo model" and semi-analytic models.
* The mean environment of galaxies with absolute magnitude brighter than -20.5 is a fair sample of the universe.
* The study finds that the environments of low luminosity, red galaxies become denser as absolute magnitude increases down to -18.
</summary>

• Transverse spin fluctuations are gapless, low-energy excitations in magnetic systems with continuous spin-rotational symmetry.
• They play a crucial role in various macroscopic properties like long-range order, order parameter magnitude, Nèel temperature, and spin correlations.
• In the antiferromagnetic (AF) ground state of the half-filled Hubbard model, transverse spin fluctuations are important in two and three dimensions.
• In the strong-coupling limit, they significantly reduce the zero-temperature AF order parameter in two dimensions to nearly 0.6 of the classical value.
• The Nèel temperature in three dimensions is reduced to nearly 0.7 of the mean-field result for the equivalent quantum Heisenberg antiferromagnet (QHAF).
• Recently, there has been interest in spin fluctuations due to defects, disorder, and vacancies in the quantum antiferromagnet.
• The authors describe a new method for evaluating transverse spin correlations and quantum spin-fluctuation corrections about the Hartree-Fock (HF) level broken-symmetry state, using magnon mode energies and spectral functions obtained in the random phase approximation (RPA).
• The method is applicable in the whole interaction strength range and is illustrated with three applications involving the AF ground state of the half-filled Hubbard model: (i) the pure model in two and three dimensions, (ii) spin vacancies in the strong coupling limit, and (iii) low-concentration impurities in the strong coupling limit.
• The method allows for the determination of the critical vacancy concentration at which the AF order parameter vanishes and shows that the point where the AF order parameter vanishes due to spin fluctuations nearly coincides with the percolation threshold.

* The text discusses the study of nonequilibrium dynamics in quantum field theory, with a focus on inflation and its dynamics in multi-field models.
* The work aims to understand the behavior of coupled, time-varying scalar fields and their fluctuations, including the effects of mixing between fields.
* The authors present a formalism for renormalizing the mean field evolution and energy density of the system, and apply it to a two-field case, studying the behavior of quantized mode functions and the effect of fluctuations on the zero mode equations of motion for various parameters.

* The existence of dark matter (dm) has been established, and its thermal relic abundance has been determined by the WMAP experiment.
* The weakly interacting massive particle (WIMP) is a promising candidate for dark matter.
* The Higgs triplet model (HTM) is a simple model for generating neutrino masses, but it does not contain a dark matter candidate.
* In a class of models where tiny neutrino masses are generated by higher orders of perturbation, the dm candidate can be naturally contained.
* In the HTM, majorana masses for neutrinos are generated via a yukawa interaction with a nonzero vacuum expectation value (vev) of an SU(2) triplet scalar field.
* The vev of the triplet field is described by a dimensionful parameter, which breaks lepton number conservation at the trilinear term.
* The structure of the neutrino mass matrix is given by that of the yukawa matrix in the HTM.
* The decay of the doubly charged component of the triplet field can provide direct information on the neutrino mass matrix.

<summary>
* Quantum key distribution (QKD) promises secure communication using quantum mechanics.
* New quantum communication technologies require a quantum-enabled telecommunications infrastructure.
* Quantum networks will contain novel components like quantum memories and repeaters.
* No technology is perfect, and quantum technologies offer practical challenges.
* Imperfections in quantum technologies can be tolerated by shifting efforts into classical post-processing of data.
* A minimal quantum requirement for devices is that they do not act as measure and prepare channels.
* To quantify a channel's quantum throughput, send part of an entangled state through the channel and determine the remaining entanglement.
* The prepare and measure (PM) scenario can be used to test for correlations in a bipartite system.
* The goal is to illustrate that device characterization via quantum throughput can be implemented in a meaningful way.
</summary>

• **Dipole Moments of Elementary Particles**: The study of dipole moments, particularly the magnetic dipole moment (MDM) and electric dipole moment (EDM), has provided valuable insights into subatomic physics, including the discovery of spin, radiative corrections, and the renormalizable theory of QED.

• **Muon g-2 Experiment**: The muon g-2 experiment at Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL) and CERN has measured the anomalous magnetic moment of the muon with high precision. The latest result from BNL's E821 experiment shows a discrepancy of 2.7 standard deviations from the Standard Model value, suggesting potential contributions from physics beyond the Standard Model.

• **Future Experiments**: Plans for future experiments include improving the precision of the muon g-2 measurement at BNL's E969 experiment and constructing a new experiment at J-PARC to search for a permanent EDM of the muon with a design sensitivity of 1.6 x 10^-24 e·cm.

• **Beyond the Standard Model**: The observation of an EDM in the muon or electron would signify physics beyond the Standard Model. Supersymmetric models and other dynamics at the TeV scale can predict EDMs at measurable levels.

• The paper presents a new design for an optomechanical system consisting of a microdisk resonator coupled to a waveguide.
• This design enables the study of reactive effects in optomechanical coupling, which originate from the mechanical motion dependence of the extrinsic losses of the disk resonator and phase-dependent gradient forces.
• The system is more effective in achieving cooling of the system to its ground state, which is desirable for studying quantum effects at the macroscopic scale.
• The paper focuses on investigating the effects of strong reactive coupling without cooling the system.
• The nonlinear response of the microdisk resonator to pump-probe fields is examined, revealing reactive-coupling-induced normal mode splitting.
• Previous works on normal mode splitting in optomechanical devices only considered dispersive coupling, while this paper reports on normal mode splitting due to reactive effects.
• The system is modeled with a strong pump field and a weak Stokes field entering through the waveguide, with the waveguide moving along the direction of the optical force exerted by the photons from the cavity.
• The Hamiltonian of the system is given, including terms for the energy of the cavity field, the energy of the waveguide, interactions between the waveguide and the incident fields, and the coupling of the cavity field to the pump and Stokes fields.
• The time evolutions of the expectation values of the system operators are solved, and the expectation value of the output fields is calculated using the input-output relation.
• Normal mode splitting in output fields is discussed, with no splitting observed in the absence of reactive coupling, but normal mode splitting occurring in the presence of reactive coupling.
• The system parameters are chosen based on a recent experiment, and the real and imaginary parts of the roots of the denominator of the Stokes response are examined numerically.
• For zero reactive coupling, the real parts of the roots always have two equal values, indicating no splitting. However, for nonzero reactive coupling, the real parts change from two equal values to two different values with increasing pump power, resulting in normal mode splitting of the output fields.
• The imaginary parts of the roots of the Stokes response change with increasing pump power for nonzero reactive coupling, further indicating that the normal mode splitting is solely due to reactive coupling.
• The output fields are analyzed in terms of their quadratures, with no splitting observed in the absence of reactive coupling, but normal mode splitting appearing in the presence of reactive coupling.
• The stokes field can be amplified by the stimulated process, with the maximum gain depending on the system parameters. The reactive coupling also generates anti-Stokes radiation.
• In conclusion,

* The article studies the dynamics of transverse magnetization transport in a one-dimensional quantum Ising chain out of equilibrium.
* The system is initially prepared with an inhomogeneity in transverse magnetization, which induces transport and relaxation dynamics in the presence of a constant external transverse field.
* The magnetization at each site exhibits oscillatory behavior with an envelope that decays algebraically in time, independent of the field strength.
* The system does not reach a homogeneous magnetization state even after infinite time, and the presence of odd-occupation states in the initial configuration is crucial for this behavior.

* <summary>
	+ The text discusses the behavior of QCD at finite baryon density, focusing on the structure of compact stars and conditions near the core of collapsing stars.
	+ The text mentions that sufficiently cold and dense baryonic matter is in the color superconducting phase, which was proposed by Frautschi and Barrois.
	+ The text also discusses the existence of thermal stable gapless color superconducting phases, confirmed in recent results based on more careful numerical calculations.
	+ The text highlights the puzzle of the chromomagnetic instability in the gapless phase, which remains an open question.
* </summary>

<summary>
* The debate about the properties of the melting phase transition of two-dimensional systems is ongoing, with the Kosterlitz-Thouless-Halperin-Nelson-Young (KTHNY) theory being the most widely accepted.
* Different studies have reported various types of transitions, including first-order, second-order, and KTHNY-like, depending on the system and the method used.
* The range of the potential and the dimensionality of the system can affect the formation of a stable hexatic phase.
* The authors of the paper argue that the observation of the hexatic phase is linked to the thermodynamic equilibration of the system, which can take significantly longer for collective relaxations than for local or single particle properties.
</summary>

• The Kepler mission has discovered over 4100 planetary candidates, many of which are super-Earths to mini-Neptunes, a size not found in our solar system.
• The transition from rocky to non-rocky planets occurs near a radius of 4 R⊕ and is very sharp.
• Assuming all Kepler candidate host stars are single can introduce a systematic uncertainty into the planetary radii and occurrence rate distributions.
• Undetected stellar companions can cause transit dilution, leading to underestimated planetary radii and overestimated planet bulk densities.
• Radial velocity and high-resolution imaging vetting can significantly reduce the mean planetary radius correction factor, especially for missions like K2 and TESS with closer targets.
• Undetected companions can affect the occurrence rates of different planet sizes, potentially pushing planets across the rocky/non-rocky boundary and impacting our understanding of the fraction of Earth-sized planets.

<summary>
* The range of HI column densities in nearby galaxies is similar to those seen in damped Lyα systems (DLAs).
* Mapping HI gas in DLAs using 21-cm emission is challenging due to the line's weakness and current technology limitations.
* DLAs are identified through absorption in background QSO spectra, which is not distance-dependent.
* There are few known DLAs with 21-cm emission within the reach of current radio telescopes.
* Most DLA host galaxies are faint and low surface brightness, making them difficult to identify optically.
* There are now ~100 known DLA galaxies, spanning a wide range in properties.
* A statistical study using local 21-cm emission data suggests that the local galaxy population can explain the incidence rate and properties of DLAs.
* The median DLA host galaxy is expected to be sub-L* and a dwarf, making their identification challenging.
</summary>

<summary>
* Star clusters form in molecular clouds, with only a small percentage of gas turned into stars.
* Gas expulsion due to stellar winds and supernovae causes clusters to become out of equilibrium.
* This paper studies the luminosity profiles of three young massive clusters: M82-F, NGC 1569-A, and NGC 1705-1.
* Observations show an excess of light at large radii, suggesting the clusters are not in dynamical equilibrium.
* Simulations of gas expulsion and violent relaxation reproduce these profiles.
* Rapid gas loss can cause clusters to dissolve, contributing to "infant mortality."
* Virial mass estimates can be significantly wrong for several tens of Myr after gas expulsion.
* Claims of unusual initial mass functions in young clusters may be incorrect due to non-equilibrium dynamics.
</summary>

<summary>
* The text discusses the interplay between quantum fluctuation, tunneling, and decoherence in a one-dimensional double-well system driven by a polychromatic external field.
* The system's Hamiltonian is given by equation (2), with parameters defined in the following equations.
* The system is initially in a Gaussian wavepacket localized in the right well.
* The recurrence time for the wavepacket in the unperturbed case is given by equation (19).
* The transition probability of finding the wavepacket in the left well is defined as equation (25).
* The text presents numerical results for the time dependence of the transition probability for various combinations of perturbation strength and number of frequency components.
* The degree of coherence of the tunneling probability is defined as equation (37).
* The text discusses the classification of motion in the parameter space based on the degree of coherence.
* The reduction of the tunneling period in the regular motion regime is considered.
* The uncertainty product, a measure of quantum fluctuation, is investigated.
</summary>

* The stochastic formalism for open quantum systems is presented, starting from the stochastic Liouville equation (SLE) and deriving the exact reduced density matrix.
* The SLE is solved using two approaches: spectral expansion and generalized hierarchical equations (GHE).
* The spectral expansion approach is efficient for bosonic bath models with simple spectral expansions, while the GHE approach can handle non-gaussian, fermionic, and bosonic bath models with arbitrary spectral densities and temperature regimes.
* The paper focuses on the spin bath model, presenting two approaches: using complex-valued noises and the dual-fermion representation.

<summary>
* The glass transition is a change from a liquid to an amorphous solid, marked by a sharp increase in relaxation times and departure from equilibrium.
* The Kauzmann temperature is where only one minimum-energy basin is accessible, proposed as the ideal glass transition point.
* Some studies suggest a thermodynamic transition at the Kauzmann temperature, while others find no evidence of it in simulations of hard-core disks.
* Mode coupling theory (MCT) predicts a dynamic transition at a critical temperature (T_c), with all structural correlations decaying in a final process.
* The full MCT shows no sharp transition at T_c, with effects from transverse currents and thermally activated matter transport.
* The nonergodicity parameters of the idealized MCT can be used to estimate T_c, given the partial structure factors of the system.
* The paper investigates a Ni-Zr glass-forming system using molecular dynamics simulations, focusing on determining T_c from the nonergodicity parameter, the f-parameter in the ergodic regime, and diffusion coefficients.
* The Ni-Zr system is well-studied and important in multi-component metallic glasses, with the present contribution focusing on the Ni68Zr32 composition.
</summary>

<summary>
* The text discusses a method for analyzing longitudinal dyadic data with nonignorable dropouts using a selection model approach.
* The method models the longitudinal measurement process using a transition model that includes both patient and spouse characteristics as covariates to capture interdependence.
* Dyad-specific random effects are introduced to account for within-dyad correlation.
* A discrete time survival model is used to jointly model the missing data mechanism, linking the dropout process to the longitudinal measurement process.
* The method uses a data augmentation approach to address the complex missing data problem caused by dropout and interdependence within dyads.
</summary>

• Quantum fluctuations of electric and magnetic fields give rise to a zero-point energy that never vanishes, even in the absence of electromagnetic sources.
• Two electrically neutral metallic parallel plates in vacuum should attract each other with a force inversely proportional to the fourth power of separation, according to Casimir's prediction.
• Lifshitz, Dzyaloshinskii, and Pitaevskii generalized Casimir's theory to isotropic dielectrics, showing that the force between two uncharged parallel plates with arbitrary dielectric functions can be derived according to an analytical formula.
• The torque between two parallel birefringent plates, predicted by Parseghian, Weiss, and Barash, has not been experimentally validated or numerically calculated until this paper.
• The authors calculate the magnitude of the torque induced by quantum fluctuations for specific materials and discuss possible experimental validations of the effect.

* The study of complex networks has increased, with applications ranging from computer science to social science and finance.
* A central problem in network science is the study of random walks on graphs and their relation to the topological properties of the network.
* The authors introduce a new framework for topologically biased random walks (TBRW) to address problems of community detection and synchronization in complex networks.
* The paper presents mathematical tools to investigate the bias parameters space and uncover details in the spectra of graph transition matrices.
* The authors define conditions for a maximal spectral gap and present numerical evidence that this maximum is global.
* The paper outlines a methodology for applying TBRW in community finding problems and discusses potential applications of TBRW in various fields.

<summary>
* The text discusses the threat of active p2p worms that exploit p2p overlay applications for rapid infection.
* The authors propose a holistic immunity system using phagocytes, a small subset of immune p2p hosts, to defend against these worms.
* Phagocytes monitor managed p2p hosts' connection patterns and traffic volume to detect worm attacks.
* Upon detection, phagocytes perform local isolation, alert propagation, and software patching to contain the worm.
* Phagocytes also provide access control and filtering mechanisms to prevent external worm attacks.
* The system forbids p2p traffic from leaking to external hosts and hides p2p hosts' IP addresses using a scalable distributed DNS service.
* An adaptive and interaction-based computational puzzle scheme is used to prevent external hosts from attacking the p2p overlay.
* The authors implemented a prototype system and evaluated its performance on a massive-scale testbed with realistic p2p network traces.
</summary>

<summary>
* Debris disks around main sequence stars are an intermediate stage between protoplanetary disks and mature systems like our solar system.
* The infrared luminosity of these disks is much higher than that of our solar system's asteroid and Kuiper belts.
* Only a few edge-on debris disks have been found to exhibit gas phase absorption, with HD 32297 being one of them.
* Observations of HD 32297 reveal two absorption components, one likely caused by circumstellar material and the other by interstellar material.
* The circumstellar absorption toward HD 32297 is the strongest detected around a nearby main sequence debris disk star.
</summary>

<summary>
* Gravity is a universal and fundamental force, affecting and being affected by any object with energy.
* The Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle (HUP) breaks down at the Planck scale, where the Schwarzschild radius becomes comparable to the Compton wavelength.
* Quantum gravity theories predict a minimum measurable length, which is model-independent and can be understood from the breakdown of HUP.
* The Generalized Uncertainty Principle (GUP) is a formulation of the uncertainty principle that holds at all scales and is represented by a specific equation.
* The parameter α in GUP is expected to be of order unity, but current experiments predict large upper bounds on it, suggesting the existence of an intermediate length scale.
* Quantum gravity effects influence all quantum Hamiltonians, and some phenomenological implications have been presented.
* Doubly Special Relativity (DSR) theories also suggest a similar modification of commutators, leading to a minimum measurable length and a maximum measurable momentum.
* The authors investigate the effects of quantum gravity on the Planck era of the universe using different versions of GUP and evaluate modifications to several quantities, enhancing understanding of quantum gravity consequences.
</summary>

• The authors present generic arguments for the renormalization of operators in a conformal field theory (CFT) deformed by a marginal or irrelevant operator.
• They show that the matrix element of two operators is determined by the coupling between them.
• For the case of N=4 supersymmetric Yang-Mills (SYM) theory at weak 't Hooft coupling, they use integrability to compute the couplings of operators to the Lagrangian.
• They also present a new method to compute 3-point correlation functions of single trace operators in SYM at strong coupling using the AdS/CFT duality.

• The paper presents a relativistic embedding scheme for solving the Dirac equation in a limited region (i) of a larger system (i@xmath102ii).
• The scheme replaces region ii with an additional term in the Hamiltonian for region i, acting on the surface separating i and ii.
• The embedding scheme is derived using a trial function with a discontinuous small component, and the problem of variational collapse is avoided by using a kinetically balanced basis set.

<summary>
* The analysis of dynamic processes in complex networks is a major research area with applications in social, biological, and technological systems.
* The spread of information, evolution of epidemics, and cascading failures in networks are relevant examples of these processes.
* Most modeling and analysis techniques are tailored to static networks, but real-world networks evolve over time.
* The interplay between the dynamics on and of networks is an important research direction.
* A simple adaptive rewiring mechanism in epidemic models can induce complex dynamics.
* The adaptive susceptible-infected-susceptible (ASIS) model accounts for arbitrary contact patterns and network adaptation mechanisms.
* The lack of tools for analyzing network adaptation mechanisms hinders effective control strategies.
* The paper derives a lower bound on the epidemic threshold of the heterogeneous ASIS model for arbitrary networks and heterogeneous node and edge dynamics.
* The lower bound is proportional to the epidemic threshold of the standard susceptible-infected-susceptible (SIS) model over a static network in the homogeneous case.
