• The system determines periods of inactivity of the imaging device.
• The system measures the toner charge level when the device is recovered from inactivity.
• The system calculates the decay of the toner charge based on the difference between the measured charge and a predetermined level.
• The system charges the toner to a predetermined level based on the calculated decay.
• The system may also predict the next user usage based on a user usage pattern.
• The system may store information on user usage patterns, predicted next user usage, sensor levels, and calculated decay for future use.
• The system may perform a pre-run of the machine to ensure the developer is at an adequate charge level for normal printing.
• The system may use an adaptive algorithm to determine the user pattern and predict future behavior.

• The invention provides a rotary magnetic head type apparatus capable of controlling with high precision the recording and reproduction of signals by plural heads, including MR heads, mounted on a rotary drum.
• The apparatus comprises a control signal generator for generating control signals for controlling the operating amperages of MR heads and a decoder circuit for discriminating data of the control signals and a current supply circuit for supplying operating currents to the MR heads in response to the output signals of the decoder circuit.
• The apparatus also comprises a regenerative integrated circuit comprising a current supply circuit and a regenerative amplifier, and a control signal generator for generating control signals for controlling the regenerative integrated circuit, with the control signals including control information regarding a regenerative amplifier for reproduced outputs of the MR heads and recording current setting for recording heads.

<summary>
* The invention improves locating and tracing of one concealed object (e.g., pipe or cable) in the presence of an adjacent object.
* A transmitter with two antennae induces distinguishable alternating currents in the objects.
* A receiver senses magnetic fields associated with these currents and produces an output signal dependent on both fields.
* The currents can be distinguished by using different carrier frequencies, modulation frequencies, or pulse rates.
* The transmitter's position is optimized for better performance, ideally centered between the objects.
* The receiver's output signal characteristic shows distinct nulls over each object, making tracing easier and more accurate.
</summary>

• The invention provides an apparatus for interfacing a speaker phone with a telephone network for hands-free automatic answering and communication.
• The apparatus includes a selector switch for choosing between regular and automatic operation modes.
• In automatic mode, an incoming call is answered automatically and connected to the speaker phone for a predetermined or extended duration.
• The apparatus includes a timer to limit the call duration and an extend switch to bypass the timer for extended conversations.
• The apparatus can be implemented using electronic or electromechanical components.

<summary>
* The invention describes a repeaterless trunk and branch ring network for optical fiber communications.
* The network combines trunk and branch structures with a ring geometry for enhanced survivability.
* Optical energy is transmitted over the same branch cables that distribute communications signals to power remote optical amplifiers.
* A light emitting power source is coupled to the branch fiber optic cable, transmitting energy unidirectionally.
* The energy is used to amplify attenuated optical signals in an optical amplifier located in the branch fiber optic cable, the optical fiber cable trunk, or the branching unit.
* The network reduces the number of undersea optical repeaters required, lowering capital and operating costs.
* The invention is particularly well suited for undersea applications, but can also be used in terrestrial communications systems.
</summary>

* The invention provides a cover plate device for wall-mounted electrical wiring devices that hides all fasteners and can accommodate walls that are not flat or even.
* The device consists of an attachment member that is mounted to the wiring device and a cover plate member that latches onto the attachment member using independent pawls and racks, allowing for compensation of wall irregularities.

* The collapsible light-shielding device for a screen consists of concentrically nested annular strips that slide over one another between a pushed-in and pushed-out position.
* The strips have a decreasing wall thickness in the axial direction, allowing the device to be set to various angular positions relative to the screen.

<summary>
* The invention provides a solution to automatically inform a speaker to decrease their speaking rate when it likely exceeds a rate that a listener can understand.
* The speaking rate threshold can be based on the listener's estimated or known listening rate, which can vary based on their proficiency with the language being spoken.
* The speaker can be notified through a wearable computing device that vibrates, beeps, blinks, speaks a message, displays a message, or uses other sensory mechanisms.
* The invention can also suggest an alternative language for the discourse if both the speaker and listener are proficient in it.
* The invention can be implemented as a program for controlling computing equipment or as a method performed by a service agent and/or a machine manipulated by a service agent in response to a service request.
</summary>

<summary>
* The device uses a TV camera to record rapid processes with a high and selectable resolution in time.
* It deviates and suppresses the beam to make the scanning beam run successively and cyclically over N lines of a picture plane.
* A cyclic line counter carries out one counting step for each line pulse and supplies an end-of-count pulse after p line pulses, where N/p is an integer greater than 1.
* A sawtooth generator synchronized with the output pulses of the counter controls the vertical deviation of the beam.
</summary>

• The present invention provides a solution for integrating voice calls with multimedia sessions in a packet switched network.
• A blended call is a call that blends voice and multimedia functions into a single communication session.
• A multimedia server with blender software is associated with a telephony server to manage blended calls.
• For incoming calls, the telephony server determines if the intended recipient supports blended capabilities.
• If the recipient supports blended capabilities, the telephony server directs the call to the multimedia server with blender software.
• The blender software initiates a single session with two call components: a voice call component and a multimedia call component.
• The blender software controls the signaling paths of the parallel components and may integrate them into a single signaling path for the multimedia server to control the bearer paths.

• The present invention provides a content synchronization framework for connected devices, enabling any device to synchronize with a central reference point based on contextual information or dynamic attributes shared with the central reference point.
• The central reference point constructs a response in a semantic compatible with the connected device, comprising one or more file description bundles prioritized for download.
• The client device creates a delta list of bundle files to replace out-of-date or missing files on the client device and downloads the files in the prioritized order.
• The client device overwrites local copies of the bundle files with the downloaded files, confirms complete download of the bundles, and rejects incompletely downloaded bundles.

<summary>
* The invention provides a system for facilitating communication between a finder of an object and an owner of the object.
* The system includes a unique ID provided to the owner, which is associated with the owner's contact information in a database.
* The owner can associate the ID and a virtual locale (e.g., a website address) with the object.
* The finder can communicate with the owner by providing the ID and the communication to the virtual locale.
* The system forwards the finder's communication to the owner using the owner's contact information from the database.
* The system maintains anonymity for both the finder and the owner by using anonymous email addresses.
</summary>

• The invention relates to electron multipliers, specifically foil electron multipliers used in photomultipliers and particle detectors.
• Foil electron multipliers use a series of thin foils in an evacuated enclosure to multiply electrons in transmission stages.
• Each foil acts as a discrete multiplication stage, with a voltage applied to accelerate electrons.
• The foils are held by foil holders in the evacuated enclosure and arranged collinearly or in an array along an arc.
• The voltage on each stage can be applied using resistors or separate power supplies, creating an electric field gradient.
• Incident particles transit through the first foil, generating secondary electrons that are accelerated towards the next foil.
• The secondary electrons are transmitted through the next foil with a probability T SE, depending on the foil thickness and accelerating potential.
• The electron multiplication process continues at each foil stage, resulting in a growing avalanche of electrons collected on the anode.
• The mean gain of the foil electron multiplier is given by Equation 2, with factors affecting gain including electron transmission, grid transmission, and secondary electron emission yield.
• The foil electron multiplier has a higher gain efficiency than conventional electron multipliers, requiring fewer stages for the same charge amplification.

• The 3-D Phenomenoscope invention allows ordinary 2-dimensional motion pictures to be viewed in part as a 3-dimensional experience.
• It takes advantage of the Pulfrich effect, which makes lateral motion of an ordinary motion picture appear in 3-Dimensions.
• Ordinary glasses are configured with right and left lenses that can be individually controlled, a digital photo sensor to capture viewed motion picture frames, a computer processor and algorithm to process the frames and identify synchronization events, and means to control the darkness of the lenses based on the identified synchronization events.
• The preferred embodiment uses an intensity edge map algorithm to detect lateral motion in the motion picture and control the state of the viewer glasses.
• The 3-D Phenomenoscope works with any form of motion picture media, including film, digital film, VCR tape, DVD, PC computer screen, plasma and LCD displays.
• The battery-powered viewer glasses are controlled in real-time by an intelligent processor packaged with the glasses, so 3-dimensional viewing works equally well whether the movie is viewed on a TV, DVD player, PC, or in a movie house.
• Since darkening of the lenses to obtain the 3-dimensional illusion is only activated when sustained lateral motion is detected, eyestrain and discomfort is greatly reduced.
• The 3-D Phenomenoscope invention solves problems and constraints involving the production, projection, and viewing of 3-dimensional motion pictures.
• It allows any motion picture with a degree of sustained lateral motion to be viewed with the visual effect of 3-dimensions.

* The invention describes a method and apparatus for singulating semiconductor wafers using pressure instead of a wafer saw.
* Trenches are formed along scribe lines on the wafer, and then mechanical pressure is applied to cause a "clean break" along the trenches, singulating the individual die.
* The apparatus includes a pad for supporting the wafer, a positioning member to position the wafer on the pad, and a pressure mechanism to apply mechanical pressure to the wafer.

<summary>
* The present invention provides a protection structure for field emission display devices to prevent burnout damage to field emission elements.
* The protection structure includes one or more reduction plates or electrodes on the cathode, which alter the discharge path of ionized gases away from the cathode.
* A bias voltage source applies a negative voltage to the reduction plates, attracting positive nitrogen and oxygen ions and preventing current-induced damage to the field emission elements.
* In one embodiment, multiple elongated reduction plates run parallel and adjacent to rows of field emission elements.
* In another embodiment, the reduction plates are arranged in a meshwork- or net-shaped configuration among the field emission elements.
* The reduction plates can be fabricated on the cathode at the same time as the cathode strips using photolithography and etching techniques.
</summary>

<summary>
* The image sensor of the present invention includes a semiconductor substrate with opposed major surfaces and opposed edges, one of which is receptive to light.
* An image sensor element is formed in the substrate adjacent to the light-receptive edge, comprising a charge collection and transfer means and an image sensing region.
* The image sensing region generates charge carriers when light impinges on the surface of the light-receptive edge.
* The substrate includes means for guiding charge carriers in the image sensing region toward the charge collection and transfer means.
* The substrate comprises a bottom layer highly doped with a P-type material and an upper layer more lightly doped with a P-type material.
* The image sensor element includes a photodiode in the image sensing region and a buried-channel CCD as the charge collection and transfer means.
* A P+ layer is formed in the top surface of the image sensor between each edge surface and the column of image sensor elements adjacent to the edge surface.
* The image sensor can be used to image in a plurality of planes, including the top surface and the two edge surfaces.
* The image sensor can be used in various applications, such as simultaneously imaging a plurality of planes or color applications with suitable filters and optics.
</summary>

<summary>
* A home network includes devices that can serve as either a network master node or a network slave node.
* The network master node performs network administrative functions in addition to its nominal device functions.
* The network slave node performs only its nominal device functions.
* The network master node can transfer the network administrative functions to a network slave node.
* The network slave node can accept the transfer of the network administrative functions from the network master node.
* The network slave node can become the new network master node after accepting the transfer of the network administrative functions.
* The network master node can select a network slave node to transfer the network administrative functions to based on predetermined selection criteria.
</summary>

• The invention relates to an antenna array for measuring the direction of propagation of electromagnetic radiation using radio interferometric techniques.
• The array comprises at least four antennae spaced to form at least two equi-spaced linear triplets perpendicular to a ground plane, with each triplet characterized by its element spacing and height above the ground plane.
• The array provides a measure of the elevation angle of a radio wave arriving from a remote source, independent of the ground reflection coefficient, by combining and processing the signals from the antennae in each triplet.

* The invention provides a subminiature lamp assembly with a high temperature polymer that directly surrounds and is in compression contact with the glass envelope, providing extended axial length sealing, heat resistance, ease of handling, and increased resistance to invasion and chemical attack.
* The assembly uses a fluoroelastomer as the preferred type of elastomer, which has excellent heat resistance and resistance to aggressive fuels and chemicals, and can maintain a seal at a range of temperatures from low to high.

• The present invention provides a method for configuring a GDFE based precoder in a MU-MIMO wireless system, which significantly reduces computational cost while resulting in no capacity loss.
• The method relaxes the requirement for knowledge of the covariance matrix S zz corresponding to "Least Favorable Noise" and provides a uniform framework for realizing a GDFE Precoder.
• Unlike conventional GDFE Precoder design, the proposed method does not require channel reduction when the Input Covariance Matrix S xx for downlink channel is rank deficient.
• The method achieves significant improvement in computational cost over conventional GDFE Precoders.
• An alternative method for computing the filter matrix C is provided, which can be used when the rank of channel matrix H is less than its number of rows.
• The method provides a way to compute matrices B, G and F of the GDFE Precoder without any knowledge of S zz.

• The invention relates to a heat-dissipating device and a housing thereof, specifically an axial fan with improved intake airflow rate and heat-dissipating performance.
• The fan housing has an outer frame with a passage for guiding air streams from an opening to another opening.
• An sidewall of the passage at one of the opening sides extends radially outwards to enlarge the intake or discharge area for air streams.
• The sidewall extends radially outwardly with respect to a central axis of the passage in a symmetrical manner.
• Alternatively, the sidewall extends radially outwardly with respect to a longitudinal axis of the passage and beyond the peripheral edge of the outer frame.
• The sidewall may also extend radially outwardly with respect to a longitudinal axis of the passage in a frustum-conical or a frustum-elliptically conical manner.
• The sidewall of the passage is preferably formed with an inclined portion or a beveled edge there around.
• The housing includes an air inlet, an air outlet, and a passage for guiding air streams from the air inlet to the air outlet.
• An sidewall of the passage at the air inlet side extends radially outwardly to enlarge an intake area of the air streams.
• The radially outward extension of the sidewall of the passage at the air inlet side is partially cut off to form a notch, enlarging an intake area for lateral side air streams.

* The electroluminescent display panel can display different colors by changing the driving voltage, without using an intermediate electrode.
* The panel can display images in green at night time and in a lemon color at day time, with a high luminance.

• The invention relates to an electronic portable communications terminal for Internet/network telephony, comprising audio means, converting means, protocol means, and wireless communications means for near field communication with a connecting unit adapted to establish a connection to a network and/or the Internet according to a standardized Internet/network protocol.
• The terminal is adapted to communicate additional information and/or data with the connecting unit, such as an IP address of a communication receiver, an IP address of a communication transmitter/said terminal, an IP address of at least one connecting unit, an IP address of a service server, TCP/IP packets, speech mails, commercials, music, stock exchange and financial news, chat-lines, chat-rooms, and telephone meetings.

<summary>
* Pb/Bi-containing high-dielectric materials are convenient but have issues with reactivity and diffusion.
* Growth of oxides on Si results in the formation of a low dielectric constant SiO2 or silicate layer.
* A Ge buffer layer on Si reduces reactivity and enhances epitaxy.
* A thin layer of SrTiO3 or other stable high-dielectric oxide can act as a chemical barrier and nucleate the desired perovskite structure.
* For large density capacitors, (Ba1-x,Srx)TiO3 (BST) is a good linear dielectric.
* Ge has a much smaller free energy of oxidation than Si, making it compatible with BST and BT/ST deposition.
* Not all oxides are stable next to Ge, but a thin layer of SrTiO3 or other stable ferroelectric can act as a buffer.
* A Ge buffer layer allows the integration of Pb/Bi-containing ferroelectrics on GaAs for various applications.
* A Ge buffer layer enables the fabrication of non-volatile, non-destructive readout field effect memories using ferroelectrics.
* The use of a second Ge layer allows a wider variety of conductors for the top electrode and higher temperature processing.
</summary>

* The invention provides a receiver input circuit with multiple amplification control loops to minimize distortions caused by non-linear components.
* The control loops include a first loop for protecting the mixer stage and varactor diodes, a second loop for protecting the mixer stage and oscillator, and optionally a third loop for supporting the other control circuits or reducing the response threshold for stronger spurious signals.

• The invention provides a system for initiating a collaborative work-share environment between two or more parties to a telephone call without complex setup processes.
• Each party to a telephone call is provided with a collaboration button and an indicator on their telephone set.
• When the indicator is illuminated, the system is capable of establishing a work-share environment.
• In response to one of the parties activating the collaboration button, the system causes network enabled applications to run on the individual users' desktop computers.
• The telephone is used in the usual way to make regular, voice-only, telephone calls.
• Once a call is established, the telephones communicate with each other to determine if they each are associated with equipment which would allow richer collaboration between their respective users.
• If such equipment is available then the indicator on at least one of the telephones is lit, indicating that richer collaboration is possible.
• If the talking parties decide that they would like to share a document or set up a video conference, this may be initiated by either party pushing the collaboration button.

* The invention relates to a method for inserting an advertising clip into a video sequence at a point called an insertion point, where the clip is selected based on the similarity of its salience map to that of the video sequence before the insertion point.
* The degree of similarity is determined by comparing the location of salience zones on both maps, and the clip with the highest degree of similarity is selected for insertion.

• The invention addresses high electric field concentrations at intersections of sub-250 nanometer conductive regions in semiconductor devices, which can lead to electrical breakdown and leakage.
• It proposes a structure where the mask layer is positioned below the high electric field locations, reducing the likelihood of breakdown and leakage.
• The mask layer is positioned 0.5 to 20 nanometers, preferably 5 nanometers, below the surface to be planarized, protecting the dielectric material and maintaining the integrity of the conductive region walls.
• The invention is particularly useful in damascene-type device structures, where adjacent conductors are disposed in thin trenches in an intralevel dielectric material, and a dielectric cap is applied over the metal lines and the masking layer.
• The process involves removing mask material after chemical-mechanical polishing, down to a level away from the high electric field points, and continuing until a selected mask thickness is reached.
• The structure of the invention results in a lower and predictable overall capacitance, leading to faster signal propagation in the interconnect wiring.

* The Downconverting Digitizer is an analog-to-digital converter that also performs downconversion to baseband and automatic gain control.
* It uses a predictive loop with a digital filter to generate a prediction of the input signal and minimize the prediction error.
* The digital filter can be reprogrammed to match the input signal characteristics and achieve higher dynamic range and lower quantization noise.
* The converter also includes an offset nuller to dynamically detect and remove offsets, and an automatic gain control loop to maintain the input signal level within the dynamic range of the predictive loop.

* <summary>
* The invention describes a method for fabricating arrays of nano-scale features on a single wafer to form a sensor device or a matrix of devices for multiplex detection of selected analytes using many simultaneous detection zones.
* The method involves using nanoimprint lithography to define groups of semiconducting nanotraces between electrodes.
* The groups of semiconducting nanotraces can be used as a sensor or, when anchored probe molecules are covalently coupled or synthesized to the surfaces, be used for multiplex detection of analytes.
* The fabrication of a set of parallel semiconducting nanotraces serves to homogenize the total response to changes in the local environment near the surface of each nanotrace.
* The response is proportional to the degree in which the electrical current traversing the set of semiconducting nanotraces is influenced by changes in the electric field strength near the surface of each nanotrace.
* The local environment can be a gas phase, an aqueous buffer sampling for complementary nucleic acids, or a solid environment such as an electrophoresis gel sampling for nucleotides on a nucleic acid sequence.
* Binding of complementary targets to the anchored probe molecules in the vicinity of the semiconducting active layer produces a change in electrical conductivity of the semiconducting active layer that can be monitored externally for each sensor device in the array in parallel.
* The fabrication of a set of parallel semiconducting nanotraces provides a means for detection of gases adsorbed on the semiconductor surfaces or multiplex detection of many simultaneous detection zones.
* </summary>

* The present invention provides a method of singulating semiconductor packages that includes plating the side surfaces of the leads of the leadframe to prevent contamination of the lead surfaces.
* The method involves providing a plurality of semiconductor dies coupled to a single common leadframe, singulating the plurality of semiconductor dies, and plating the exposed side surfaces of the leads with a plating material.
* The leads are preferably copper, and the plating material is preferably a metallic material configured not to react with oxygen, such as tin, silver, gold, nickel-gold, nickel-palladium, or nickel-palladium-gold.
* The singulation process can be performed in one full cutting operation or in two partial cutting operations.
* If the singulation process is performed in one full cutting operation, the leadframe is cut all the way between the top surface and the bottom surface.
* If the singulation process is performed in two partial cutting operations, the first partial cut does not extend all the way between the bottom surface and the top surface, and the second partial cut completes the singulation of the semiconductor dies all the way between the bottom surface and the top surface of the leadframe.

<summary>
* The mobile terminal can selectively connect to a wireless wide area network (WWAN) or a wireless local area network (WLAN).
* The WLAN gathers information about neighboring base stations from an access point and provides this information to the mobile terminal.
* The mobile terminal uses this information to skip some initial scanning procedures when connecting to the WWAN, accelerating the connection process.
* The mobile terminal can switch between the WWAN and WLAN based on a set of rules, such as signal strength thresholds.
</summary>

• The invention provides a new process for manufacturing multilayered electrical components, such as capacitors, by eliminating the need for cutting and metallizing steps.
• The process involves forming multiple electrodes and electrical components on carriers, such as decals, to create laminate sub-assemblies.
• The sub-assemblies are then stacked in a precise manner to form a resultant assembly, which can be fired to create the final electrical component.
• The process allows for the inspection of both the electrode print and dielectric print for perfection and thickness before commitment to actual construction.
• The process enables the production of smaller parts, lower voltage ratings, and no shape limitations, among other advantages.
• The process is adaptable to a number of other electronic ceramic devices, such as multilayer ferrite inductors, multilayer substrates, semiconductor packages, and precision resistors.

• The present invention relates to cellular materials used in structural applications, specifically materials comprising hierarchical cellular lattices and related methods of use and manufacture.
• The lattice structures utilize a network of hierarchical trusses, synergistically arranged, to provide support and other functionalities.
• The lattice structures maintain a low weight while providing high specific stiffness and strength.
• Sandwich panels are used in a variety of applications, including sea, land, and air transportation, ballistics, blast and impact impulse mitigation, thermal transfer, multifunctional structures, armors, ballistics, load bearing, construction materials, and containers.
• The lattice structures may be implemented with or as part of floors, columns, beams, walls, jet or rocket nozzles, land, air or water vehicles/ships, armor, etc.
• The lattice structures may be curved, such that they do not rest on a flat surface, and may be used to form the shell of a cylinder or a rocket or jet fuel nozzle.
• The lattice structures may be used to form walls or floors for housings, compartments, buildings, floors, vehicles, or infrastructure.
• The lattice structures have many applications, including use as the cores of sandwich panel structures, construction of materials with improved impact or blast load mitigation, superior cross flow heat exchange, high ballistic resistance, and energy absorption.
• The lattice structures may be manufactured in various ways, including injection molding, lattice block construction, constructed metal lattice, and metal textile lay-up techniques.
• The lattice structures may be used as templates for further processing, such as investment casting or deposition of other materials.

* The process involves co-producing power and hydrocarbons by integrating a coal-to-liquid (CTL) facility with an Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle (IGCC) facility.
* The CTL facility uses a combination of dry and wet gasification technologies to produce synthesis gas for hydrocarbon synthesis and power production, respectively, while the IGCC facility generates power using the combustion gas produced by the wet gasification stage.

• The present invention provides a method for preparing a solid device using an oxide superconducting material with improved surface properties.
• A blocking film (passivation film) is uniformly coated over the spaces or micro-holes in the surface portion of the superconducting material to prevent the removal of oxygen.
• The blocking film is formed using a photo CVD method, which is superior in stepped coverage, at a thickness of 10 Å to 2 µm.
• After forming the film, oxygen is added to the surface or portion close to the surface of the superconducting material using methods such as ion injection or hot oxidation.
• The entire body is then heat treated to position the added oxygen in the appropriate atom location and convert the film to a highly dense insulating material, providing a more complete blocking layer.

* The invention is an apparatus for preparing foam sheet samples for microscopic examination.
* It uses a screw thread mechanism to advance the foam sheet in precise increments, allowing for parallel cuts to be made with a razor blade, preserving the cell structure for examination.

• The invention is a method and apparatus for determining the angle of inclination of a seismometer, such as an on-bottom seismometer, with respect to the vertical.
• The apparatus comprises a spherical ball, a shaft, and a seismic motion detector, all arranged to form a pendulum.
• The spherical ball rests in an annular seat in a mounting plate, which is affixed to the door of the seismometer's instrument compartment.
• The shaft protrudes from the spherical ball and the seismic motion detector is mounted at the end of the shaft.
• The pendulum action of the invention automatically aligns the seismic motion detector with respect to the vertical for proper operation.
• A plunger is provided to lock the spherical ball, shaft, and seismic motion detector in their assumed orientation.
• The plunger is cocked for operation by aligning a first bore in the mounting plate and a second bore in the plunger shaft, allowing a pin to engage the plunger shaft and restrain the plunger from contacting the spherical ball.
• A solenoid is provided to remove the pin from the plunger shaft, allowing the plunger to extend and lock the spherical ball, shaft, and seismic motion detector in their assumed orientation.
• The angle of inclination of the seismometer can be determined by measuring the acute angle formed by the line passing through the center of gravity of the seismic motion detector and the center of the spherical ball in their locked position and the position they assume when hanging freely in the seismometer in its normal, up-right position.

• The humidity sensing element consists of a first electron conductive electrode, a porous dielectric coating, minute electron conductive particles, a second electron conductive electrode, and an ion-forming material.
• The impedance between the electrodes varies linearly with the relative humidity of the surrounding gaseous atmosphere when excited by a suitable alternating current voltage.
• The element is manufactured by coating the first electrode with a porous dielectric, depositing electron conductive particles, contacting the particles with an ion-forming material, and forming the second electrode on the dielectric.

<summary>
* The motor assembly includes a motor, a gear train, and a force transmission structure.
* The gear train comprises a worm, a worm gear, a damper, a drive plate, and a shaft.
* The force transmission structure comprises the drive plate and the shaft.
* The drive plate has a Y-shaped mounting hole with three interconnected sections.
* The shaft has a Y-shaped toothed portion with three teeth fittingly received in the mounting hole of the drive plate.
* The drive plate is driven by the worm gear through the damper.
* The damper has first slots for receiving ribs of the worm gear and second slots for engaging with protrusions of the drive plate.
* The protrusions of the drive plate are V-shaped and increase in width from the inner most portion towards the outer most portion.
* The shaft is held captive within the mounting hole by a circlip located within a groove in the distal end of the toothed portion.
</summary>

• The invention provides a method and system for generating a mobile time reference in a portable transceiver.
• The mobile time reference is generated using a high frequency clock (30.72 MHz) and maintained using a low frequency clock (32 KHz) when the high frequency clock is not available.
• The mobile time reference is used for detecting, identifying, and monitoring multipath signals in a WCDMA system.

<summary>
* Our invention provides an individually fitted helmet liner with a plurality of elastic thermoplastic sheets, each formed with an array of open, unfilled pockets.
* The sheets are arranged in superposed contacting relationship, allowing their pockets to deform in response to compressive contact with an adjacent layer.
* The liner is fitted to a wearer's head by heating the sheets to a plastic state, placing the liner between an outer fixture and the wearer's head, and removing it when cooled.
* The open, unfilled pockets provide compliance to smooth out effects of relative layer alignment and conform to the wearer's head contours, minimizing position shifts.
* The lack of incompressible spacer elements eliminates the need for drawstrings during size adjustment.
* The liner can be refitted to accommodate a changed head size within the same size range.
* The manufacturing process is simplified and less expensive compared to previous methods.
</summary>

• The invention is a multiorifice wafer structure with angularly disposed passages, made by fusing concentric layers of rods and cylindrical members, each successive layer of rods being disposed at a progressively larger angle with respect to the axis of the fused assembly.
• The structure is cut into thin wafers, with the interstices between the fused layers of rods and cylindrical members forming angularly disposed passageways that increase in angle as a function of their distance from the center of the structure.
• The thickness of the wafer is determined by the effective aperture of the interstices and is sufficient to impart to the fluid passing through the interstices a directional component parallel to the angular displacement of the rods with respect to the common axis of the structure.

• The invention provides a method of manufacturing a semiconductor device with improved controllability of the width of the oxide portion on the gate sidewall by forming an insulating film on the gate electrode, followed by forming a layer on the insulating film and anisotropically etching it using RIE to leave a portion thereof on the gate sidewall.
• The method also includes forming a low density region of the source/drain by ion injection of an impurity using the gate electrode and the insulating film on the gate as a mask, anisotropically etching the conductive layer to leave a portion thereof on the gate sidewall, and forming a high density region of the source/drain by ion injection of an impurity using the gate electrode and the portion of the conductive layer on the gate sidewall as a mask.

• The invention provides an enhanced radio telephone that can operate as both a conventional wireless telephone and an improved IP telephone.
• The enhanced radio telephone includes a speech coder and decoder for compressing and decompressing speech signals, which are implemented for low power consumption.
• During IP-telephone operation, the enhanced radio telephone communicates with a PC or an internal network converter to convert between coded speech signals and network-formatted data.
• The PC or internal network converter runs a streamlined software telephony application that performs UDP/IP conversion and communicates with the enhanced radio telephone via a serial, parallel, IR, or short-range radio connection.
• The enhanced radio telephone provides a convenient and comfortable handset for the user and reduces echo problems associated with conventional IP telephones.
• The invention provides an improved IP telephone that is more convenient, economical, and efficient than conventional IP telephones.

* The present invention relates to devices for producing electrical power, pressurized water, or other useful work from surface waves on a water body.
* The device comprises one or more gas tight containers submerged to a depth slightly below anticipated wave and swell troughs.
* The container(s) have a fixed depth rigid end or surface held at relatively fixed depth relative to the water body mean water level or wave troughs.
* A second movable rigid end or surface opposes the fixed end and is separated and connected by and sealed to a flexible, gas tight, reinforced, elastomer or flexible metal bellows, or a diaphragm or accordion pleated skirt.
* Overhead waves and troughs produce hydrostatic pressure variations which compress and expand the containers, respectively, bringing the movable end closer to and further from the fixed depth end.
* Container expansion and contraction is enhanced by either partial evacuation of the container or venting of the container's gas to a floating surface atmospheric vent or to a floating surface expandable bellows or bladder, or reservoir.
* The relative linear motion between the containers' fixed and movable ends is connected to and transferred to a hydraulic or pneumatic pumping means or, mechanical or electrical drive means.
* The pressurized fluid flow from the hydraulic or pneumatic pumping can drive a motor or turbine with electric generator.
* Mechanical means can direct drive a generator via rack and pinion gearing, oscillating helical drive or other oscillating linear one or two way rotational motion means.
* Electrical drive means can be by a linear generator.

<summary>
* The invention provides a blade for a scraped surface heat exchanger that facilitates mounting onto a drive shaft using a pin type connection.
* The blade has a first side and a second side, with a scraper edge and a hinge edge.
* At least one mounting hole extends through the blade body near the hinge edge.
* A first L-shaped locking track is on the first side of the blade, with a first entry track and a first intermediate track.
* A second L-shaped locking track is on the second side of the blade, with a second entry track and a second intermediate track.
* The blade is mounted by inserting it at an installation angle, then pivoting it to a shallower angle.
* The blade is restrained from lateral movement by the inner finger of the pin protruding through the mounting hole.
* The blade is held at the installation angle during insertion of the drive shaft into the outer tube.
</summary>

<summary>
* The invention relates to a process and an apparatus for detecting and eliminating defective and/or incorrectly positioned cigarettes in a cigarette magazine of a cigarette-production and/or cigarette-packaging machine.
* The detection process involves using at least one optical checking element, such as a camera, to detect at least one image of a plurality of cigarettes located in the cigarette magazine.
* The image is evaluated by an image-processing device, and if the scanned image deviates from a reference image and/or from at least one reference value, an error signal is produced.
* The elimination process involves detecting a defective and/or incorrectly positioned cigarette and, in reaction to such detection, actuating an ejecting unit arranged in the region of the magazine to eject a plurality of cigarettes located in an ejecting zone assigned to the ejecting unit.
* The elimination apparatus comprises at least one ejecting unit arranged in the region of the magazine for ejecting a plurality of cigarettes located in an ejecting zone assigned to the ejecting unit.
* The ejecting unit has a front wall and a rear wall, with the contour of the rear wall being greater than the contour of the front wall by at least the width of one cigarette to avoid jamming of cigarettes only partially gripped by the front wall.
</summary>

* The invention provides a simplified connection system for high voltage power cables with ratings up to 400 KV and above.
* The system uses a common cable connection interface for all accessories and interconnections, resulting in advantages such as factory pretesting, reduced installation time and cost, and simplified field testing.
* The interface components do not include any gas or oil, eliminating the risk of leaks or explosions.

* The fixing mechanism for a tool comprises a tool, a tool frame, and a tool holder in the frame of a machine tool.
* At least one of the connecting surfaces in the tool frame and the tool holder is shaped as a curved surface.
* The first contact surface in the tool frame and the second contact surface in the tool holder are placed against each other in the operational position of the fixing mechanism to transmit machining force between the tool frame and the tool holder.
* The fixing mechanism can be applied in a wide range of technology, including machining by chipping, such as milling, reaming, drilling, turning, etc. of wood, plastics, metal, etc. as the material for machining.

• The invention provides methods and apparatus for generating supply voltages for display driver circuits with high efficiency and low radiated energy (low noise).
• The invention uses switching regulator circuits that have been modified to create multiple circuit paths carrying current in opposite directions to cancel out radiated noise.
• Additional terminal lines are provided to sink any electromagnetic interference (EMI) generated in the outermost paths.
• The invention allows for the production of large amounts of current, suitable for driving large displays like the Apple iPhone, without the typical penalties associated with EMI or noise.
• In conventional implementations, the high resistance of indium tin oxide (ITO) used in display applications can result in a voltage drop of about 500 millivolts.
• The invention configures parallel source and drain paths in an alternating relationship to cancel out EMI generated in the source paths by the EMI generated in the drain paths.
• The invention uses terminal leads at the periphery edges of the circuit to act as RF antennas and pick up any leaking fields generated by the last fully-connected paths in the circuit.

• The document describes a power system with a battery having multiple cells, where the cells are charged such that their voltages are approximately equal at the end of a determined period.
• The charging rate may differ among some cells for at least a portion of the period to achieve this equalization.
• The system aims to reduce the time spent rebalancing and charging vehicle batteries.

• The invention is an AC-to-DC converter for lamp power supply that provides constant brightness with no low or high frequency flicker, reducing eye fatigue and protecting health.
• The converter includes input protection, EMI filter, rectifier, filter, converter, output filter, lamp, start circuit, control circuit, biasing circuit, sampling circuit, output protection circuit, feedback and dimming circuit, and input monitor circuit.
• The converter uses a control circuit to regulate the output voltage at a constant value, and a feedback and dimming circuit to adjust the output voltage and dim the lamp by changing a potentiometer resistor value.

• The system controls electric lights and window treatments to maintain a desired illumination profile in a space.
• The system also controls window treatments to minimize or eliminate sun glare through openings into the space.
• The system employs a closed loop control algorithm with a dead-band for controlling window treatments to minimize or eliminate sun glare.

* <summary>
* The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has made significant progress in enhancing aviation security since September 11, 2001, but it has not been determined how much more secure the nation's aviation system is.
* TSA has implemented congressional mandates and explored options for increasing the use of technology and information to control access to secure areas of airports and to improve passenger screening.
* TSA has also taken steps to address vulnerabilities in air cargo, general aviation, and airport perimeter security.
* TSA faces several longer-term challenges, including the need to develop a risk management approach, ensure adequate funding, coordinate with other agencies and stakeholders, and build a results-oriented culture within the Department of Homeland Security.
* </summary>

• LDA covers lobbying of federal officials, including executive branch officials for nonlegislative matters, while IRC definitions do not cover executive branch officials for nonlegislative matters.
• LDA covers legislative matters and an extensive list of nonlegislative matters, while IRC section 4911 only covers legislative matters and IRC section 162(e) covers legislative and nonlegislative subjects but has a narrower definition of nonlegislative subjects.
• LDA includes 19 exceptions to its lobbying definition, while IRC sections 4911 and 162(e) have 5 and 7 exceptions, respectively, with two of the IRC section 4911 exceptions potentially allowing a significant amount of lobbying expenses to be excluded from coverage.

• GAO has been assessing strategic sourcing in federal acquisitions for over a decade.
• Strategic sourcing can lead to significant savings and improved performance.
• OMB issued a memorandum in 2005 implementing strategic sourcing practices.
• FSSI program was established in 2005 to address government-wide opportunities.
• In 2012, most agencies leveraged only a fraction of their buying power through strategic sourcing.
• Agencies face challenges in obtaining and analyzing reliable spending data.
• Expertise, leadership commitment, and metrics are also key challenges in strategic sourcing.
• Disincentives such as budget cuts and lack of centralized information can hinder strategic sourcing.
• Services procurement is particularly relevant given current fiscal environment.
• Leading companies have achieved savings of 4 to 15 percent through strategically sourcing services.

• The current surface transportation programs in the U.S. are not effectively addressing key transportation challenges such as increasing congestion and growing freight demand.
• A fundamental reexamination of the federal approach to surface transportation is needed to create more focused, performance-based, and sustainable programs.

• The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) funds its activities through a combination of Airport and Airway Trust Fund (Trust Fund) revenues and General Fund revenues.
• The Trust Fund is credited with revenues collected from system users through dedicated excise taxes, including a 7.5% ticket tax on domestic airline tickets, a $3.30 domestic passenger segment tax, a 6.25% tax on the price paid for transportation of domestic cargo or fuel taxes on domestic commercial aviation fuel and domestic general aviation (GA) gasoline and jet fuel.
• The General Fund contribution has varied greatly, ranging from 0% to 59% of FAA’s budget.
• The National Civil Aviation Review Commission (Commission) issued a report in 1997 analyzing alternative funding means to meet the needs of the nation’s aviation system.
• The Commission recommended that FAA’s revenues be more closely linked to the costs of services provided to support ATC activities, including capital investments.
• Some stakeholders support the current excise tax system, while others support a change to direct user charges.
• The degree to which alternative funding options could address concerns about the current excise system ultimately depends on the extent to which the contributions required from users actually reflect the costs they impose on the system.
• The six funding options considered include two that would modify the current excise tax structure and four that would adopt more direct charges to users.

* DOD has identified 5,842 servicemembers and an estimated 350 civilians potentially exposed during Project 112 tests.
* DOD has not exhausted all possible sources of information and has not conducted a cost-benefit analysis to determine the feasibility of addressing unresolved issues.
* DOD's current effort to identify individuals potentially exposed outside of Project 112 has several shortcomings, including lack of clear objectives, scope, and information needs; inadequate oversight; limited use of other entities' work; and lack of transparency.
* DOD and VA have had limited success in notifying potentially exposed individuals due to inconsistent information transmission, lack of use of all available resources, and no actions taken to notify civilians.

<summary>
* Mexican drug trafficking organizations (DTOs) rely on firearms from the U.S. to assert control over territory, eliminate rivals, and enforce business dealings.
* Most firearms seized in Mexico and traced back to the U.S. come from Texas, California, and Arizona.
* Firearms parts, such as unfinished receivers and components, are increasingly being used to assemble firearms in Mexico, making them difficult to trace.
* ATF and ICE have taken steps to improve coordination on efforts to combat firearms trafficking, but challenges remain in information sharing and agency roles.
* The indicator used in the Strategy to track progress by U.S. agencies in stemming firearms trafficking to Mexico is not adequate.
* Mexican and U.S. officials have expressed concerns about corruption and frequent turnover in Mexican law enforcement, which can hinder collaboration.
</summary>

• NCHIP is a federal grant program managed by BJS to build a national infrastructure for criminal history records.
• States use NCHIP funds for various purposes, with a majority used for NICS-related activities.
• States have made progress in automating criminal history records and making them accessible nationally.
• Factors relevant for policymakers in debating the future of NCHIP include the extent of cumulative progress, demand for background checks, and technology upgrades.
• None of the 50 states have used NCHIP funds to develop or implement a ballistics registration system.

<summary>
* EPA's Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) program, also known as Superfund, includes incineration as a cleanup remedy for hazardous waste sites.
* EPA has used incineration at 43 Superfund sites, with 3 incinerators currently in operation and 4 additional sites planned for incineration.
* Incinerators used at Superfund sites are generally transportable and exempt from obtaining a permit, but EPA applies relevant environmental standards from other federal laws, such as RCRA.
* EPA employs several methods to ensure the safe operation of Superfund incinerators, including setting site-specific standards, incorporating safety features, monitoring emissions, and providing on-site oversight.
* EPA has not fully implemented two additional methods to promote safe operation: requiring inspections by RCRA hazardous waste incinerator inspectors and systematically sharing lessons learned from site to site.
* GAO recommends that EPA implement its guidance for having RCRA inspectors evaluate Superfund incinerators and document and share lessons learned from each site.
* EPA generally agreed with GAO's findings and recommendations but questioned the benefits of preparing voluminous site-specific studies on lessons learned.
* EPA provided technical and editorial comments, which GAO incorporated into the report as appropriate.
* The report was issued on January 29, 1997, and was sent to the Administrator of EPA, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, and other interested parties.
</summary>

• The SEC's financial statements were fairly stated in all material respects for fiscal years 2007 and 2006, but the agency had one material weakness and three significant control deficiencies in internal control.
• The material weakness was in the financial reporting process, including period-end financial reporting, disgorgements and penalties accounts receivable, accounting for transaction fee revenue, and preparing financial statement disclosures.

• The Postal Service's cluster-level workforce in 1997 did not match the 1990 CLF in terms of representation of women and minorities.
• Black and Asian men and women were fully represented, while white and Hispanic women and Native American men were underrepresented.
• Women and minorities were generally promoted to EAS 17 and above positions in percentages higher than or close to their workforce representation.
• As of September 1997, women and minorities were present in all EAS 17 and above positions and had been promoted to these positions during 1997.
• However, women and minority representation was generally lower in EAS 17 and above positions than in EAS 11 through 16 positions.

• **Definition of MWD**: MWDs are dogs bred, procured, or acquired by DOD for tasks like explosive and narcotic detection, patrol, tracking, and other requirements.
• **Robby’s Law**: This law promotes the adoption of MWDs after their military service. It gives priority to former handlers, then others capable of humane care, and finally law enforcement agencies.
• **Disposition Process**: MWDs are removed from service through a process involving a review board, which considers medical and behavioral factors. Handlers can adopt MWDs, with the most recent handler typically getting priority.
• **Tracking Systems**: DOD uses three systems (WDMS, Central Repository, and ROVR) to track MWD information, including their removal from service.
• **Medical Conditions**: Prevalent medical conditions in adopted MWDs include skin, dental, and musculoskeletal issues. Some conditions may require removal from service, while others can be treated.
• **Veterinary Care**: Adopted MWDs need preventative care, with costs varying based on factors like location and treatment options. Assistance is available through nonprofit organizations and DOD medical services at military installations.

<summary>
* The Comanche helicopter program was established to replace the Army's light helicopter fleet with a low-cost, advanced technology aircraft for armed reconnaissance and attack missions.
* The program has experienced significant cost increases and reductions in planned acquisition quantities due to funding reductions and restructuring.
* The Army's restructuring of the Comanche program continues risks associated with making production decisions before knowing whether the aircraft will perform as required and the risk of higher program costs.
* The Comanche's software development and integration is a significant program objective, but there are ongoing issues with the Ada compilation system, software development delays, and configuration management.
* Maintainability requirements for the Comanche are at risk due to potential failures to meet direct maintenance man-hours per flight hour (MMH/FH), mean time to repair (MTTR), and fault isolation goals.
* The Army's maintenance concept for the Comanche program is predicated on two levels of maintenance—unit- and depot-level maintenance—to achieve operating and support savings.
* GAO recommends that the Secretary of Defense require the Army to complete operational testing to validate the Comanche's operational effectiveness and suitability before committing any funds to acquire long-lead production items or enter low-rate initial production.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Food Stamp Program provides eligible low-income households with benefits to purchase food, with eligibility and benefit levels determined by household income and assets.
* FNS offers options and waivers to states to increase program access, reduce reporting burden, and minimize payment errors, such as extending benefits to households leaving TANF and allowing states to merge TANF and Food Stamp Program rules.
* States use various reporting options and waivers to change how households with earnings report changes in their circumstances, with the most common being waivers that eliminate the requirement to report changes in earned income of $25 or more per month.
</summary>

* HUD's fiscal year 2000 budget request includes 19 new initiatives and programs, with 7 set-asides totaling $210 million.
* The budget proposes a 9% increase in budget authority over fiscal year 1999, with significant funding increases in several ongoing programs, including Section 8 contract renewals.
* GAO is concerned about HUD's capacity to manage the proposed increase while undergoing organizational reform and implementing new initiatives.
* GAO has questions about the accuracy of HUD's budget proposals for the Section 8 program and the basis for the substantial increase in total Section 8 outlays.

* DOD is planning to replace the Landstuhl Regional Medical Center (LRMC) and the 86th Medical Group (MDG) clinic in Germany with a new medical center.
* The new medical center will be the only tertiary-level referral hospital for EUCOM, CENTCOM, and AFRICOM theaters of operation.
* DOD's guidance for planning and acquisition of military health facilities was used to determine the facility requirements.
* The replacement medical center is being designed to be able to expand capacity during surges to support contingency operations.
* DOD used beneficiary population data as of March 2010 and data on historical patterns of patient migration to identify the areas served by the proposed replacement medical center.
* The replacement medical center is being sized for peacetime operations, but can expand to meet the needs of contingency operations.
* DOD has been reducing its military posture in Europe since German reunification, which may impact the size of the replacement medical center.
* DOD's cost estimate for the replacement medical center was developed using best practices, but was minimally documented.
* The cost estimate does not include recurring life cycle costs, costs for supporting infrastructure, or operation and maintenance costs for personnel or equipment.
* DOD agreed with GAO's conclusions and recommendations, but did not provide the reassessment for review.

• ICE officers and attorneys exercise discretion throughout the alien apprehension and removal process.
• Discretion is exercised in six phases: initial encounter, apprehension, charging, detention, removal proceedings, and final removal.
• ICE officers have more discretion in the initial phases of the apprehension and removal process.
• ICE attorneys have less discretion in the later phases of the apprehension and removal process.
• ICE has not completed efforts to provide officers with complete and up to date guidance to reflect expanded worksite and fugitive operations.
• ICE does not have a mechanism to ensure that officers receive consistent information regarding legal developments.
• ICE does not have a mechanism to analyze information specific to the exercise of discretion.
• ICE has recently begun undertaking reviews and revisions of training that are consistent with internal controls.

• Ground ambulance services vary in organizational structure, staffing, transport types, and revenue sources.
• Medicare payments for ambulance services consist of a service-level payment and a mileage payment.
• Providers may be affiliated with institutions, independent, for-profit, nonprofit, or government-based.
• Providers may rely on volunteers, paid staff, or a mix of both, and may offer BLS or ALS services.
• Revenue sources for providers may include community tax support, charitable donations, grants, subscription programs, and payments from Medicare or Medicaid.
• The mix and amount of revenues available may vary, affecting the level of service provided.
• Medicare payments have increased since 2002, but some providers may have lower margins due to recent changes in payment policies and increased fuel costs.

• DOD has 226,000 SRC I missiles and rockets in the continental US.
• Army, Navy, Marine Corps, and Air Force collectively have accountability for these items.
• DODM 5100.76 requires continuous program and policy oversight for AA&E, including SRC I ammunition.
• DOD policy requires SRC I ammunition to have a higher level of protection and security.
• DOD and military services have policy and guidance on accounting, safeguarding, and shipping SRC I ammunition.
• In 2014, DOD had challenges implementing HAZMAT regulations, affecting the transportation of HAZMAT.
• In 2014, military services' automated information systems had limitations affecting efficient management of conventional ammunition.
• In 2000, an Army ammunition depot had internal controls weaknesses leading to loss of accountability and control over SRC I rockets.
• In 1997, military services had different procedures and requirements for maintaining oversight of SRC I rockets.
• In 1994, services had discrepancies in SRC I missiles inventories and lacked systems to track missiles by serial number.

• The Social Security Administration (SSA) collects and maintains personal information, including names, dates of birth, addresses, and Social Security Numbers (SSNs), to administer its programs and ensure individuals receive the benefits they are entitled to.
• SSA has a long history of protecting individuals' privacy and maintaining the confidentiality of their personal information.
• SSA's disclosure policy is designed to balance the need to protect individuals' privacy with the need to assist law enforcement in their investigations.
• SSA's policy is more restrictive than the Privacy Act and the disclosure policies of most federal agencies, but similar to those of the IRS and Census Bureau.
• SSA's policy allows for disclosure of personal information to law enforcement under certain conditions, such as when the individual has been indicted or convicted of a crime, or when the information is necessary to investigate or prosecute fraud or other criminal activity in SSA's programs.
• SSA's policy requires that law enforcement requests be in writing, signed by an official of the requesting office, and specify the information being requested and the law enforcement activity involved.
• SSA's policy is implemented through regulations, guidance, and procedures, including the Program Operations Manual System (POMS) and Emergency Messages.
• SSA's Office of the Inspector General (OIG) is authorized to handle law enforcement requests and maintain records of disclosures made.
• SSA's policy is designed to ensure consistent application across all levels of the agency, including field offices, regional offices, and headquarters offices.

<summary>
* RCRA's requirements for managing hazardous waste can hinder cleanups, particularly of remediation waste.
* EPA has identified three key requirements that create disincentives for cleanup: land disposal restrictions, minimum technological requirements, and permit requirements.
* Land disposal restrictions require waste to be treated to stringent standards before it can be disposed of on land.
* Minimum technological requirements set design and operating specifications for facilities that treat or dispose of hazardous waste.
* Permit requirements prohibit the treatment, storage, or disposal of hazardous waste without a permit.
* EPA has developed policy and regulatory alternatives to mitigate the impact of these requirements on cleanups.
* The contained-in policy allows contaminated media to be excluded from RCRA's regulation if they no longer pose a hazard.
* The Superfund waiver exempts on-site cleanups from the requirement to obtain a RCRA permit.
* The source of contamination presumption allows cleanup managers to presume that waste is not a listed hazardous waste if no records exist to document its source.
* The area of contamination policy allows waste to be consolidated and treated or left in place and capped without triggering land disposal restrictions.
* The corrective action management unit (CAMU) rule allows waste to be managed within a strictly defined area on-site without meeting RCRA's land disposal restrictions or minimum technological requirements.
* EPA proposed a comprehensive rule in 1996 to reform RCRA's requirements for managing remediation waste, but plans to withdraw it due to stakeholder disagreements and legal uncertainties.
* EPA is pursuing final rulemaking on four narrower portions of the proposal by June 1998.
* EPA believes that comprehensive reform of remediation waste management can best be achieved through legislative revision of RCRA.
* GAO recommends that EPA take steps to ensure that regulators overseeing cleanups have a more consistent understanding of how to apply EPA's existing policy and regulatory alternatives to RCRA's requirements for managing remediation waste.
</summary>

• Medicare program integrity activities were subsumed under general administrative budget and performed by insurance companies under contract with CMS before 1996.
• HIPAA established MIP in 1997, providing CMS with dedicated funding for program integrity activities.
• MIP funds are allocated to five activities: audit, medical review, secondary payer, benefit integrity, and provider education.
• CMS plans to use additional MIP funds provided by DRA for fiscal year 2006 to support Part D program integrity efforts.

* TSA has enhanced screener training by developing a dual-function screener training course, allowing local staff to deliver basic training, and providing recurrent training through the Online Learning Center and hands-on training tools.
* TSA has implemented leadership and technical training programs for Screening Supervisors and has provided FSDs with the capability to query and analyze TIP data in a number of ways, including by screener, checkpoint, and airport.
* TSA has increased the amount of covert testing it performs and has enabled FSDs to conduct local covert testing at passenger screening checkpoints.
* TSA has completed its first round of the screener recertification program and plans to implement TIP for checked baggage screening and develop an image recognition component for the checked baggage screeners recertification testing.

* <summary>
* IRS has not established a long-term, desired level-of-telephone-service goal based on taxpayers' needs and costs/benefits, and instead annually determines funding and expected service level.
* IRS faces challenges in recruiting, training, retaining, and scheduling customer service representatives due to job characteristics, inadequate resources, lack of competency gap assessment, and inaccurate demand forecasting.
* IRS is working to improve its human capital management practices, including setting long-term service goals, assessing competency gaps, monitoring attrition, and evaluating practices' effects on service goals and interrelationships.
* </summary>

* Ginnie Mae's market share of new MBS issuance has declined from 42% in 1985 to 7% in 2004, while its share of outstanding MBS has declined from 54% in 1985 to 10% in 2004.
* Ginnie Mae's volume of new MBS issuance has remained relatively constant, ranging from $150 billion to $200 billion annually from 1998 to 2004, while its outstanding volume has declined from $612 billion in 2000 to $453 billion in 2004.
* Ginnie Mae's share of the government-backed mortgage market has remained relatively constant, with 90% or more of FHA and VA loans being securitized through Ginnie Mae.
* Ginnie Mae faces challenges in maintaining its market share and volume, including changes in the marketplace, improving loan data disclosure, managing its commitment authority, and ensuring the accuracy of its data systems and internal controls.

<summary>
* DOD has reversed $592 million of illegal or improper closed account adjustments from fiscal year 2000, but reversing these adjustments has revealed additional accounting errors that must be corrected.
* DOD has agreed to reverse and correct $172 million of illegal or improper closed account adjustments from fiscal year 2001.
* DOD has implemented controls to prevent illegal closed account adjustments, resulting in an 80% reduction in such adjustments during the first 6 months of fiscal year 2002.
* However, GAO found $253,212 of illegal closed account adjustments processed during this period that were not prevented by the controls.
* DOD's long-standing accounting accuracy problems and weak control environment contribute to the need for closed account adjustments.
* GAO recommends that DOD continue to monitor and correct closed account adjustments and that the Congress consider options to eliminate or reduce such adjustments.
</summary>

• **Transition of Domain Name System Management**: The U.S. government began efforts to privatize the management of the domain name system in 1998, aiming to transition it to a private, nonprofit corporation called ICANN.
• **ICANN's Progress and Challenges**: ICANN has made progress in promoting competition, such as increasing the number of registrars and introducing new top-level domains. However, it has faced delays in enhancing the stability and security of the domain name system, formalizing relationships with key entities, and establishing a representative and effective governance structure.
• **ICANN's Reform Initiative**: In 2002, ICANN's president proposed fundamental reforms to address issues with the corporation's structure and operations, leading to the creation of a committee to consider and recommend changes. The U.S. Department of Commerce, responsible for overseeing the transition, has been monitoring ICANN's progress and is gathering input from various stakeholders to assess the reform effort.

* <summary>
	+ The Department of the Interior (Interior) has provided a retention allowance to one Senior Executive Service (SES) manager at the Office of the Special Trustee for American Indians (OST)—the Principal Deputy Special Trustee.
	+ From fiscal years 2001 to 2005, the average performance award amounts that SES managers received at OST were generally lower than the average amounts provided to other bureaus and offices within Interior and other federal agencies.
	+ The Principal Deputy Special Trustee received three major awards from fiscal years 2000 to 2006, including two time-off awards and a performance award.
	+ Seven of OST’s SES managers received at least two major awards in 2 years or more.
	+ The average performance award amount of OST’s SES performance awards was higher than the average amounts of other bureaus and offices within Interior and other federal agencies in fiscal year 2001.
	+ The average amounts of OST’s performance awards for fiscal years 2002 through 2005 were generally lower than the average amounts provided to other bureaus and offices within Interior and other federal agencies.
	+ Interior’s Executive Resources Board (ERB) made the final determination on all performance awards and retention allowances provided to SES managers.
* </summary>

<summary>
* VA and DOD began a joint effort in 1998 to share patient health information for active duty military personnel and veterans.
* The initial project, GCPR, aimed to create an electronic interface for accessing patient data from either agency's health information systems.
* In 2001, GAO recommended designating a lead entity and creating comprehensive plans for the project.
* VA and DOD revised their strategy in 2002, naming VA as the lead entity and establishing the Federal Health Information Exchange (FHIE) program.
* FHIE was fully operational by 2004, allowing VA providers to access data on separated service members.
* VA and DOD are working on two demonstration projects—Bidirectional Health Information Exchange and Laboratory Data Sharing Interface—to exchange information between existing systems.
* The departments continue to work on the long-term goal of achieving a virtual medical record through the CHDR initiative, which faces several challenges.
</summary>

* IRS has nine audit standards to ensure quality audits, including one for workpapers.
* Workpapers should support the auditor's conclusions, be clear and organized, and protect taxpayer privacy.
* IRS found problems with workpapers, such as disagreements between workpapers and reports, missing documents, and incomplete or illegible workpapers.
* EQMS evaluations showed that auditors met all key elements of the workpaper standard in no more than 72% of audits from 1992 to 1997.
* IRS' primary quality control is supervisory review of workpapers, but documentation of such reviews was limited.
* IRS is drafting changes to the IRM to require documentation of managerial involvement in audits.

* State's ATA program aims to enhance friendly countries' antiterrorism skills, strengthen bilateral ties, and increase respect for human rights.
* The program provides training and equipment, but lacks clear guidance from S/CT, leading to uncertainty about how assistance aligns with broader U.S. counterterrorism policy goals.
* State has not complied with a congressional mandate to report on U.S. international counterterrorism assistance since 1996, and ATA annual reports contain inaccurate data and lack systematic assessments of program performance.

• The U.S. bankruptcy system involves multiple federal entities, including bankruptcy courts, the Judicial Conference of the United States, AOUSC, the Federal Judicial Center, the U.S. Trustee Program, and the Bankruptcy Administrator Program.
• Bankruptcy courts adjudicate most lawsuits, foreclosures, and other collection activities against debtors, preserving assets and preventing creditors from taking company assets before a case is resolved.
• Equitable treatment of creditors means all creditors with substantially similar claims are classified similarly and receive the same treatment.
• Business debtors may seek liquidation (Chapter 7) or reorganization (Chapter 11) under the Code.
• Proceedings under Chapters 7 and 11 can be voluntary or involuntary.
• A firm going through Chapter 11 bankruptcy generally passes through several stages, including first-day motions, disclosure, plan of reorganization, and reorganization.
• The U.S. bankruptcy system involves multiple federal entities, including bankruptcy courts, the Judicial Conference of the United States, AOUSC, the Federal Judicial Center, the U.S. Trustee Program, and the Bankruptcy Administrator Program.
• Bankruptcy courts adjudicate most lawsuits, foreclosures, and other collection activities against debtors, preserving assets and preventing creditors from taking company assets before a case is resolved.
• Equitable treatment of creditors means all creditors with substantially similar claims are classified similarly and receive the same treatment.
• Business debtors may seek liquidation (Chapter 7) or reorganization (Chapter 11) under the Code.
• Proceedings under Chapters 7 and 11 can be voluntary or involuntary.
• A firm going through Chapter 11 bankruptcy generally passes through several stages, including first-day motions, disclosure, plan of reorganization, and reorganization.
• Certain financial institutions may not file as debtors under the Code and other entities face special restrictions in using the Code.
• Insured depository institutions, insurance companies, broker-dealers, and commodity brokers generally cannot file for bankruptcy under the Code.
• Broker-dealers can be liquidated under the Securities Investor Protection Act (SIPA) or a special provision of Chapter 7 of the Code.
• Commodity brokers can be liquidated under a different special provision of Chapter 7.
• Regulators often play a role in financial company bankruptcies, with the Code not explicitly naming federal financial regulators as a party of interest with a right to be heard before the court.
• FD

<summary>
* The electricity industry consists of generation, transmission, distribution, and system operations.
* Utilities own and operate electricity assets, while system operators manage and control the grid.
