* The smart grid vision aims to increase reliability, facilitate renewable energy, and provide real-time energy cost information.
* Federal and state authorities oversee the electricity industry, with FERC regulating wholesale electricity sales and transmission, and state regulators overseeing local distribution and retail sales.
* NERC is responsible for ensuring the reliability of the bulk power system, including critical infrastructure protection standards.
* NIST and FERC were required by the Energy Independence and Security Act of 2007 to support smart grid modernization and cybersecurity.
* Cyber threats to the electricity industry can be unintentional or intentional, with advanced persistent threats posing significant risks.
* Known cyber vulnerabilities in smart grid and related systems include increased entry points, new vulnerabilities, wider access, and increased customer information.
* Multiple entities, including NERC, NIST, FERC, and the Departments of Homeland Security and Energy, have taken steps to secure the electricity grid.
* Key challenges in securing the electricity grid include monitoring implementation of cybersecurity standards, clarifying regulatory responsibilities, taking a comprehensive approach to cybersecurity, ensuring built-in security features, effectively sharing cybersecurity information, and establishing metrics for evaluating cybersecurity.
</summary>

• Federal workforce has mission-critical skills gaps that pose high risk to the nation.
• Over 34% of federal employees will be eligible to retire by 2020, which could exacerbate skills gaps.
• Current budget and long-term fiscal pressures, changing nature of federal work, and potential retirements threaten to worsen skills gaps.
• OPM data shows high retirement eligibility rates in some agencies, such as HUD.
• Various factors can affect when individuals actually retire, and some amount of retirement and other forms of attrition can be beneficial.
• Numerous tools are available to help agencies address their talent needs, but problems exist across a range of personnel systems and functions.
• Congress has provided agencies with exemptions from the current pay system to give them more flexibility in setting pay.
• A long-standing federal human capital management question is how to update the entire federal compensation system to be more market based and performance oriented.
• Lessons learned from organizations that have implemented market-based and performance-oriented pay systems provide useful insights for the federal government.
• Agencies should make effective use of the tools and flexibilities provided by Congress to build and maintain a high-performing workforce.

• DOD received funding for GWOT through supplemental appropriations and annual appropriations.
• Supplemental appropriations were provided for military personnel and operation and maintenance expenses.
• DOD transferred funds from the Iraqi Freedom Fund to support GWOT activities.
• DOD transferred and reprogrammed funds among appropriation accounts to cover gaps between supplemental appropriations and reported obligations.
• DOD increased its annual appropriation request by more than $10 billion annually to support GWOT, with the military services receiving about $7.9 billion in fiscal year 2004 and about $7.6 billion in fiscal year 2005.
• The military services absorbed the increase into their annual appropriations and allocated it based on their judgment of where the funds were most needed.
• DOD did not explicitly take into account the funds provided through its annual appropriation that it intended for support of GWOT.
• In fiscal year 2004, the military services reported obligations in support of GWOT that were above the supplemental funds appropriated by the Congress.
• DOD used authorities granted to it, including transferring funds and reducing or deferring planned spending for peacetime operations, to cover the gaps.

• The Department of the Treasury (Treasury) extended the Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) to address perceived weaknesses in the economy and respond to unanticipated shocks.
• Treasury coordinated with the Federal Reserve and FDIC to make decisions related to the extension of TARP, and plans to continue doing so for upcoming decisions.

<summary>
* The food supply is vulnerable to deliberate contamination, and federal agencies have taken steps to address this risk.
* FDA and USDA have issued voluntary security guidelines for food processors, but they lack comprehensive information on implementation due to concerns about public disclosure.
* The food industry is taking steps to enhance security, but there is no requirement for them to do so.
* The Congress has directed water systems to assess their vulnerability to terrorist attacks and develop emergency response plans, which could serve as a model for the food industry.
* FDA and USDA lack the authority to mandate security measures and are concerned about the public disclosure of sensitive security information.
</summary>

<summary>
* The largest interagency contracting vehicle is the MAS program, managed by GSA.
* Agencies use interagency and enterprisewide contracts to leverage buying power, but lack reliable data to manage and oversee them.
* OMB and agencies lack comprehensive data on MACs and enterprisewide contracts.
* Concerns exist about contract duplication and missed opportunities to leverage buying power.
* Limited governmentwide policy exists for establishing and overseeing MACs and enterprisewide contracts.
* GSA faces challenges in managing the MAS program due to lack of transactional data, limited use of pricing tools, and decentralized management structure.
* GSA lacks data on MAS orders and prices paid, hindering strategic management and best price achievement.
* GSA uses pricing tools but applies them to a small number of contracts, limiting their effectiveness.
* Decentralized management and inconsistent performance measures create MAS program management challenges.
</summary>

* <summary>
	+ 18F and USDS have provided useful services to federal agencies, with most surveyed project managers satisfied with their work.
	+ Both organizations have developed outcome-oriented goals and procedures for prioritizing projects, but not all goals are outcome-oriented and performance has not been fully measured.
	+ 18F has delayed its projected date for full cost recovery and has not established associated performance measures.
	+ USDS has not developed a quarterly report on the 10 high priority programs, and its policy does not clearly define the relationship between CIOs and digital service teams.
* </summary>

* The baby boom generation is aging, and this will lead to a significant change in the ratio of the working-age population to the population age 65 and older.
* The aged dependency ratio is expected to rise from 21 percent in 2000 to 35 percent by 2030.
* Older workers are employed in a diverse group of occupations but are a growing proportion of white-collar occupations.
* Between 2000 and 2008, the number and percentage of workers over age 55 will increase in all major occupational categories.
* The aging of the labor force presents opportunities and challenges for employers, and government agencies should work together to identify sound policies to extend the worklife of older Americans.

• The Visa Waiver Program (VWP) allows citizens of certain countries to travel to the U.S. without a visa for stays of up to 90 days.
• The Electronic System for Travel Authorization (ESTA) was implemented in 2008 to enhance security and facilitate travel for VWP participants.
• ESTA requires VWP travelers to obtain approval before boarding a U.S.-bound carrier, reducing the burden on travelers in other ways.
• ESTA has reduced the burden on travelers by eliminating the I-94W form and providing earlier notice of ineligibility.
• ESTA has also simplified travel for many business travelers by eliminating the need to complete the I-94W form multiple times a year.
• ESTA has not fully analyzed the risks associated with noncompliance, such as passengers boarding without verified ESTA approval.
• DHS has not completed half of the mandated biennial reviews of VWP countries in a timely manner, which could impact their continued participation in the program.
• Information-sharing agreements between the U.S. and VWP countries are not yet fully implemented, which could also impact program security.
• DHS has taken steps to address these issues, such as establishing time frames for reviewing noncompliant passengers and working to complete biennial reviews on time.

• State child welfare systems face growing caseloads, with foster care population increasing from 276,000 in 1984 to 494,000 in 1995.
• Federal law requires states to make reasonable efforts to prevent or eliminate the need for removing children from their homes and to provide services for reunification or permanent placement.
• States must develop a case plan for each child, reviewed every 6 months, with a permanency hearing within 18 months.
• 26 states have enacted laws or policies to shorten the time between entering foster care and the first permanency hearing, with most requiring it within 12 months.
• Some states have implemented operational and procedural changes to expedite the permanency process, such as concurrent planning and revising court procedures.
• Arizona's Housing Assistance Program and Severance Project, and Kentucky's termination of parental rights project, are examples of successful initiatives.
• States increased their chances of successful initiatives by involving key stakeholders, obtaining buy-in, and providing resources.
• Lack of evaluation data hinders understanding of the overall impact of these initiatives, and may lead to unintended consequences.

• The DATA Act requires federal agencies to report spending data to improve transparency and accountability.
• Agencies have identified challenges in reporting complete and accurate data, including missing or incorrect ZIP+4 information and issues with intragovernmental transactions.
• OMB and Treasury have issued guidance to help agencies report data, but additional guidance is needed to address potential clarity, consistency, or data quality issues.
• OMB and Treasury have established a Data Standards Committee to maintain and update data standards, but more work is needed to establish a fully functioning data governance structure.
• The DATA Act requires agencies to link financial and award data using a unique award identifier, but some agencies may not be able to record this identifier in their financial systems.
• OMB and Treasury have established a process for agencies to certify the accuracy of their data submissions, but questions remain about the effectiveness of this process.
• OMB and Treasury have not established a process for determining which agencies are required to report spending data under the DATA Act, and additional clarification is needed to improve the usefulness of the guidance provided.
• OMB has not established procedures for ensuring non-exempt agencies are reporting spending data as required, and has not stated whether it will make the results of the determinations publicly available.
• OMB does not have plans to reassess, on a periodic basis, which agencies are required to report spending data under the DATA Act, and additional clarification is needed to improve the usefulness of the guidance provided.

<summary>
* OSC uses ARC for contracting support, including the MPRI task order.
* ARC issued a sole-source order for the MPRI task order without adequate justification.
* OSC officials performed duties normally done by contracting officer's representatives without authorization or training.
* OSC hired an intermittent consultant using 5 U.S.C. § 3109, and his tasks were consistent with OPM criteria.
* OSC employees can seek redress for prohibited personnel practices through OSC, MSPB, or EEOC.
* However, OSC employees may face conflicts of interest when alleging prohibited personnel practices against the Special Counsel or Deputy Special Counsel.
* Potential options for OSC employees include external investigation or expanded MSPB jurisdiction.
* ARC and OSC agreed with GAO's recommendations.
* GAO made clarifications but did not make other changes suggested by OSC.
</summary>

<summary>
* VA's mission is to provide health care, benefits, and memorial services to veterans.
* VA operates approximately 240 information systems and manages 314,000 desktop computers and 30,000 laptops.
* VA plans to replace or modernize legacy systems, such as PAID and BDN, by 2017 and 2018, respectively.
* VA's 6-year strategic plan aims to improve veterans' access to benefits and services, eliminate the disability claims backlog, and end veteran homelessness.
* VA spent about $3.9 billion on IT in fiscal year 2015 and requested about $4.1 billion for fiscal year 2016.
* VA's CIO is transforming the Office of Information and Technology to better serve veterans.
* VA faces challenges in developing new systems, modernizing existing systems, and increasing interoperability with DOD.
* Effective IT management is critical to VA's mission performance.
</summary>

• **HCFA's Role**: HCFA is responsible for administering Medicare, a vast program serving millions of beneficiaries and processing billions of claims annually.
• **Medicare Components**: Medicare consists of two parts: Part A (hospital insurance) and Part B (supplementary medical insurance).
• **Managed Care**: HCFA oversees managed care plans, including risk contract health maintenance organizations (HMOs), which serve over 5 million beneficiaries.
• **Legislative Reforms**: Recent acts like HIPAA and BBA grant HCFA authority to enhance anti-fraud activities and introduce new health plan options and payment reforms.
• **HCFA's Challenges**: HCFA faces numerous challenges, including implementing new legislation, modernizing information systems, and managing a large workforce.
• **Resource Distribution Concerns**: Managers express concerns about the distribution of agency resources, with some tasks potentially being neglected due to focus on BBA implementation and year 2000 issues.
• **Specialized Expertise Need**: HCFA needs staff with specialized technical expertise to implement recent reforms expeditiously.
• **Loss of Institutional Experience**: The loss of experienced staff due to retirement is a significant concern, as it may hinder the implementation of new payment systems and other tasks.

• FAA's funding primarily comes from the Trust Fund, which receives revenues from excise taxes on airline tickets, aviation fuel, and cargo shipments. These revenues are then available for use subject to appropriations.
• The administration's reauthorization proposal suggests changing FAA's financing system to one based more on cost-based charges, with funding for ATO coming primarily from user charges on commercial aircraft and fuel taxes on general aviation aircraft.
• The proposal also includes creating an advisory board to make recommendations on fee setting and authorizing limited borrowing authority for FAA.

<summary>
* GSA's Federal Technology Service is responsible for providing telecommunications services to federal agencies.
* The current long-distance telecommunications services program, FTS2001, has two contracts with Sprint and MCI WorldCom, each guaranteeing minimum revenues of $750 million.
* GSA is planning the FTS Networx acquisition program to replace the existing contracts, with goals including meeting agency needs, obtaining best value, encouraging competition, responding to the changing marketplace, and providing opportunities for small businesses.
* The Networx program consists of two acquisitions: Networx Universal and Networx Select, with Universal expected to result in multiple contract awards to a few offerors and Select planned for multiple contracts with a more limited service scope.
* GSA faces challenges in finalizing the Networx program strategy, including ensuring adequate inventory information, establishing measures of success, structuring and scheduling contracts, and initiating implementation planning.
* Industry representatives have varying views on the proposed acquisition approach, with some expressing concerns about the scope of services and the procurement timetable.
* GSA must address transition planning to avoid repeating the difficulties encountered during the FTS2001 transition.
</summary>

* <summary>
* FSA, established as a PBO, has made progress in improving customer and employee satisfaction but needs to address systems integration, program integrity, and human capital management.
* FSA's unit cost calculation for administering student aid programs is complex and should be better explained in performance plans and reports.
* FSA's performance plans lack clear goals and measures for systems integration and program integrity, which need to be improved.
* FSA needs to develop a comprehensive human capital strategy that includes succession planning and staff development.
* </summary>

<summary>
* NIH awarded over 21,500 Recovery Act grants totaling $20.7 billion.
* Grants varied in size, geographic distribution, duration, and research methods.
* NIH used standard review processes and criteria for Recovery Act grants.
* Grantees report quarterly on jobs supported by Recovery Act funds to www.federalreporting.gov.
* NIH and grantees collect information on FTEs and other impacts of Recovery Act funding.
* FTEs supported by NIH Recovery Act funding increased from 12,000 in Dec 2009 to 21,000 in Jun 2011.
* NIH expects Recovery Act funds to support a total of approximately 54,000 FTEs.
* NIH and grantees use various metrics to track scientific and nonscientific impacts of Recovery Act funding.
* Principal investigators reported using Recovery Act funds to purchase supplies, equipment, and services.
* Some principal investigators provided scientific training to health care professionals using Recovery Act funds.
</summary>

• Transit-oriented development (TOD) is compact, mixed-use, and walkable neighborhoods near transit stations.
• Factors supporting TOD include market demand for real estate, available land for development, supportive residents, and efficient access to jobs and activity centers.
• Challenges hindering TOD include higher construction costs, lenders' reluctance, lengthy approval processes, unsupportive residents, and unattractive physical features around stations.
• Local governments can encourage TOD through zoning, station area planning, targeted infrastructure investments, and tax incentives.
• FTA considers factors related to TOD when assessing proposed projects, but these factors make up a small percentage of the overall rating.
• Ridership performance of transit lines varies, with some projects exceeding ridership expectations and others falling short.

<summary>
* The Social Security Administration (SSA) provides Personal Earnings and Benefit Estimate Statements (PEBES) to workers to inform them about their Social Security benefits and earnings records.
* The PEBES is sent automatically to eligible workers who have not requested a statement, with the first mailing scheduled for 1997.
* The PEBES provides benefit estimates based on certain assumptions about future employment and earnings.
* The PEBES does not account for certain special circumstances that could affect a worker's actual retirement benefit.
* The PEBES has been revised based on public feedback, but it still contains too much information and is too complex.
* The PEBES lacks an obvious purpose, attractive design, and easy-to-understand explanations, making it difficult for readers to navigate and understand.
* SSA has not collected detailed information from its front-line workers on the public's response to the PEBES and has not conducted formal comprehension tests.
* To improve the PEBES, SSA should revise its layout and design, simplify explanations, evaluate and test alternative formats, and collect more detailed feedback from front-line workers.
</summary>

* SSA administers two programs for individuals unable to work due to disability: DI (insurance program) and SSI (minimum income program). Both use the same disability definition, but have different eligibility requirements and benefits.
* About 14% of disability beneficiaries receive both DI and SSI benefits (concurrent beneficiaries), who are more likely to have mental impairments and be female, with an average age of 45.

• The federal government has appropriated $88 billion for hurricane relief and recovery efforts through four emergency supplemental appropriations acts.
• FEMA received $60 billion for the Disaster Relief Fund, DOD received $1.9 billion, and COE received $400 million in the first two acts.
• FEMA is required to report weekly to the Appropriations Committees on the use of funds it received, but these reports do not provide timely information from a governmentwide perspective.
• FEMA's reported obligations and expenditures for mission assignments do not reflect the status from a governmentwide perspective.
• There is no framework or mechanisms in place to collect and consolidate information, and to report on the $88 billion in hurricane relief and recovery funds provided thus far to 23 federal agencies on a governmentwide basis.
• The government's progress in the rebuilding efforts will be difficult to measure without consistent, reliable, and timely governmentwide information on the use of these funds.
• To improve information on the status of hurricane relief and recovery funds, FEMA should explain in its weekly reports how its reported obligations and expenditures for mission assignments do not reflect the status from a governmentwide perspective, and OMB should establish a framework for governmentwide reporting on the status of hurricane-related funding.

<summary>
* FAA has authority to authorize UAS operations in the national airspace.
* FAA provides access through COAs, experimental certificates, and section 333 exemptions.
* FAA has issued 674 public COAs and 48 section 333 exemptions since 2014.
* FAA has a three-phase approach to UAS integration: Accommodation, Integration, and Evolution.
* FAA issued a Notice for Proposed Rulemaking for small UAS operations in February 2015.
* FAA has selected six UAS test sites, with five receiving 48 COAs and one experimental certificate since 2014.
* FAA and test sites work together to ensure safe testing environments and oversight.
* Other countries allow commercial UAS operations with similar restrictions to FAA's proposed rules.
* FAA faces critical steps to keep the UAS integration process moving forward, including issuing a final rule for small UASs and developing an implementation plan.
* FAA is working to make test sites more accessible and has launched a public education campaign for safe UAS operations.
</summary>

<summary>
* DOD's Commander's Emergency Response Program (CERP) in Afghanistan faces challenges in providing adequate management and oversight due to insufficient trained personnel.
* CERP projects have evolved in complexity, with more projects costing over $500,000, requiring more oversight and management.
* Training on CERP responsibilities is inadequate, leading to errors in contracts and project files.
* Coordination between DOD and USAID on development projects is occurring, but a centralized database for all projects is lacking.
* DOD partially concurred with two recommendations and concurred with one, but GAO believes further action is needed.
</summary>

• The report identified 65 solar-related initiatives across six federal agencies in fiscal years 2010 and 2011.
• Over half of these initiatives supported solar projects exclusively, while the rest supported solar alongside other renewable energy technologies.
• The initiatives supported different types of solar technologies, including photovoltaic and concentrated solar power, and various technology advancement activities from basic research to commercialization.
• The initiatives provided funding to universities, industry, nonprofit organizations, and federal labs and researchers through grants, contracts, and other mechanisms.
• The report found no clear evidence of duplicative initiatives, but some initiatives may have overlapping activities that could be consolidated or resolved through enhanced coordination.

<summary>
* DOD's risk assessment process for chemical and biological defense equipment is flawed and unreliable, leading to an inaccurate low risk assessment.
* Inadequate inventory management contributes to increased risk, with no integrated inventory system for managing protective equipment.
* DOD underestimates the risk by analyzing requirements based on individual equipment items and not ensembles, and by combining service data into a consolidated DOD inventory position.
* To improve risk assessment and readiness, DOD should evaluate risk based on complete ensembles, implement an integrated inventory management system, and cease counting equipment as on hand before delivery.
</summary>

* <summary>
* Federal managers reported limited change in access to and use of program evaluations since 2013.
* Managers with evaluations credited them with contributing to assessing program effectiveness and implementing changes to improve program management or performance.
* Factors that managers reported facilitated evaluation use included leadership support, staff involvement, and evaluation relevance to decision makers.
* </summary>

<summary>
* The federal government has the opportunity to be a model for the employment of people with disabilities.
* The federal government is not on track to achieve the goals set in the executive order.
* Many agency plans for hiring and retaining people with disabilities do not meet OPM's criteria.
* Agency officials need more comprehensive training on tools available to them for hiring and retaining individuals with disabilities.
* The accuracy of data on the number of individuals with disabilities in the federal government is a concern.
</summary>

• BLM's mission is to manage public lands and resources, with about 270 million acres of public lands and 300 million acres of subsurface mineral resources under its management.
• The Bureau's fiscal year 1995 appropriation totaled $1.24 billion.
• BLM is developing the Automated Land and Mineral Records System (ALMRS) to automate land and mineral records and case processing activities, and to provide information to support land and resource management activities.
• The ALMRS/Modernization project consists of three components: ALMRS Initial Operating Capability (ALMRS IOC), Geographic Coordinate Data Base (GCDB), and modernization of BLM's computer and telecommunications infrastructure and rehost of selected management and administrative systems.
• BLM has completed most of the initial installation of computer and telecommunications equipment and has met most of its ALMRS IOC, GCDB, and rehost milestones thus far.
• The project schedule could slip due to the complexity of the remaining tasks and the tight schedule, with little time available to deal with unexpected problems.
• BLM plans to obtain an independent assessment of the ALMRS IOC to help ensure that its requirements are met, but the Bureau's plan to stress test the ALMRS IOC portion of the modernized system is not sufficient.

• IAEA is an independent organization that verifies compliance with nuclear non-proliferation agreements.
• The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT) is the key international agreement that IAEA enforces.
• IAEA's safeguards objectives are to account for nuclear material necessary for weapons production and detect diversion.
• IAEA uses various measures, including inspections, material accounting, containment, and surveillance, to verify compliance.
• The Nuclear Suppliers Group (NSG) is a multilateral export control regime that helps IAEA by requiring recipients of nuclear exports to accept IAEA safeguards.
• IAEA has strengthened its safeguards by implementing the Additional Protocol, which provides more comprehensive information and inspection rights.
• However, IAEA faces limitations in its ability to detect clandestine nuclear programs, such as lack of unfettered inspection rights and practical access problems.
• There are weaknesses in IAEA's safeguards, including limited information on key non-NPT countries and the lack of the Additional Protocol in many NPT signatories.
• The U.S. provides assistance to Russia and other former Soviet countries to secure nuclear material and warheads, detect illicit trafficking, and eliminate excess stockpiles.

• The public faces a high risk of severe disruption of critical services due to the Year 2000 computing crisis, including grounded flights, power loss, and national defense impacts.
• Federal agencies are making slow progress in fixing their systems, and some agencies are significantly behind schedule, putting them at high risk of not being compliant in time.

• OMB has a role in implementing the Information Quality Act (IQA) by developing and issuing guidelines for federal agencies to use for ensuring and maximizing quality, objectivity, utility, and integrity of information they disseminate.
• OMB has worked with agencies to help them develop their own IQA guidelines and has provided assistance and direction to agencies in implementing IQA.
• OMB has not worked with all independent agencies to help them meet IQA requirements, and some agencies do not have IQA guidelines in place.
• OMB has taken steps to improve the public's access to IQA information, such as requiring agencies to post their IQA guidelines and related information on their public websites.

<summary>
* Mutual funds and banks are both financial intermediaries that raise funds from savers and invest them.
* Banks primarily lend to borrowers, while mutual funds invest in securities like stocks and bonds.
* The importance of bank loans as a source of finance has been declining, with businesses and consumers increasingly turning to securities markets.
* Mutual funds have attracted significant amounts of money that could have been placed in bank deposits.
* At the end of 1994, mutual funds held $2.172 trillion, while bank deposits totaled $3.462 trillion.
* Between 1989 and 1994, mutual funds grew by $1.191 trillion, while bank deposits decreased by $89 billion.
* The impact of mutual funds on deposits is difficult to quantify, but it is likely sizable, potentially less than $700 billion.
* The movement of money from deposits to mutual funds does not affect the total supply of loanable and investable funds.
* However, it may shift the intermediaries through which finance flows and affect the availability of credit for different sectors.
* The impact on residential, consumer, and business borrowers is not clear, but mutual funds' investments in securities can enhance the capacity of securities markets to absorb new issues.
</summary>

• The Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) are responsible for improving the nation's public health infrastructure and response to public health emergencies, including bioterrorism.
• HHS and DHS have made progress on major public health IT initiatives, but significant work remains to be done.
• CDC's PHIN initiative includes applications at various stages of implementation, while DHS's initiatives are still in early stages.
• Federal agencies face challenges in improving the public health infrastructure, including developing a national health IT strategy, implementing health data standards, coordinating with state and local public health agencies, and addressing weaknesses in IT planning and management.
• The Secretary of HHS and the Secretary of Homeland Security should take action to ensure that federal initiatives are aligned with the national health IT strategy and coordinated with state and local public health initiatives, and to address interoperability challenges associated with the exchange of public health information.
• HHS and DHS provided additional contextual information and technical comments, which were incorporated into the report as appropriate.
• The report was prepared from July 2004 through April 2005 in accordance with generally accepted government auditing standards.

* **Recent Changes to Pension and Benefit Offerings**: Most large sponsors have made changes to their DB plan formulas, with 81% modifying them. 52% converted traditional plans to cash balance or other hybrid designs, and 62% froze or limited future pension accruals for some or all plan participants.
* **Future Changes**: Most sponsors are unlikely to make significant changes to their DB plans in the near future, but 50% plan to add or expand automatic enrollment features to 401(k)-type DC plans, and 45% plan to increase fixed income investments in their DB plans.
* **Retiree Health Benefits**: 80% of respondents offered health benefits to at least some active employees who could become eligible for retiree benefits, but 46% no longer offer retiree health benefits to employees hired after a certain date. 54% decreased or eliminated their share of health care costs for future retirees who were non-bargaining employees.

* <summary>
	+ The U.S. resettles refugees through a systematic process involving federal, state, and local agencies, as well as private organizations.
	+ Refugees are placed in communities based on factors such as the community's capacity to serve them, employment opportunities, and the presence of family members or ethnic communities.
	+ The federal government provides funding for resettlement services, including cash and medical assistance, employment and social services, and health screenings.
	+ Refugees can face challenges integrating into their communities, such as language barriers, lack of education or work experience, and health issues.
	+ Some communities have developed strategies to facilitate refugee integration, such as establishing refugee community centers, media campaigns, and mentoring programs.
	+ Secondary migration, or the movement of refugees from one community to another, can strain local resources and may not be adequately addressed by current funding processes.
	+ Federal agencies monitor the performance of refugee resettlement programs, but do not currently measure refugee integration as a program outcome.
	+ Studies on refugee integration have identified indicators of integration, barriers to integration, and facilitators of integration.
	+ The federal government can take steps to improve refugee resettlement, such as providing additional guidance on consulting with local stakeholders, increasing the responsiveness of grants for secondary migrants, and examining performance measures to encourage longer-term goals.
* </summary>

<summary>
* The National Flood Insurance Program (NFIP) was established in 1968 to reduce federal disaster costs by providing flood insurance to homeowners and businesses.
* NFIP offers subsidized and full-risk premiums, with subsidized rates applying to about 22% of policies.
* FEMA has taken mitigation efforts to reduce flood damage, but the inventories of repetitive loss properties and subsidized policies have continued to grow.
* NFIP's borrowing authority was increased to $20.8 billion after the 2005 hurricanes, and it still owes approximately $17.8 billion.
* To achieve public policy goals, actions could include charging premiums that reflect actual risks, limiting costs to taxpayers, encouraging broad participation, and promoting private market participation.
* Mitigation efforts could be improved by consolidating FEMA's three flood mitigation programs and providing federal assistance for up-front costs.
* Expanding NFIP participation could lower premium rates and reduce taxpayer costs, but challenges include ensuring risk diversification and affordability for low-income property owners.
</summary>

<summary>
* The 287(g) program allows state and local law enforcement officers to perform immigration enforcement functions under the supervision of ICE.
* ICE has not clearly documented the objective of the 287(g) program in program-related materials.
* MOAs lack specificity on how and under what circumstances participating agencies should use 287(g) authority.
* ICE has not defined the nature and extent of supervision required for participating agencies.
* ICE has not specified what data should be collected and how it should be reported by participating agencies.
* ICE has not developed performance measures to assess the effectiveness of the 287(g) program.
* ICE provides training, equipment, and supervision resources to participating agencies.
* Participating agencies provide officers, space for equipment, and funding for other expenses.
* ICE and participating agencies report benefits such as reducing crime, identifying repeat offenders, and improving community quality of life.
* Concerns include fear of deportation for minor offenses, racial profiling, and increased enforcement at worksites.
</summary>

• SEC, NASD, and NYSE share information on mutual fund sales practices and other examination priorities through examination modules and regular meetings.
• SEC reviews SRO examination modules during on-site inspections and broker-dealer oversight examinations.
• SEC distributes examination guidance to its broker-dealer examiners through internal memorandums and other written guidance.
• SEC provides training to its broker-dealer examiners on mutual funds and other topics through courses and seminars.
• SEC tracks and assesses the training provided to its broker-dealer examiners through attendance rosters and other records.
• SEC has not developed a system to track the full scope of work performed during its broker-dealer oversight examinations, limiting its ability to assess the significance of deficiencies and violations found.

• TVA is an independent federal corporation established to improve the quality of life in the Tennessee River Valley.
• TVA's legislation and governance are outlined in the TVA Act, which established its mission, authorities, and limitations.
• TVA's operations and planning involve generating electricity, managing debt, and maintaining financial health.
• TVA's debt ceiling is set by Congress and has not been changed since 1979, but its business and operations have grown.
• TVA's retirement system, TVARS, is a separate legal entity administered by a seven-member board.
• TVA aims to reduce its debt to $22 billion by 2023 through rate increases, limiting operating expenses, and reducing capital expenditures.

* <summary>
* FDIC provided $970 million in open bank assistance to First City banks in 1988, but they failed in 1992.
* FDIC estimated the cost of the 1992 resolution at $500 million, but the sale of the banks in 1993 resulted in a surplus of about $60 million.
* FDIC's resolution decisions are subject to lessons learned from the First City experience.
* FDIC's open bank assistance decision in 1988 was based on economic assumptions that proved to be incorrect.
* FDIC's assistance agreement did not include sufficient safeguards to ensure that First City pursued a prudent business strategy.
* OCC's examination reports and workpapers could have been more comprehensive in explaining the basis for its closure decision.
* FDIC could have considered information from the primary regulator relative to asset quality in making its resolution decisions.
* </summary>

• The Single Audit Act of 1984 was passed to improve accountability and oversight of federal assistance provided to state and local governments.
• The act requires a single audit for entities receiving $500,000 or more in federal financial assistance, covering financial statements, internal control, and compliance with laws and regulations.
• A recent study by the President's Council on Integrity and Efficiency (PCIE) found that 51% of single audits had deficiencies, with 35.5% being unacceptable.
• The PCIE recommended revising standards, requiring minimum continuing professional education (CPE) for auditors, and enhancing disciplinary processes.
• GAO supports the PCIE recommendations but notes that unresolved issues regarding the proposed training requirement need to be addressed.

<summary>
* Medicare is a federal health insurance program for elderly and disabled beneficiaries.
* It consists of two parts: hospital insurance (part A) and supplemental medical insurance (part B).
* Claims are processed by intermediaries (for part A) and carriers (for part B).
* Medicare's contracting process differs from other federal programs due to provisions in the Social Security Act.
* Intermediaries are selected through a nomination process by provider associations, while carriers are chosen by the Secretary of Health and Human Services from a small pool of health insurers.
* Medicare could benefit from various contracting reforms, such as:
	+ Directly choosing contractors on a competitive basis.
	+ Allowing contractors to specialize in specific functions.
	+ Authorizing performance-based contracts and profit.
	+ Terminating contracts more efficiently.
* Medicare has used health insurers for claims processing since its inception, but the number of willing insurers has declined.
* The agency has proposed legislative changes to repeal provider nomination authority and allow contracting with non-health insurers.
* Functional contracting and performance-based contracting have challenges that need to be addressed.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Defense Science Board (DSB) estimated that DOD could save $6 billion annually by outsourcing CONUS logistics activities.
* DSB's estimate was overstated by about $1 billion due to understated contract administration and oversight costs and one-time inventory savings claimed as steady state savings.
* Another $3 billion in projected savings would be difficult to achieve or unlikely to be achieved due to timing and DOD's culture.
* The remaining $2 billion of DSB's $6-billion savings estimate was achievable or already identified in DOD's future year defense program.
* DSB overstated its estimate of annual savings from equipment reliability improvements by at least $1.2 billion.
* DSB's assumption of a 25-percent savings rate from outsourcing was overly optimistic.
* Not all logistics activities can be outsourced due to legislative barriers, such as the 60/40 public-private split and the requirement for public-private competition.
* DOD's effort to reduce costs and achieve savings is important, and it should develop a detailed implementation plan for improving the efficiency and effectiveness of its logistics infrastructure.
* The plan should establish time frames for identifying and evaluating alternative support options and implementing the most cost-effective solutions.
* DOD should present the plan to Congress to provide a basis for oversight and allow affected parties to see what is going to happen and when.
</summary>

* <summary>
* The Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) reduced its workforce by 1,894 FTEs between fiscal years 1993 and 1996, with the Office of Housing accounting for the largest percentage of HUD’s downsizing.
* HUD refocused its mission, consolidated routine activities, implemented paperless processing, and used contractors to supplement staff and provide technical expertise.
* HUD’s Office of Housing reported that it maintained performance during downsizing, and performance measurement data showed that the Office generally met or exceeded the goals it set for itself during this period.
* Customer satisfaction surveys conducted during downsizing showed mixed results, and interviews with a small number of Office of Housing customers revealed that some were dissatisfied with the Office’s performance due to major losses of staff with adequate technical expertise.
* </summary>

<summary>
* IRS's National Research Program (NRP) aims to measure voluntary compliance with tax laws.
* NRP's main elements are casebuilding, classification, and taxpayer audits.
* Casebuilding involves gathering information to verify taxpayer-reported data.
* Classification determines which returns need auditing and the type of audit required.
* NRP audits focus on verifying items that cannot be independently verified.
* IRS has made progress in casebuilding, classification, and auditing NRP returns.
* Quality assurance measures are in place to ensure accurate NRP data.
* IRS is minimizing taxpayer burden through NRP casebuilding and classification processes.
* NRP is on track to meet its goals of obtaining meaningful compliance data while minimizing burden.
</summary>

• The U.S. Census Bureau (Bureau) is responsible for planning the 2010 Census, including the American Community Survey (ACS) and the Master Address File/Topologically Integrated Geographic Encoding and Referencing (MAF/TIGER) enhancements.
• The Bureau's Decennial Management Division has been given the responsibility for planning the 2010 Census and has established an executive steering committee for this purpose.
• Each group under the 2010 Census planning organization has specific activities that it was charged with studying.
• The General Accounting Office (GAO) is the audit, evaluation, and investigative arm of Congress and exists to support Congress in meeting its constitutional responsibilities and to help improve the performance and accountability of the federal government for the American people.
• GAO examines the use of public funds, evaluates federal programs and policies, and provides analyses, recommendations, and other assistance to help Congress make informed oversight, policy, and funding decisions.

• HHS has established a framework to protect Medicare beneficiaries' prescription drug use information used for purposes other than direct clinical care.
• This framework includes regulations, outreach efforts, and enforcement activities.
• HHS has issued regulations, including the HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules, to govern the use and disclosure of protected health information (PHI).
• OCR has developed guidance and conducted outreach efforts to promote awareness of PHI uses and protections.
• OCR investigates complaints and data breaches to enforce HIPAA regulations.
• OCR has initiated a pilot audit program to proactively monitor covered entities' compliance.
• However, OCR has not yet issued required guidance on de-identifying PHI or established plans for a sustained audit capability.

• The MHSS has no current or upcoming need for clinical psychologists who may prescribe medication as it already has a surplus of psychiatrists and psychologists to meet its readiness requirements.
• The PDP faced several implementation problems, including lack of a clearly defined purpose, difficulty recruiting participants, unspecified selection criteria, changes in curriculum, delays in granting prescribing privileges, and unresolved supervision issues.
• The total cost of the PDP is estimated to be about $6.1 million, or approximately $610,000 per psychologist who completed the program.
• The PDP increased the number of MHSS mental health care providers who may prescribe drugs, potentially reducing psychiatrists’ workloads.
• The cost-effectiveness of having MHSS psychologists prescribe psychotropic medication is unclear, and reinstating the PDP is not recommended given the MHSS's current readiness requirements and the project's substantial cost and persistent implementation difficulties.

* The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) project has made progress in building, integrating, and testing significant portions of the telescope within its schedule and cost commitments.
* Technical challenges have impacted the project's schedule, with over 100 risks identified that need to be mitigated before launch.
* The project is currently on schedule with 8.75 months of schedule reserve remaining, but all elements and major subsystems are within weeks of moving onto the project's critical path.
* The project's cost status is within its allocated budget for the fourth consecutive year since the 2011 replan, but the cryocooler used a significant share of the project's fiscal year 2015 cost reserves.
* Independent oversight has provided insight into project risks, with the Standing Review Board and Independent Verification & Validation facility continuing to oversee progress and identify concerns.

• Chemical facilities are potential targets for terrorists due to the hazardous materials they store and use.
• EPA regulates around 15,000 facilities under the Clean Air Act, but their security preparedness is largely unknown.
• DHS has limited authority to address chemical sector security and relies on voluntary participation from the private sector.
• DHS and EPA have called for legislation to give the federal government greater authority over chemical facility security.
• Industry associations have taken steps to encourage or require members to address security, but the extent of participation is unclear.
• Challenges in preparing facilities against a terrorist attack include cost, lack of threat information, and limited guidance on vulnerability assessments and emergency response planning.
• DHS and EPA have proposed legislation to require high-risk chemical facilities to conduct vulnerability assessments and implement security measures.

• DHS faces challenges in ensuring privacy protections are addressed early and consistently across its programs and activities, including data mining, passenger prescreening, use of data from commercial sources, use of personal identification technologies like RFID, and participation in the information sharing environment.
• DHS has taken steps to address privacy concerns in some programs, such as ADVISE and Secure Flight, but further action is needed to ensure consistent implementation of privacy protections across the department.

• Social Security provides benefits to retirees, disabled workers, and dependents.
• The program has expanded over time to include disability and survivors’ insurance.
• Benefits are calculated using a progressive yet earnings-based formula.
• Old Age benefits are calculated using the highest 35 years of indexed earnings.
• Disability benefits are calculated using fewer years of earnings, depending on the worker's age at application.
• Spouses, children, and survivors can also receive benefits based on a worker's earnings record.
• Benefits are subject to a family maximum and receive annual cost-of-living adjustments.
• The program faces long-term financing challenges due to demographic changes.
• Reform proposals have been made to improve solvency, including benefit reductions and revenue increases.
• The effects of these reforms on disabled workers and dependents should be considered.

• As of September 30, 2014, Treasury had disbursed $435 billion in TARP funds, with $38.5 billion allocated to housing programs.
• Treasury has recovered $226.4 billion in repayments and income from the Capital Purchase Program (CPP), exceeding the original amount disbursed by $21.5 billion.
• Treasury estimates that some nonhousing programs will produce lifetime income, while others will have a lifetime cost.
• Treasury continues to wind down TARP nonhousing programs and implement housing programs, with a focus on protecting taxpayers' interests and maximizing returns.

• Coal-fueled electricity generating units provide a significant share of U.S. electricity.
• Four key EPA regulations will affect coal-fueled units, with different compliance deadlines.
• These regulations aim to reduce air pollution, water resources, and solid waste impacts.
• EPA projects significant health and environmental benefits from these regulations.
• A new regulation to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from existing fossil-fueled units is proposed.
• DOE, FERC, and EPA are monitoring industry progress in responding to EPA regulations.
• RTOs provide information to agencies on retirements, retrofits, and reliability assessments.
• Power companies plan to retire more coal-fueled capacity and retrofit less than previously estimated.
• Retirements are expected to be concentrated in certain states and among older, smaller, and more polluting units.
• Agencies concur with GAO's analysis and will continue monitoring industry progress and coordinating efforts.

• FSA does not consistently conduct annual eligibility determinations for estates kept open beyond 2 years, as required.
• Only 39 out of 181 estates reviewed received all required annual determinations.
• 73 estates (40%) did not receive any eligibility determinations from 1999 to 2005.
• Some estates received payments for over 10 years without any eligibility determinations.
• Even when determinations were conducted, they were sometimes based on insufficient information or explanations.
• Some field offices approved payments to groups of estates without individual determinations.
• The extent of eligibility determinations varies between states.
• FSA's lack of management controls resulted in improper payments to deceased individuals, totaling $1.1 billion from 1999 to 2005.
• USDA agreed with GAO's recommendations to improve oversight of farm programs.

<summary>
* FAA's ATC modernization program has experienced significant cost overruns, delays, and performance shortfalls over the past 16 years.
* Key projects such as WAAS and STARS have encountered delays and cost increases, and FAA is still struggling with software acquisition processes.
* FAA lacks a complete and enforced systems architecture, reliable cost information, and an effective management structure for software acquisition.
* FAA faces a looming crisis with the year 2000 date requirements and is behind schedule in addressing it.
</summary>

<summary>
• The U.S. provided $970 million in rule of law programs worldwide from 1993 to 1998.
• Annual funding increased from $128 million to $218 million over this period.
• Latin America and the Caribbean received the largest share (36%).
• Africa, Central Europe, and the former Soviet Union each received about 15%.
• Funding shifted from Latin America and the Caribbean to Central Europe.
• Central Europe's share grew from 9% to 31% between 1993 and 1998.
</summary>

• Franchise funds are government-run, self-supporting businesslike enterprises managed by federal employees.
• They provide a variety of common administrative services, such as payroll processing, information technology support, employee assistance programs, public relations, and contracting.
• Franchise funds are required to recover their full costs of doing business and are allowed to retain up to 4 percent of their total annual income.
• The Government Management Reform Act of 1994 authorized the Office of Management and Budget to designate six federal agencies to establish the franchise fund pilot program.
• Congress anticipated that the franchise funds would be able to provide common administrative services more efficiently than federal agencies’ own personnel.
• The original operating principles for franchise funds included offering services on a fully competitive basis, using a comprehensive set of performance measures to assess the quality of franchise fund services, and establishing cost and performance benchmarks against their competitors—other government organizations providing the same types of services.
• There are five franchise funds currently in operation, and DOD primarily uses two for contracting services—GovWorks, operated by the Department of the Interior, and FedSource, operated by the Department of the Treasury.

• Federal officials and stakeholders identified federal authorities, agency initiatives, joint community-level planning, leadership, community engagement, and agency resources for collaboration as directly affecting federal-nonfederal collaboration aimed at reducing wildland fire risk to communities.
• Many federal officials and stakeholders said an engaged community, which understands the issues associated with wildland fire and is willing to take action to reduce risk, enhances federal-nonfederal collaboration to reduce wildland fire risk.
• Federal officials and stakeholders identified actions that could improve federal and nonfederal entities' ability to reduce wildland fire risk to communities, including improving implementation of the Cohesive Strategy, increasing collaborative planning, expanding education, increasing prevention efforts, improving timber-processing capability, adopting state and local ordinances, and providing insurance incentives.
• The report recommends that the Secretaries of Agriculture and the Interior direct the Chief of the Forest Service and the Director of the Office of Wildland Fire, respectively, to work with WFLC to develop measures to assess national progress toward achieving the goals of the Cohesive Strategy.

• The Foundation received $3 million from the U.S. Treasury for the Memorial Garden project, with an additional $73,152 in interest earned by June 30, 1994.
• The Foundation's financial condition is precarious, with liabilities exceeding assets, and there are doubts about its ability to continue operations and maintain the Memorial Garden.

• Pension plans invest in hedge funds and private equity to achieve returns superior to stocks, diversify portfolios, and reduce volatility.
• Challenges of investing in hedge funds and private equity include investment risks, limited transparency, liquidity, operational risks, and high fees.

• The U.S. territories have unique Medicaid and CHIP programs with different eligibility, benefits, and funding structures compared to the states.
• Limited federal oversight and program integrity efforts in the territories raise concerns about protecting Medicaid and CHIP funds from fraud, waste, and abuse.

* <summary>
	+ EPA's CERCLIS database identified 3,036 sites awaiting an NPL decision, but only 1,789 are potentially eligible.
	+ Potentially eligible sites include 1,739 nonfederal sites and 50 federal facilities.
	+ 686 sites have had some cleanup activities, while 1,103 have not or no information is available.
	+ Sites are located in 48 states, DC, Puerto Rico, and the Northern Mariana Islands, and under Navajo Nation jurisdiction.
	+ EPA, other federal agencies, and states have conducted cleanup actions at 38% of potentially eligible sites.
	+ 13% of sites have conditions associated with contaminated drinking water sources.
	+ Officials from 25% of states rated their state's ability to fund cleanup activities as excellent or good, while 52% rated it as poor or very poor.
* </summary>

* <summary>
	+ State has taken measures to strengthen the security of the visa process, including requiring personal interviews and scanning fingerprints, which have increased consular workload and wait times.
	+ State has implemented some procedures and policies to maximize efficiency and better manage visa workload, such as using consular management assistance teams and establishing business and student facilitation programs.
	+ State has deployed temporary duty staff and utilized consular-commissioned officials to assist in processing and adjudicating visa applicants, particularly in India.
	+ State has repositioned consular staff to posts with high visa demand, such as Brazil, China, India, and Mexico, and plans to transfer additional positions to these posts.
	+ State has not developed a long-term strategy to address increasing visa demand, which is projected to continue to rise, and has not estimated the resources needed to meet future demand.
* </summary>

* OPM's retirement modernization initiative, RetireEZ, aims to provide prompt and complete benefit payments upon retirement.
* The program has partially implemented two of eight planned capabilities, while the remaining six have not been implemented due to the termination of the DBTS contract.
* OPM has not yet developed a complete plan for its restructured program, including scope, implementation strategy, lines of responsibility, management processes, schedule, and results-oriented goals.
* OPM faces significant management challenges, including developing a reliable cost estimate, establishing effective EVM, managing requirements, planning tests, and ensuring proper oversight.

• The number of school-aged children with limited English proficiency in the U.S. has grown significantly over the last two decades.
• The Bilingual Education Act (BEA) was passed in 1968 to educate these students and has four grant programs: PDI, Enhancement, Comprehensive, and Systemwide.
• These programs share similar goals, eligibility criteria, and uses of funds, but have different legislative purposes and grant lengths.
• The effectiveness of these programs is unknown due to lack of comparable data, as local assessments vary.
• Consolidating these programs could reduce overlap and allow Education to redirect resources to other activities.
• Education officials believe that one program with adequate flexibility could meet the needs of school districts serving students with limited English proficiency.
• The Congress may want to consider consolidating the four bilingual education programs into one to decrease overlap and improve efficiency.

• NCIC is a nationwide criminal justice information system maintained by the FBI, serving as a repository of data on crimes and criminals of nationwide interest and as a locator file for missing and unidentified persons.
• As of January 1, 2011, NCIC contained 85,820 active records in its missing persons file, with 35,000 federal, state, and local law enforcement agencies having access to it.
• The Adam Walsh Child Protection and Safety Act of 2006 requires all reports of missing persons under the age of 21 to be entered into NCIC within 2 hours of receipt.
• CJIS, the division within the FBI that operates as the focal point for criminal justice information services, is responsible for ensuring compliance with the 2-hour entry requirement.
• CJIS conducts triennial audits of CSAs (Criminal Justice Agency) to assess their compliance with NCIC policies, including the 2-hour entry requirement.
• During its audits, CJIS reviews random samples of records of missing persons in selected LEAs (Law Enforcement Agencies) and assesses all missing children records contained in the sample to determine compliance with the 2-hour entry requirement.
• CJIS found that 9 out of 10 CSAs audited were out of compliance with the 2-hour entry requirement, with the percentage of missing children records entered within 2 hours ranging from 53% to 91% across the 10 states.
• The two predominant reasons for untimely entry of missing children records were LEA personnel not knowing about the 2-hour entry requirement and responding officers not providing information on the missing child in a timely manner.
• CJIS and the Board have not established minimum audit standards for assessing compliance with the 2-hour entry requirement, which raises questions about the reliability of CSA information on LEA compliance.

* Automobile crashworthiness is influenced by crash type, crash severity, automobile size, safety belts, and driver age and gender.
* Crash type and crash severity are the most important factors affecting driver injury.
* Automobile weight has the least explanatory power among the factors examined.
* Women drivers are more likely to be hospitalized or killed in collisions with cars and light trucks but not in one-car crashes.
* Drivers 65 and older have a greater risk of hospitalization or death than younger drivers in one-car as well as multivehicle crashes.
* Safety belts may not protect women drivers as well as men drivers, but their effectiveness is roughly equivalent for drivers 16 to 64 and for drivers 65 and older.

* The Coast Guard's budget request for fiscal year 2008 is $8.73 billion, an increase of 3.3% from the previous year.
* The budget includes $5.9 billion for operating expenditures, which supports the Coast Guard's 11 mission programs, as well as increases in cost of living, fuel, and maintenance costs.
* The budget also includes $949 million for acquisition, construction, and improvement (AC&I) activities, a decrease of 19% from the previous year.

• DOD’s Families First program aims to improve the quality of household goods moves for servicemembers and civilians.
• The program has faced management challenges and delays in implementing a new information management system, DPS.
• DOD has not developed a comprehensive plan to organize, staff, and fund Families First.
• Long-standing problems in DOD’s personal property program persist despite millions of dollars invested in improvements.
• DOD has not analyzed alternatives to Families First as required by Congress.
• The cost of Families First is projected to increase by about $1.2 billion over current program costs through fiscal year 2011.
• DPS is expected to cost about $180 million through fiscal year 2011.
• DOD has not set aside funding to cover the over $1 billion in increased costs associated with implementing Families First.
• DOD’s comments on a draft of this report concurred with GAO’s recommendations and cited specific actions taken or planned to address them.

* <summary>
* The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulates pesticides used on tobacco in the United States, including assessing their health risks and setting residue limits for approved pesticides on human food and animal feed crops.
* EPA does not set residue limits for pesticides approved for use on tobacco, and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and USDA do not test tobacco for maximum concentrations of residues of approved pesticides.
* The Dairy and Tobacco Adjustment Act of 1983 requires USDA to establish maximum allowable concentrations for residues of selected pesticides that are not approved for use on tobacco in the United States but that are likely used on tobacco in some other countries and to test imported and domestic flue-cured and burley tobacco to ensure the residue levels do not exceed the maximum levels allowed.
* USDA tests samples of imported and domestic flue-cured and burley tobacco for residues of 20 pesticides not approved for use in the United States, primarily for purposes of trade equity.
* The USDA testing program found less than 1 percent of domestically produced or imported flue-cured and burley tobacco with residue levels above the allowable levels from 1999 through 2001.
* </summary>

* User fees are a way to finance federal programs or activities by charging users for services or benefits above and beyond what is normally available to the general public.
* The beneficiary-pays principle is a useful guideline for assigning costs to those who primarily benefit from the program.
* Fees should be set and adjusted to cover the intended share of costs over time.
* The primary challenge in determining when and how to collect a fee is striking a balance between ensuring compliance and minimizing administrative costs.
* Congress determines to what extent an agency may access (obligate and spend) fee collections.
* Agencies must substantively review and report on their fees on a regular basis to ensure that fees remain aligned with program costs and activities.

* <summary>
* OSSE and DCPS have used federal payments for various school improvement activities, including facility renovation, summer school programs, and professional development.
* Both agencies have faced challenges in managing and monitoring the use of these funds, with OSSE designated as a "high risk" grantee by the U.S. Department of Education and DCPS struggling with procurement practices and contract monitoring.
* </summary>

• Agencies may not fully link their budgets to strategic goals and consider resource limitations.
• Agencies often pursue individual needs rather than collective needs.
• Individual program decisions may undercut sound policies.
• Congressional direction may require agencies to buy items and provide services that are not planned for or needed.
• Agencies may budget and allocate resources incrementally based on historical precedents rather than strategic planning.
• Agencies may not adequately consider likely agencywide resource limitations.
• Agencies may not fully implement portfolio-based investment management practices.
• Agencies may not ensure that programs proceed through the acquisition process with requisite knowledge.
• Agencies may not budget for adequate funding, putting Congress in a position to decide whether to provide additional funding.
• Agencies may not maintain stability in system requirements throughout the acquisition process.

<summary>
* DOD sets a standard price for fuel annually, based on crude oil price, refinement markup, and nonproduct costs.
* Actual fuel costs differed from estimated costs in fiscal years 2009-2013 due to price fluctuations and consumption differences.
* Crude oil price and refinement markup accounted for most of the difference between estimated and actual prices.
* DOD increased refinement markup in 2013 to account for price spread between WTI and other crude oil benchmarks.
* DOD has not reevaluated its approach or documented assumptions for setting the standard price since 2007.
* DOD has not considered alternative crude oil benchmarks or accounted for differences between domestic and international crude oil prices.
* DOD has not documented its rationale for selecting WTI as a crude oil benchmark or determining the refinement markup.
* DOD has not considered whether a crude oil baseline is still reasonable given recent market changes.
</summary>

* <summary>DOD's procurement process spans numerous Defense agencies and military services, beginning with the receipt of a requirement and ending at the contract closeout. The procurement process provides for acquiring supplies and services from nonfederal sources and administering the related contractual instruments. It also provides for administering grants, cooperative agreements, and other transactions executed by contracting offices. The procurement process begins with the receipt of a requirement and ends at the contract closeout. In November 1994, DOD’s Director of Defense Procurement (DDP) initiated the SPS program to acquire and deploy a single automated system to perform all contract management-related functions within DOD’s procurement process for all DOD organizations and activities. From 1994 to 1996, DOD defined SPS requirements and solicited commercially available vendor products for satisfying these requirements. DOD subsequently awarded a contract to American Management Systems (AMS), Incorporated, in April 1997, to use its commercially available contract management system as the foundation for SPS, modify this commercial product as necessary to meet the requirements, and perform related services. DOD also directed the contractor to deliver SPS functionality in four incremental releases. The department later increased the number of releases across which this functionality would be delivered to seven; reduced the size of the increments; and allowed certain, more critical functionality to be delivered sooner. Over the last 4 years, DOD and AMS have deployed four releases to 773 locations in support of 21,900 users. The fifth release was delivered in February 2001 for acceptance testing; however, due to software deficiencies, this release was sent back to the vendor for rework and has not been deployed. AMS is expected to provide a second version of this release to DOD in July 2001 for additional testing. If accepted, the fifth release is to be deployed to about 4,500 users beginning in fiscal year 2002. DOD has not yet contracted for the sixth and seventh releases.</summary>

• USCIS has taken steps to implement internal controls to detect immigration benefit fraud, including establishing an office for fraud detection and national security, outlining a strategy for detecting fraud, and conducting fraud assessments.
• USCIS has not yet implemented some aspects of internal control standards and fraud control best practices that could further enhance its ability to detect fraud, such as expanding its fraud assessment program to cover more application types, incorporating threat and consequence assessments into its fraud assessment activities, and using risk analysis to evaluate management alternatives to mitigate identified vulnerabilities.
• USCIS needs to implement a mechanism to ensure that information about fraud vulnerabilities uncovered during the course of normal operations—by USCIS and related agencies—feeds back into and contributes to changes in policies and procedures when needed to ensure that identified vulnerabilities result in appropriate corrective actions.

• IRS processed 113.4 million individual income tax returns in 1994, slightly less than expected.
• Electronic filing and TeleFile use increased, while 1040PC use declined.
• IRS' computer systems performed well, with some intermittent problems.
• IRS met or exceeded its refund accuracy and timeliness goals.
• IRS identified 58,828 fraudulent refund claims, a significant increase from the previous year.
• Taxpayers had difficulty reaching IRS by telephone for assistance, orders, and TeleFile.

• TennCare is a capitated managed care program in Tennessee that expanded health coverage to hundreds of thousands of uninsured people.
• The program was implemented rapidly, leading to confusion among enrollees, providers, and MCOs.
• TennCare's capitation rates were set using historical Medicaid costs and were reduced by charity care deductions and enrollee cost sharing.
• The state's methodology for setting capitation rates was criticized by consultants as actuarially unsound and not accounting for regional cost variations.
• TennCare's financial impact on providers is uncertain, but available analyses suggest that it has negatively affected hospitals, federally qualified health centers, and physicians.
• The success of TennCare depends on the continued participation of MCOs and providers.
• TennCare's quality and accessibility of medical care are largely unknown, but early indications suggest that quality and access could be improved.
• The state's quality assurance monitoring plan is slow to implement, and HCFA requires interim monitoring strategies to ensure access and quality.
• TennCare's capitation rates were substantially below adjusted historical Medicaid per capita fee-for-services costs, and the rates were not based on commonly accepted actuarial methods.
• The state's capitation rate-setting methodology did not account for regional cost variations, and the rates were not based on commonly accepted actuarial methods.

* The rapid and widespread increase in the use of crack—a smokable form of cocaine—in the 1980s was referred to as a drug epidemic.
* To identify emerging drug use problems, researchers and government agencies look for changing patterns in drug use, such as a new illicit drug, a change in how a drug is taken, or a change in the level of use of an existing drug among populations that routinely abuse drugs.
* The federal government funds activities and programs to implement the nation’s drug control strategy, with about 25 percent of federal drug control resources provided to state and local governments and private entities.
* The National Institute on Drug Abuse (NIDA), the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA), and the Office of National Drug Control Policy (ONDCP) are the main federal agencies involved in drug abuse prevention, treatment, and research.

• **State Profiling Methods**: States use statistical models or characteristic screens to identify unemployment claimants likely to exhaust benefits. Most states use statistical models, which rank claimants based on their likelihood of exhaustion. Some states use characteristic screens, which select claimants based on specific criteria. States may also consider additional variables beyond those recommended by Labor.

• **Reemployment Services**: States provide reemployment services to profiled claimants, including orientation sessions, job search assistance, and sometimes individual needs assessments and service plans. However, the extent and nature of these services vary, and many states do not adhere to Labor's recommended in-depth approach.

• The military health system has three missions: maintaining the health of active-duty service members, maintaining readiness, and providing care to dependents and retirees.
• TRICARE is the military health care program that offers three options: TRICARE Prime, TRICARE Extra, and TRICARE Standard.
• Medicare is a federally financed health insurance program for the elderly, some people with disabilities, and people with end-stage kidney disease.
• The Medicare subvention demonstration allowed DOD to create managed care organizations that participate in the Medicare+Choice program and enroll older retirees.
• The demonstration ended on December 31, 2001, and was replaced by TRICARE For Life, which provides expanded health care coverage to older military retirees.
• DOD's costs of providing care to Senior Prime enrollees were higher than what Medicare could pay, primarily due to higher utilization of services.
• The BBA payment rules resulted in Medicare owing DOD nothing for care provided to Senior Prime enrollees during 1999, as DOD's expenditures on care for all retirees exceeded its level of effort requirement.

<summary>
* NTSB has fully implemented or made significant progress in following leading management practices in eight areas.
* Three management recommendations were fully implemented by 2008.
* NTSB has made further progress on eight management recommendations since 2008.
* NTSB has fully implemented an IT strategic plan and undergone annual security audits.
* NTSB has made significant progress in limiting local administrator privileges and developing a strategic training plan.
* NTSB has initiated actions to improve knowledge management and diversity management.
* NTSB has developed transparent policies for selecting accidents to investigate in all modes.
* NTSB has increased use of its Training Center and reduced its overall operating deficit.
* NTSB proposes changes to its authorizing legislation, including authority to investigate incidents and reduced requirements for rail and maritime accidents.
</summary>

<summary>
* EPA's GPRA implementation provides valuable information on plans, goals, strategies, and performance measures.
* EPA's performance report shows progress in improving air quality, safe drinking water, and hazardous waste cleanup.
* EPA's strategies for achieving goals include working with states, research, and regulatory approaches.
* EPA's performance plan for fiscal year 2002 reflects changes from the previous year's plan.
* EPA has made improvements to its performance report in response to GAO's concerns.
* EPA's performance plan includes goals and measures related to human capital and information security, but not state working relationships.
