* EPA's major management challenges include human capital, information security, state working relationships, and environmental information management.
* EPA's performance report discusses progress in resolving these challenges.
* EPA's performance plan has goals and measures related to three of the four major management challenges.
* EPA's performance plan does not have specific goals or measures related to improving working relationships with the states.
</summary>

<summary>
* DOD's CIM initiative aims to improve business practices and use information technology more efficiently, but its implementation has faced challenges.
* DOD has shifted its focus from improving business processes to selecting and implementing migration systems, which has raised concerns about locking in inefficient processes and diverting funds from improvement projects.
* DOD's management strategy for CIM has not fully engaged functional managers, leading to a lack of acceptance and support for the initiative.
* To address these issues, DOD should revise its CIM management strategy to involve functional managers more actively, train employees to promote understanding and acceptance of changes, and consider renaming the initiative to better communicate its primary objective.
</summary>

<summary>
* GAO investigators produced counterfeit NRC documents and a bill of lading for a fictitious company.
* They transported radioactive sources sufficient to make a dirty bomb across the U.S.-Canada and U.S.-Mexico borders.
* At both borders, CBP inspectors did not question the validity of the counterfeit documents.
* CBP inspectors detected the presence of radioactive sources using radiation portal monitors and RIID devices.
* GAO briefed CBP and NRC officials about the results of their undercover operations.
* NRC officials disagreed with GAO's assessment of the amount of radioactive material needed for a dirty bomb.
</summary>

<summary>
* DOD's technology transition programs, including TTI, DACP, and Quick Reaction Fund, aim to speed up the integration of promising technologies into military operations.
* The programs have shown potential benefits, such as improved performance, affordability, manufacturability, and operational capability for warfighters.
* However, it's too early to assess the overall impact of these programs, and they lack consistent performance measures to track progress and return on investment.
* To optimize these programs, DOD should develop performance measures, improve feedback mechanisms, use formal agreements, confirm technology readiness levels, enhance communication, and assess the role of the Technology Transition Council.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Bureau's 2020 Research and Testing and GSS-I schedules exhibit some characteristics of a reliable schedule but have important weaknesses.
* The Bureau is not conducting a quantitative risk analysis on its schedules, which could impact the Bureau's ability to meet milestones and provide a measure of how much time contingency should be built in the schedule to help manage certain risks.
* The Bureau has implemented a formal change control process and provides narratives that go along with some schedule updates, ensuring management is informed of schedule changes on a regular basis.
* The Bureau has not taken advantage of some opportunities to use its schedules to reinforce roles or clarify responsibilities, such as by reflecting dependencies of activities or handing off to each other.
* The Bureau is following leading practices for collaboration for its MAF development work, including setting goals and establishing joint strategies, reinforcing individual accountability, and using coordination groups and matrixed research teams.
</summary>

• The Clean Air Act, passed in 1963 and significantly amended in 1970, 1977, and 1990, regulates air pollution from stationary and mobile sources.
• EPA is responsible for setting national ambient air quality standards (NAAQS) for six major pollutants: ozone, carbon monoxide, nitrogen dioxide, sulfur oxides, particulate matter, and lead.
• EPA must review and revise NAAQS every 5 years to ensure they are protective of public health and welfare.
• States are responsible for developing implementation plans to achieve and maintain compliance with NAAQS.
• EPA must approve or disapprove state implementation plans.
• EPA has completed most of the 452 actions required by the 1990 amendments related to Titles I, III, and IV.
• EPA missed many statutory deadlines for these actions, but the deadlines played an important role in guiding and supporting EPA's efforts to complete them.
• EPA has not completed 22 requirements related to Title I with statutory deadlines, including rules involving consumer and commercial products and reviews of NAAQS.
• EPA has not completed 21 requirements related to Title III, mostly residual risk reviews of technology-based standards.
• EPA has not completed 2 requirements related to Title IV, including an opt-in regulation for process sources and a sulfur dioxide/nitrogen oxides inter-pollutant trading study.

• OJJDP established the Girls Study Group to identify effective programs for preventing and reducing girls' delinquency.
• The group reviewed over 1,000 documents and identified 61 programs targeting girls' delinquency.
• The group assessed the methodological quality of studies on these programs using OJP's What Works criteria.
• The group found that few programs had been studied and lacked conclusive evidence of effectiveness.
• OJJDP plans to provide technical assistance to help programs prepare for evaluations.
• OJJDP will issue a solicitation for funding to support evaluations of girls' delinquency programs in fiscal year 2010.
• OJJDP has not developed a documented plan with specific funding requirements and time frames for meeting its girls' delinquency goals.
• GAO recommended that OJJDP develop and document a plan to address girls' delinquency issues.
• OJP agreed with the recommendation and plans to publish a proposed juvenile justice program plan in the Federal Register.

• <summary>
• DOD created DFAS in 1991 to consolidate finance and accounting activities and improve efficiency.
• DFAS assumed control of finance centers and small finance offices, and began consolidating activities at a few locations.
• DFAS and military services share finance and accounting responsibilities, with DFAS handling most operations.
• DFAS has 23,500 employees, while military services have about 17,300.
• DFAS budget was $1.64 billion in 1996, with plans to decrease by 10% by 2000.
• DFAS has reduced the number of finance and accounting systems from 324 to 217.
• DFAS and military services account for monies from four primary sources: general, working capital, nonappropriated, and security assistance funds.
• DFAS and military services perform various finance and accounting activities, including paying personnel, retirees, and contractors, and collecting debts.
• </summary>

* The Federal Reserve System (Federal Reserve) was established in 1913 to provide a central bank for the United States.
* The Federal Reserve Act established the Federal Reserve as an independent agency with a decentralized structure to ensure that monetary policy decisions would be based on a broad economic perspective from all regions of the country.
* The Federal Reserve's monetary policy decisions do not have to be approved by the President, the executive branch of the government, or Congress.
* The Federal Reserve operates in a unique public and private structure, consisting of the Board of Governors (a federal agency), the 12 Reserve Banks (federally chartered corporations), and the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC).

<summary>
* The 1992 Act established a task force to study motor vehicle titling, registration, and salvage issues related to theft.
* The task force recommended uniform definitions for vehicle categories, titling and control methods, duplicate title issuance, inspections, exportation, funding, and enforcement.
* Transportation accepted most of the task force's recommendations but opposed using highway funds as an enforcement tool.
* The 1992 Act also required the establishment of the National Stolen Passenger Motor Vehicle Information System (NSPMVIS).
* An advisory committee recommended that NICB serve as the NSAPIS Administrator and that Congress enact legislation establishing an Oversight Committee.
* The committee recommended that NSAPIS provide automatic notification to law enforcement agencies and users in case of hits or no hits.
* The committee also recommended security measures, manufacturer involvement, and limited immunity for NSAPIS participants acting in good faith.
</summary>

<summary>
* **Entities Involved**: Drug wholesalers, independent pharmacies, PSAOs, third-party payers, and PBMs interact to facilitate drug distribution and payment.
* **Pharmacy Types**: Independent pharmacies are a significant part of the retail pharmacy market, accounting for nearly 34% of U.S. retail pharmacies in 2010.
* **PSAOs**: At least 22 PSAOs operate in the U.S., representing between 20,275 and 28,343 pharmacies in 2011 or 2012.
* **PSAO Services**: Key services include contract negotiation, communication, and help-desk services. Other services may include central payment, reconciliation, inventory management, and certification programs.
* **Contract Negotiation**: PSAOs negotiate various contract provisions, with reimbursement rates and audit provisions being of particular concern to pharmacies.
* **PSAO Requirements**: Some PSAOs require member pharmacies to participate in all contracts, while others allow pharmacies to choose specific contracts.
* **PSAO Ownership**: Most PSAOs are owned by wholesalers or independent pharmacy cooperatives. PSAO owners may operate PSAOs to benefit their non-PSAO lines of business.
* **PSAO Applications**: Pharmacies must submit applications to join a PSAO network, with information used to verify licensing and good standing.
</summary>

* <summary>Federal departments and agencies have made progress in developing and using enterprise architectures, but many challenges remain. Most departments and agencies have not fully satisfied all the conditions needed to be at stage 2 or above in GAO's architecture management framework.</summary>

<summary>
* The U.S. free trade agreement (FTA) with Oman was concluded in 2005 and signed in 2006, aiming to contribute to economic growth, create jobs, and support U.S. exports.
* The agreement provides immediate duty-free access for most goods, market access for services, and protections for intellectual property and investors, while also including enforceable labor and environmental provisions.
</summary>

• Hate crimes are criminal offenses motivated by bias against a person's race, religion, disability, ethnic/national origin, or sexual orientation.
• Congress has enacted several laws to address hate crimes, including the Civil Rights Act of 1968, the Hate Crimes Statistics Act of 1990, and the Hate Crimes Sentencing Enhancement Act of 1994.
• The Matthew Shepard and James Byrd, Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act of 2009 expanded the scope of hate crime victims to include gender, sexual orientation, gender identity, and disability.
• The commerce clause, section 5 of the 14th Amendment, and sections 2 of the 13th and 15th Amendments are potential constitutional authorities for hate crime legislation.
• The Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Morrison narrowed Congress's authority under the commerce clause to regulate non-economic, violent criminal conduct based solely on its aggregate effect on interstate commerce.
• The legislative clauses of the 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments give Congress the power to enforce the Amendments by appropriate legislation.
• The 1st Amendment's freedom of speech clause and the 6th Amendment's right to a jury trial provide constitutional limits on hate crime legislation.
• The Court has struck down statutes that punish speech or expression, but has upheld statutes that punish conduct, such as bias-motivated crimes.

• East Asian nations' exchange rate policies have been a source of tension with the U.S.
• Some countries are accused of keeping their currencies undervalued to gain trade advantages.
• The U.S. Treasury monitors and reports on major trading partners' exchange rate policies.
• East Asian governments prefer managed float policies, unlike the U.S.'s support for free float.
• The 1997-1998 Asian financial crisis influenced East Asian governments' resistance to free float policies.
• The impact of East Asian currency appreciation on U.S. trade deficits is debated among economists.

<summary>
* U.S. ambassadors and other Chiefs of Mission (COMs) serve as the President's personal representatives in foreign countries.
* COM authority extends to all executive branch personnel in a country, except those under the command of a Geographic Combatant Commander (GCC) and Voice of America (VOA) correspondents.
* COMs are responsible for coordinating and supervising all U.S. government activities in their country of assignment.
* COM authority is derived from the President's constitutional powers, legislation, and executive orders.
* The Foreign Service Act of 1980 (FSA 1980) is the primary legislative source of COM authority.
* The President's Letter of Instruction provides further detail on a COM's role and responsibilities.
* COMs have authority over the personnel stationed at the embassy and in the country of assignment, and all U.S. government personnel are required to report to the COM and abide by COM directives.
* COMs are responsible for the security of all U.S. government personnel in their country of assignment, except for those under the command of a GCC and VOA correspondents.
* COM authority does not extend to the legislative and judicial branches, but COMs are expected to coordinate with Members of Congress and their staffs when they travel to a foreign country.
</summary>

<summary>
* China's economy heavily relies on global trade and investment flows, with exports contributing significantly to its GDP growth.
* The global economic slowdown, particularly in major export markets like the U.S., EU, and Japan, has significantly impacted China's export sector and industries dependent on FDI.
* China's economic growth slowed in 2008 and early 2009, with fourth-quarter 2008 growth at 6.8% and first-quarter 2009 growth at 6.1%.
* China's exposure to the U.S. sub-prime mortgage problem is unclear, but its government entities hold significant U.S. securities, including mortgage-backed securities.
* The Chinese government has implemented a two-year, 4 trillion yuan ($586 billion) stimulus package to boost the economy, with a focus on infrastructure projects and assisting 10 pillar industries.
* China's economic recovery is underway, with GDP growth in the second quarter of 2009 at 7.9%, but concerns remain about long-term growth prospects and the sustainability of the recovery.
* China's role in responding to the global financial crisis is debated, with some suggesting it could boost purchases of U.S. securities to help stabilize the U.S. economy, while others question the wisdom of such investments given China's huge development needs at home.
* U.S.-Chinese economic ties may be affected by the global financial crisis, with China blaming U.S. economic policies for the crisis and potentially increasing trade and investment barriers, which could lead to increased protectionist pressures in the U.S.
</summary>

• The Mineral Lands Leasing Act of 1920 (MLLA) ended private acquisition of title to federal oil lands and authorized the Secretary of the Interior to lease lands containing oil and gas.
• The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) manages most federal mineral development and public domain lands, while the Forest Service manages National Forest System (NFS) lands.
• BLM and the Forest Service must comply with the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) when analyzing lands for potential leasing.
• Competitive and noncompetitive leasing procedures are authorized under the MLLA. Competitive leases are auctioned quarterly, while noncompetitive leases are available for two years after a competitive auction.
• Leases are conditioned upon payment of a royalty of at least 12.5% in amount or value of oil or gas production and annual rentals.
• The primary term for competitive and noncompetitive leases is ten years, with extensions possible for drilling operations or oil or gas production.
• Operators must submit an Application for a Permit to Drill (APD) for each oil or gas well, and BLM must prepare an environmental record of review or an environmental assessment before acting on the APD.

* In 2014, 30% of U.S. tax filers chose to itemize their deductions, with higher-income individuals more likely to itemize and claim larger deductions.
* The mortgage interest deduction was the largest single deduction for most itemizers, while the deduction for state and local income taxes was the largest for higher-income itemizers.
* The four largest itemized deductions accounted for 17.8% of individual tax expenditures in FY2018, with the deduction for state and local income or sales taxes being the largest.
* Limiting itemized deductions could increase federal revenue, but may also have economic consequences and affect tax filer behavior.

• The Pacific Islands region is strategically important to the U.S. due to its location, resources, and relationships with other countries.
• The U.S. has long-standing ties with Australia and New Zealand, and works with them to maintain regional stability and promote economic development.
• China's growing engagement in the region has raised concerns, but some experts argue that its influence is limited and Australia remains the dominant power.
• The region faces environmental challenges, including climate change, ocean acidification, and illegal fishing, which impact its economies and communities.

<summary>
* The Endangered Species Act (ESA) provides for the listing and protection of species that are endangered or threatened with extinction.
* Federal agencies are required to consult with the Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) or the National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) to determine whether their actions might jeopardize listed species or destroy or adversely modify their critical habitat.
* If a project could jeopardize a species, a jeopardy opinion is released along with any reasonable and prudent alternatives (RPAs) to the agency action that would avoid jeopardy.
* To excuse any incidental taking of listed species, the Services issue an incidental take statement that includes reasonable and prudent measures (RPMs) to minimize the effects of the project.
* If a federal action cannot be conducted without jeopardizing species, and the federal agency believes that the RPAs would thwart the project, the federal agency, the governor of the state where the project would occur, or the licensees or permittees involved in the project may seek an exemption.
</summary>

• The current income tax law allows capital losses to offset other income up to $3,000, with excess losses carried forward.
• Some propose increasing the net capital loss deduction to stimulate the economy or restore the value of the loss limitation, but this may benefit mainly high-income individuals and could potentially depress stock prices further in the short run.

<summary>
* The National Labor Relations Act (NLRA) recognizes employees' right to collective bargaining through representatives of their choice.
* The NLRA excludes "supervisors" from the definition of "employees," which includes individuals with authority to perform certain functions using independent judgment.
* In Kentucky River Community Care, Inc. , the Supreme Court held that professional or technical judgment can constitute independent judgment for supervisory status.
* In Oakwood Healthcare, Inc. , the NLRB defined "assign," "responsibly to direct," and "independent judgment" for purposes of section 2(11) of the NLRA.
* The NLRA prohibits employers and unions from interfering with, restraining, or coercing employees in the exercise of their rights guaranteed in section 7.
* Employer and union misconduct that "reasonably tends" to restrain or coerce employees is considered an unfair labor practice.
* Employers may make antiunion speeches on company time and property, but last-minute speeches to massed assemblies of employees within 24 hours before an election are prohibited.
* Employers can restrict the distribution of union literature on their property if employees can be reached through other channels of communication, but access may be required if employees are isolated.
</summary>

* <summary>
* Banks play a central role in the financial system by connecting borrowers to savers and allocating capital across the economy.
* Banking is vital to the health and growth of the U.S. economy, but banking panics and failures can create devastating losses.
* The 2008-2009 financial crisis threatened the total collapse of the financial system and the real economy.
* Many assert only huge and unprecedented government interventions staved off this collapse.
* Congress often considers policies related to the banking industry.
* </summary>

<summary>
* The bill increases physician payment update factor, modifies PAQI Fund amounts, and extends Physician Quality Reporting System.
* It extends add-on payments for physicians in scarcity areas through June 30, 2008.
* The bill extends temporary provisions for geographic reclassification of hospitals and medical laboratory billing.
* It extends exceptions to annual per beneficiary payment limits for outpatient therapy services and cost reimbursement for brachytherapy services.
* The bill allows SNPs to restrict enrollment to special needs beneficiaries until January 1, 2010, and extends cost-based plans' operation in areas with two local or two regional MA plans.
* It requires insurers and third-party administrators to submit information to identify situations where a group health plan is or has been a primary plan to Medicare.
* The bill appropriates funds for SCHIP, Medicaid, and miscellaneous activities, and includes offsets to pay for these provisions.
</summary>

* <summary>House committees have the authority to conduct studies and investigations at any time and incur related expenses.</summary>
* <summary>Each committee is required to adopt an oversight plan for each Congress, reviewing specific problems with federal rules, regulations, statutes, and court decisions that are ambiguous, arbitrary, or nonsensical, or that impose severe financial burdens on individuals.</summary>

<summary>
* The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) is a regional organization of 10 countries, established in 1967 to promote economic, political, and security cooperation.
* The United States has deep-seated interests in Southeast Asia, including maritime security, democracy promotion, and trade liberalization, but has been criticized for not engaging sufficiently with ASEAN.
* The Obama Administration has taken steps to engage more with ASEAN, including appointing an ambassador to the organization, acceding to the ASEAN Treaty of Amity and Cooperation, and holding a U.S.-ASEAN leaders' meeting.
* ASEAN has expanded its trade agreements with other countries, including China, India, Japan, and South Korea, and is considering the formation of an East Asian Community.
* The United States and ASEAN share an interest in promoting democracy and human rights in Burma, but have divergent approaches to the issue.
* Congress has played a role in promoting U.S. engagement with ASEAN, including the appointment of an ambassador to the organization, and may continue to do so in the future.
</summary>

<summary>
* Cuba has been on the U.S. state sponsors of terrorism list since 1982.
* Being on the list restricts trade, aid, and other benefits.
* Cuba's retention on the list has been debated, with some arguing it's a Cold War relic.
* The U.S. accuses Cuba of supporting terrorist groups and hosting fugitives from U.S. justice.
* Cuba denies supporting terrorism and has offered to negotiate the extradition of fugitives.
* The U.S. alleges Cuba has a limited biological weapons program, but intelligence is inconclusive.
* Some argue for a tiered approach to sanctions based on the level of support for terrorism.
* Others believe any support for terrorism should be met with strong sanctions.
</summary>

• The Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT) is a separate tax calculation on a broader tax base than the regular tax, designed to ensure that high-income individuals pay at least some minimum amount of tax.
• The AMT base is broader than the regular tax base, but there are many provisions that are not included in its base, such as lower capital gains tax rates and the exclusion for tax-exempt bonds.
• The AMT exemptions are not indexed to inflation, which has led to an increase in the number of taxpayers covered by the AMT over time. In 1987, about 140,000 returns paid the AMT, but by 2009, it is projected that over 9 million taxpayers will pay the AMT.
• The AMT interacts with other tax provisions, such as marriage penalty relief, and can limit the benefits of tax cuts for some taxpayers. For example, the marriage penalty legislation in the 106th Congress would have increased the number of taxpayers on the AMT or affected by the credit by 49% by 2010.
• There are different views on how to address the AMT, ranging from indexing the exemptions to keep its relative importance fixed, to eliminating the AMT altogether, to adjusting the AMT in tandem with regular tax changes to ensure it fulfills its role.

• The Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, and Related Agencies (THUD) Appropriations Subcommittees fund the Department of Transportation (DOT) and the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD), along with related agencies.
• The THUD bill is typically around half discretionary funding and half mandatory contract authority, with a significant portion of the discretionary funding offset by rescissions and receipts.
• The FY2018 THUD appropriations process was unusual due to the late adoption of a budget resolution, with both the House and Senate Appropriations Committees releasing informal suballocations for THUD in July 2017.

<summary>
* The U.S. and India have a "global partnership" but India's relationship with Iran is a concern for the U.S.
* India has a long-standing, positive relationship with Iran, including energy commerce and defense ties.
* The U.S. opposes India's defense relations with Iran and any pipeline projects involving Iran.
* India has voted with the U.S. on IAEA resolutions regarding Iran's nuclear program, despite domestic criticism.
* The U.S. has sanctioned some Indian entities for transfers to Iran that could be useful for Iran's WMD programs.
* India and Iran cooperate in Afghanistan to secure their mutual interests.
</summary>

• U.S. dairy farmers and their supporters are pushing for stricter import controls on milk protein concentrates (MPCs) to raise milk prices and encourage domestic production.
• Opponents argue that such restrictions would increase food manufacturing costs and retail prices, and could lead to WTO compensation negotiations with major MPC suppliers.

<summary>
* Serbia's new government is a coalition of the Serbian Progressive Party (SNS), Socialist Party of Serbia (SPS), and United Regions of Serbia, led by Prime Minister Ivica Dacic.
* The government faces economic challenges, including high unemployment and a depreciated currency, and is seeking an IMF loan.
* Serbia's relations with Kosovo remain a key issue, with the two sides signing an agreement on April 19, 2013, to normalize relations.
* The agreement calls for the creation of an "Association/Community of Serbian-majority municipalities" in Kosovo, with full oversight of certain areas.
* Implementation of the agreement faces challenges, including opposition from Kosovo Serb leaders in northern Kosovo.
* U.S.-Serbian relations have improved, with the U.S. supporting Serbia's EU integration and calling for cooperation with Kosovo.
* The U.S. continues to raise the case of the Bytyqi brothers, murdered by Serbian forces during the 1999 war in Kosovo.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Supreme Court decided four search and seizure cases during its October 2012 term.
* In Florida v. Jardines, the Court ruled that a dog sniff at the front door of a suspected grow house is a Fourth Amendment search requiring probable cause.
* In Florida v. Harris, the Court held that a dog's alert is sufficient to establish probable cause for a vehicle search, reversing the Florida Supreme Court's decision.
* In Bailey v. United States, the Court clarified the scope of the Michigan v. Summers rule, limiting detention of individuals to the immediate vicinity of the premises to be searched.
* In Missouri v. McNeely, the Court rejected a per se exception to the warrant requirement for blood tests in drunk-driving cases, instead favoring a case-by-case analysis.
</summary>

• The federal government first supported energy storage and electric power system technology in the 1970s.
• The advancement of computer capacity and industrial controls has expanded grid operators' ability to monitor and control power flows.
• Internet-connected networks have become vulnerable to unwanted computer-driven intrusions and disruptions, revealing a new cybersecurity challenge for electric power systems.
• The electric power industry faces challenges such as a changing power generation mix, replacing aging infrastructure, modernizing communication networks, accommodating new end-use technologies, and planning for increased interdependencies of natural gas, water, and electricity systems.
• The DOE Office of Electricity Delivery and Energy Reliability (OE) is charged with supporting more economically competitive, environmentally responsible, secure, and resilient U.S. energy infrastructure.
• OE's mission is guided by the Quadrennial Technology Review and the Grid Modernization Multi-Year Program Plan, aiming to achieve a future electric grid that provides reliable, affordable, and clean electricity to consumers.
• OE's FY2017 budget request sought $262 million, a $56 million increase over the FY2016 level, with proposed new programs including a Grid Institute, State Distribution-Level Reform, and State Energy Assurance.
• The largest requested increases were for Energy Storage, Infrastructure Security, and the three new programs, while the largest cut was sought for Cybersecurity.
• OE's FY2017 funding was ultimately set at the FY2016 level of $206 million through a continuing resolution.

* The Commemorative Works Act (CWA) of 1986 governs the establishment of commemorative works in the District of Columbia and its environs.
* The CWA defines a commemorative work as a statue, monument, sculpture, memorial, plaque, inscription, or other structure designed to perpetuate the memory of an individual, group, event, or significant element of American history.
* The CWA requires congressional authorization for the establishment of a commemorative work.
* The CWA created the National Capital Memorial Advisory Commission to advise the Secretary of the Interior and the Administrator of General Services on policy and procedures for establishing commemorative works.
* The CWA divides the District of Columbia and its environs into three sections for the placement of memorials: the Reserve, Area I, and Area II.
* The Reserve is a no-build zone that prohibits the siting of new commemorative works.
* Area I is reserved for commemorative works of preeminent historical and lasting significance to the United States.
* Area II is reserved for subjects of lasting historical significance to the American people.
* The CWA provides a 24-step process for creating a commemorative work in the District of Columbia, including site selection, design approval, fundraising, and construction.
* The CWA allows for the extension of legislative authority for commemorative works if certain conditions are met.

* <summary>
* S. 1796, America's Healthy Future Act of 2009, is a bill ordered reported by the Senate Committee on Finance on October 19, 2009, which includes provisions affecting private health insurance.
* The bill requires most individuals to have health insurance and employers with more than 50 full-time employees to either provide coverage or pay a penalty.
* New health plans must meet specified requirements to be qualified health benefits plans (QHBPs) and offer coverage at one of four tiers: bronze, silver, gold, or platinum.
* The bill establishes a temporary reinsurance program for individual policies and risk corridors to adjust payments to plans based on their actual expenses.
* It also requires insurers to offer QHBPs that include the essential benefits package and limits out-of-pocket costs.
* The bill creates a program for states to establish basic plans for low-income individuals not eligible for Medicaid.
* It requires states to establish exchanges through which individuals and small employers can obtain QHBPs.
* The bill provides incentives for the creation of health insurance co-operatives and limits the deductibility of compensation for health insurance executives.
* It also includes revenue provisions that would raise funds to pay for expanded health insurance coverage, including an excise tax on high-cost employer-sponsored health insurance and a fee on health insurance providers.
* </summary>

• **Purpose of High Risk Pools**: High risk pools are state-established programs that provide health insurance to individuals who cannot obtain or afford coverage in the private market due to preexisting health conditions.
• **Eligibility**: Eligible individuals include those who have been denied coverage, received quotes higher than the pool's premiums, or have offers with permanent exclusions for preexisting conditions. Many states also allow HIPAA-eligible persons to enroll.
• **Funding**: States fund these pools through premiums, assessments on insurers, general revenue, and federal grants. They usually operate at a loss and require additional funding sources.
• **Benefits and Enrollment**: Benefits vary by state but generally reflect coverage available in the private nongroup market. Enrollment varies significantly across states, with most pools having fewer than 4,000 participants.
• **Federal Grants**: The federal government provides grants to states to establish and operate high risk pools. Since 2002, CMS has awarded seed grants to help states create pools and operational grants to cover losses experienced by existing pools.

* The Civil Reserve Air Fleet (CRAF) is a program that provides airlift support to the Department of Defense (DOD) in times of crisis.
* The FY2008 National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) required a comprehensive and independent assessment of CRAF, to be delivered to congressional defense committee no later than April 2008.
* The FY2008 NDAA also extended the authorization of the Aviation Insurance Program (AIP) and called for a DOD study on the size and mix of the airlift force, including the potential impact of CRAF on DOD's airlift fleet requirements.

<summary>
* The National Telecommunications and Information Administration (NTIA) is a U.S. Department of Commerce agency that advises on telecommunications and information policies.
* NTIA's responsibilities include managing federal spectrum use, leading interagency efforts on Internet policy, and administering grants for broadband technology and public safety communications.
* The NTIA supports increasing mobile broadband spectrum capacity by 500 MHz through clearing, sharing, and improving federal spectrum use.
* NTIA also plays a role in international spectrum management, including harmonization and participation in World Radio Conferences.
</summary>

• The Energy Policy Act of 2005 (P.L. 109-58) was signed by President Bush on August 8, 2005, and is the first omnibus energy legislation enacted in over a decade.
• The act includes provisions to improve the reliability of the U.S. bulk power system, encourage energy efficiency, and increase domestic energy production.
• FERC is required to establish and regulate an electric reliability organization (ERO) to develop and enforce reliability standards for the bulk power system.
• The act also includes provisions to streamline the siting of interstate electric transmission facilities and to encourage the deployment of advanced transmission technologies.
• The act repeals the mandatory purchase requirement under Section 210 of PURPA for new contracts if FERC finds that a competitive electricity market exists and a qualifying facility has access to independently administered, auction-based, day-ahead, real-time wholesale markets and long-term wholesale markets.

• The Robinson-Patman Act (R-P) of 1936 aims to maintain a competitive market for small businesses by prohibiting sellers from discriminating in price between different purchasers of commodities of like grade and quality.
• The act applies only to sales of goods purchased for resale within the United States and does not apply to services or exports.
• Sellers can defend against R-P allegations using several affirmative defenses, including meeting competition, cost justification, and the nonprofit institutions exemption.
• The nonprofit exemption allows institutions like hospitals and health maintenance organizations (HMOs) to purchase supplies at discounted prices for their own use.
• The Supreme Court has interpreted the "for their own use" phrase strictly, limiting its application to purchases that meet the needs of the institution and its staff, and excluding purchases for resale or private practice.
• The Antitrust Modernization Commission recommended repealing the Robinson-Patman Act due to its potential to limit discounting and increase consumer prices.

• The Obama Administration has faced scrutiny for nonenforcement decisions, including those related to marijuana legalization, immigration, and the Affordable Care Act (ACA).
• The House has held hearings and approved legislation addressing nonenforcement decisions, while the Senate has not concurred.
• The ENFORCE the Law Act of 2014 and a joint resolution would authorize lawsuits challenging nonenforcement policies.
• The Take Care Clause requires the President to "take Care that the Laws be faithfully executed."
• The Supreme Court has interpreted the Take Care Clause as imposing a duty on the President to execute laws and as ensuring presidential control over enforcement.
• The judicial branch generally will not review discretionary enforcement decisions, including those made by federal prosecutors or agencies.
• Congress may guide or restrict enforcement discretion by statute, but may not itself enforce laws or appoint or remove enforcement officers.
• Morrison v. Olson established a standard for evaluating intrusions into the executive's enforcement power.
• The False Claims Act's qui tam provision has been upheld as constitutional under the Morrison standard.

• The official U.S. poverty rate was 14.5% in 2013, with 45.3 million people living in poverty.
• Poverty tends to follow the economic cycle, with higher rates during recessions and lower rates during economic growth.
• The poverty rate increased markedly over the past decade due to two economic recessions.
• Poverty is concentrated among certain groups, including minorities, women and children, the very old, the unemployed, and those with low educational attainment or skills.
• In 2013, 27.2% of blacks, 23.5% of Hispanics, and 9.6% of non-Hispanic whites were in poverty.
• The aged poverty rate was 9.5% in 2013, near an historic low.
• The Supplemental Poverty Measure (SPM) paints a different picture of poverty, especially among the aged and children.

<summary>
* The U.S. farm bill, renewed every 5-6 years, includes programs that affect trade and may impact U.S. commitments under the World Trade Organization (WTO).
* The WTO's Agreement on Agriculture (AoA) sets limits on trade-distorting domestic support and export subsidies, and disciplines market access.
* The AoA categorizes domestic support programs based on their potential to distort markets: green box (minimally distorting), blue box (production-limiting), and amber box (most distorting).
* The United States is subject to an annual spending limit of $19.1 billion on amber box support, with certain de minimis exemptions.
* The Agreement on Subsidies and Countervailing Measures (SCM) governs subsidies that cause significant market distortion.
* WTO dispute settlement procedures can be used to challenge domestic support programs that violate WTO rules.
* The U.S. 2014 farm bill includes a provision to adjust program outlays to avoid breaching the AMS limit.
* The last U.S. notification to the WTO was for the 2012 marketing year, with total AMS of $16.8 billion, below the $19.1 billion limit.
</summary>

• The Federal Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grant (FSEOG), Federal Work-Study (FWS), and Federal Perkins Loan programs are collectively referred to as "campus-based" programs.
• These programs are unique in that federal funds are awarded directly to institutions of higher education (IHEs) that administer the programs and provide institutional funds to match the federal funds they receive for them.
• The campus-based programs are among the oldest of the federal student aid programs and play a relatively smaller role in the federal student aid effort compared to other programs like the Direct Loan and Pell Grant programs.
• The FSEOG, FWS, and Perkins Loan programs were authorized under the Higher Education Act of 1965 (HEA) and are among the programs that expired at the end of FY2015.
• The FSEOG and FWS programs have continued to be funded through annual appropriation bills, while the Perkins Loan program was amended and extended through FY2017 under the Federal Perkins Loan Program Extension Act of 2015 (Extension Act).
• The Perkins Loan program's authorization of appropriations expired at the end of FY2014, and its operations were significantly curtailed on October 1, 2015.
• The Extension Act prohibits future appropriations for the purpose of enabling the Secretary to make new Federal Capital Contributions (FCCs) and prohibits an automatic extension of the program under the General Education Provisions Act (GEPA).
• The campus-based programs are allocated to IHEs through a two-stage process, with a base guarantee and a fair share component. The base guarantee is based on the year the IHE began participating in each of the campus-based programs, while the fair share is based on the IHE's institutional need.
• The FSEOG, FWS, and Perkins Loan programs are among the programs that may be considered for reauthorization under the HEA. Issues related to these programs that may be considered include the extent to which they provide types of aid to students that are not provided via other postsecondary aid programs, whether the current formula for allocating funds to institutions is optimal, and the potential role of the campus-based aid programs in a redesigned federal aid system.

* State alert systems for missing adults are recent initiatives, with 11 states identified as having active systems.
* These systems target vulnerable adults due to cognitive, mental, physical, or developmental disabilities, or advanced age.
* The federal government may play a role in assisting states to develop these systems nationwide.

* <summary>DHS FY2017 appropriations totaled $41.3 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority, including $6.7 billion for disaster relief and $163 million for overseas contingency operations.</summary>
* <summary>The FY2017 appropriations act included a new structure for DHS appropriations, with four categories: Operations and Support, Procurement, Construction and Improvement, Research and Development, and Federal Assistance.</summary>

• The September 11, 2001, attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon highlighted the potential vulnerability of the nation's water supply and water quality infrastructure.
• Water infrastructure systems include surface and ground water sources, dams, reservoirs, aqueducts, pipes, treatment facilities, and wastewater collection and treatment facilities.
• The federal government owns and manages a small portion of the nation's water infrastructure, primarily dams and reservoirs for irrigation development and flood control, with municipal and industrial water use as an incidental purpose.
• The largest federal facilities are managed by the Bureau of Reclamation (Reclamation) and the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (Corps).
• The federal government is responsible for only about 5% of the dams whose failure could result in loss of life or significant property damage.
• A fairly small number of large drinking water and wastewater utilities located primarily in urban areas provide water services to more than 75% of the U.S. population.
• Attacks resulting in physical destruction to any of these systems could include disruption of operating or distribution system components, power or telecommunications systems, electronic control systems, and actual damage to reservoirs and pumping stations.
• Bioterrorism or chemical attacks could deliver widespread contamination with small amounts of microbiological agents or toxic chemicals, and could endanger the public health of thousands.
• Cyber attacks on computer operations can affect an entire infrastructure network, and hacking in water utility systems could result in theft or corruption of information, or denial and disruption of service.

• Perkins IV reauthorizes and amends the Carl D. Perkins Vocational and Technical Education Act of 1998, providing funding for career and technical education through FY2012.
• The act retains the overall structure and purposes of Perkins III, but includes several changes and additions.
• Funding is distributed to states based on a formula that considers population groups and per capita income, with additional funds allotted if funding exceeds the FY2006 level.
• States must distribute at least 85% of their grants to the local level, with up to 10% reserved for administration and 5% for state leadership functions.
• Perkins IV includes new provisions for accountability, including separate core indicators of performance for secondary and postsecondary levels, adjusted levels of performance, and sanctions for failing to meet performance targets.

* The federal estate tax is a tax on the estate of a decedent, levied against and paid by the estate, while the inheritance tax is imposed on and paid by the heirs of the decedent.
* The gross estate of a decedent includes the value of all property, real or personal, tangible or intangible, wherever situated, in which the decedent owned an interest on the date of the decedent's death, as well as certain interests in property transferred to another person at some time prior to the date of death.
* The decedent's taxable estate is determined by reducing the gross estate with allowable deductions, including estate administration expenses, certain debts and losses, the amount of qualified transfers to a surviving spouse, charitable bequests, and state death taxes.
* The federal gift tax is a tax imposed on an annual basis on all gratuitous transfers of property made during life, with the tax liability depending upon the value of the "taxable gift" after deductions and exclusions.
* The generation-skipping transfer (GST) tax is a flat-rate tax (currently 40%) imposed on three different transfer events: a direct skip, a taxable termination, or a taxable distribution, with several exemptions and exclusions available.

<summary>
* The U.S. government has implemented various programs and policies to enhance border and transportation security.
* These programs and policies can be categorized into five main approaches: pushing the border outwards, hardening the border, facilitating legitimate travel and trade, strengthening the border through intelligence, and multiplying effectiveness through engagement of other actors.
* Pushing the border outwards involves intercepting unwanted people or goods before they reach the U.S. through measures such as pre-inspections, advance passenger/cargo notice programs, and the Container Security Initiative (CSI).
* Hardening the border involves using technology and increasing the presence of agents at the border to prevent unwanted entry.
* Facilitating legitimate travel and trade involves making the border more accessible for low-risk travelers and goods through programs such as NEXUS, SENTRI, and FAST.
* Strengthening the border through intelligence involves using traditional foreign intelligence and criminal intelligence to prevent certain goods and individuals from crossing U.S. borders.
* Multiplying effectiveness through engagement of other actors involves working with foreign governments, state and local law enforcement, and the private sector to enhance border security.
* The U.S. government has entered into bilateral agreements with Canada and Mexico to enhance border security and facilitate legitimate travel and trade.
* The U.S. government has also begun working with the European Union to facilitate cooperation on the CSI.
</summary>

<summary>
* Cabo Verde is a small island nation with historical ties to the United States.
* U.S.-Cabo Verdean relations focus on counternarcotics efforts, military professionalization, and development projects.
* Cabo Verde is strategically located, making it a transshipment point for Latin American cocaine and a refueling stop for trans-Atlantic air traffic.
* The country is an African model of democratic governance with high per capita income, literacy rate, and positive social indicators.
* Cabo Verde's political system includes provisions for expatriate voters, and it has a long-standing tradition of emigration to the United States.
* The country faces challenges such as recurrent water shortages, poverty, and drug trafficking.
* Cabo Verde receives development assistance from the Millennium Challenge Corporation (MCC) and participates in the African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA).
* The United States provides military training and equipment to Cabo Verde to help combat drug trafficking.
* Cabo Verde is an active member of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) and has hosted regional conferences and military exercises.
</summary>

• The United States and New Zealand have re-established close security cooperation, with the Wellington Declaration of 2010 and the Washington Declaration of 2012 marking a return to high-level defense ties.
• New Zealand's strategic interests lie primarily in the South Pacific, with a focus on maintaining peace, prosperity, and stability in the region, while also expanding trade and investment linkages with Asia.

• The U.S. Constitution provides the President with two methods of appointing officers of the United States: by and with the advice and consent of the Senate, or by filling vacancies that occur during a recess of the Senate.
• The Recess Appointments Clause allows the President to fill vacancies that occur during a recess of the Senate, but the Constitution does not explicitly define what constitutes a "Recess."
• The Adjournment Clause provides that neither House of Congress may adjourn for more than three days without the consent of the other, and this clause has been used to inform the meaning of "Recess" for purposes of the Recess Appointments Clause.
• The executive branch has historically implied that a recess of at least three days is likely necessary for the President to make a recess appointment, but this is not explicitly required by the Constitution.
• The President's recess appointment power has been challenged in court, but lower federal courts have generally upheld the President's authority to make recess appointments.
• The Consumer Financial Protection Act (CFP Act) established the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) and provides that the Bureau is to be headed by a single Director, who is to be appointed by the President with the advice and consent of the Senate.
• The CFP Act also provides that the Secretary of the Treasury (Secretary) is authorized to perform the functions of the Bureau until a Director is confirmed by the Senate.
• The scope of the Secretary's authority is limited to the functions of the Bureau under subtitle F of the CFP Act, which transfers certain consumer financial protection functions from other agencies to the Bureau.
• The Secretary's authority to exercise the Bureau's transferred powers lasts "until the Director of the Bureau is confirmed by the Senate in accordance with section 1011," which establishes the standard process for appointing advice and consent positions.
• A reviewing court may interpret section 1066 as allowing a recess appointed Director, such as Richard Cordray, to assume the full authorities established by the CFP Act, or it may interpret the provision as only allowing a Senate-confirmed Director to exercise the full powers of the position.

* <summary>
* Expedited removal initially applied to aliens arriving in the U.S. at a port of entry, in transit, or interdicted at sea.
* INS considered but did not implement a pilot program to extend expedited removal to criminal aliens in Texas correctional facilities.
* INS defined "arriving alien" to include aliens seeking admission, transit, or interdicted at sea.
* INS reserved the right to expand expedited removal procedures based on operational needs.
* </summary>

<summary>
* The Constitution requires that congressional districts be drawn to achieve approximate population equality.
* The Elections Clause gives states the power to draw congressional districts, but Congress can make or alter such laws.
* The Voting Rights Act requires that redistricting plans not result in the denial or abridgement of the right to vote based on race, color, or language minority status.
* The Supreme Court has established the "one person, one vote" principle, requiring that each congressional district contain approximately the same population.
* The Court has permitted some population deviation from precise equality, but has struck down plans with large deviations.
* Partisanship can justify small differences in population, but the Court is considering whether it can justify larger deviations.
* The Court has ruled that states may draw districts based on total population, but has not foreclosed the possibility of using eligible voters or other measures.
* The Voting Rights Act requires that redistricting plans not result in the dilution of minority voting power.
* The Court has held that race can be a predominant factor in redistricting, but only if it is narrowly tailored to achieve a compelling state interest.
</summary>

* <summary>
* Wildfire funding has increased significantly since 2000, with FY2008 being the highest at $4.46 billion.
* The average acreage burned annually has also increased, with the six biggest fire seasons occurring in the past decade.
* High fuel loads on federal lands, particularly in forests, contribute to severe wildfires and high suppression costs.
* Wildfire management costs have risen, with suppression costs exceeding agency appropriations annually since 2003.
* Fuel reduction efforts have increased but remain limited, with only about 1% of federal lands treated annually.
* The federal role in protecting non-federal lands and structures, and the funding of relevant federal activities, is a topic of debate.
* Post-fire rehabilitation has received increased attention, with legislation proposed to expedite the process.
* </summary>

<summary>
* Across the U.S., about 27.5% of state and local government employees (about 6.6 million persons) work in positions not covered by Social Security.
* Coverage rates vary widely across states, with some having 90% or more of employees covered, and others having less than 5%.
* Mandatory Social Security coverage for newly hired state and local government employees has been recommended by deficit reduction groups.
* Mandatory coverage is projected to have a net positive effect on Social Security Trust Funds, closing 8-9% of the projected long-range funding shortfall.
* It could simplify retirement planning and benefit coordination for workers who divide their careers between state and local government positions and other positions.
* It could provide better retirement, survivor, and disability insurance protections for workers who move between state and local government positions and other positions.
* It could result in better benefit protections through the provision of dependents' and survivors' benefits under Social Security.
* It could eliminate the need for the Windfall Elimination Provision (WEP) and Government Pension Offset (GPO), which reduce Social Security benefits for some public pension recipients.
</summary>

* <summary>
	+ Trade Adjustment Assistance (TAA) provides federal assistance to workers who lose their jobs due to foreign competition.
	+ TAA was reauthorized by the Trade Adjustment Assistance Reauthorization Act of 2015 (TAARA) and is set to expire on June 30, 2021.
	+ TAA is jointly administered by the federal government and the states, with funding provided by the federal government.
	+ To be eligible for TAA, a group of workers must have become totally or partially separated from their employment due to increased imports or offshoring.
	+ TAA benefits include training and reemployment services, income support, and a tax credit for health insurance premiums.
	+ TAA is subject to sequestration under the Budget Control Act of 2011, as amended. </summary>

• **Program Overview**: The Federal Employee Dental and Vision Benefits Enhancement Act of 2004 established the Federal Employees Dental and Vision Insurance Program (FEDVIP), offering supplemental dental and vision benefits to federal employees, Members of Congress, annuitants, and dependents.
• **Eligibility and Enrollment**: Eligible individuals can enroll in FEDVIP during the standard open season for FEHB plans, change plans during open season each year, or following a qualifying life event. New employees have 60 days to enroll.
• **Plan Options**: There are four nationwide dental plans, three regional dental plans, and three vision plans, each with high and standard options. Individuals can choose self-only, self + 1, or family plans, and are not required to enroll in both dental and vision plans.
• **Premiums and Costs**: Premiums vary by plan, enrollment type, and residency (for dental plans only). Active employees pay pre-tax premiums, but annuitants, survivor annuitants, and compensationers do not have this option. There are no preexisting condition exclusions, but there are waiting periods for orthodontia.
• **Benefits and Considerations**: Benefits include oral examinations, restorative procedures, endodontic services, and orthodontic services. Individuals must consider their expected use of services, FEHB coverage, and the option of contributing to a Flexible Spending Account (FSA) when deciding whether to enroll in FEDVIP.

<summary>
* ARRA provided $17.15 billion in supplemental FY2009 discretionary appropriations for biomedical research, public health, and other health-related programs within HHS.
* The funds were designated as emergency supplemental appropriations for FY2009 and are to remain available for obligation through the end of FY2010.
* Most of the health-related programs and activities for which ARRA provided supplemental funds also receive funding in annual appropriations acts through regular procedures.
* ARRA funds were allocated to various HHS agencies and offices, with the largest amounts going to NIH ($10.0 billion), HRSA ($2.0 billion), and ONC ($2.0 billion).
* The funds were used for a wide range of activities, including biomedical research, health workforce programs, health center infrastructure and operations, comparative effectiveness research, health information technology, and prevention and wellness programs.
* ARRA also established a federal interagency advisory panel to coordinate comparative effectiveness research and promoted the widespread adoption of electronic health records and other health information technology.
* HHS agencies are required to submit reports on the actual obligations, expenditures, and unobligated balances for each ARRA-funded activity by November 1, 2009, and each six months thereafter as long as funding remains available for obligation or expenditure.
* ARRA required that a report on the actual obligations, expenditures, and unobligated balances for each ARRA-funded activity be submitted by November 1, 2009, and each six months thereafter as long as funding remains available for obligation or expenditure.
</summary>

* The Livestock Mandatory Reporting Act (LMR) requires meat packers to report prices and other information on purchases of cattle, hogs, lamb, boxed beef, wholesale pork, and lamb carcasses and boxed lamb to the USDA.
* The law was reauthorized in 2015 and is set to expire in 2020, with changes made to swine and lamb reporting requirements.

<summary>
* A sitting U.S. Senator's status and service are not directly affected by an indictment for a felony.
* No federal statute, constitutional provision, or Senate Rule requires resignation or removal upon indictment.
* Conviction of a felony may result in loss of committee chairmanships or ranking Member status under party rules.
* Conviction may also lead to internal disciplinary proceedings, including censure or expulsion from the Senate.
* Indictment or conviction does not disqualify a Senator from serving, unless it's for treasonous conduct after taking an oath.
* The Senate has discretion to discipline Members for misconduct, but expulsion is rare and usually reserved for severe cases.
* There is no right to recall a Member of Congress, and the Constitution sets the exclusive qualifications for congressional office.
</summary>

• The U.S. has approximately 766 million acres of forestlands, with most being privately owned.
• The Forest Service (FS) in the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) administers several programs to support forest management and protection on both private and public forests.
• These programs provide technical and financial assistance for activities such as planning for and responding to wildfires, and supporting the development of new uses and markets for wood products.
• The programs are primarily funded through the annual discretionary appropriations process and are typically funded in the annual Interior, Environment, and Related Agencies appropriations acts.

<summary>
* Burma is a major transit point for illicit drugs, humans, guns, wildlife, gems, and timber.
* Corruption among officials facilitates trafficking and provides immunity from law enforcement.
* The country's extra-legal economy is so large that its size and structure are difficult to assess.
* The U.S. government has imposed sanctions on Burma due to its role in transnational crime and human rights abuses.
* The U.S. provides assistance to neighboring countries to combat trafficking from Burma.
* Despite efforts, transnational crime in Burma remains a significant issue.
</summary>

<summary>
* The Affordable Care Act (ACA) has significantly impacted federal mandatory spending, with most of the spending going towards expanding health insurance coverage.
* The ACA includes provisions for premium tax credits and cost-sharing reduction payments for individuals and families who purchase private insurance coverage through health insurance exchanges, as well as federal matching funds for states that choose to expand their Medicaid programs.
* The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) reports that spending on premium tax credits and cost-sharing reductions totaled $79.2 billion for the first three fiscal years in which the ACA exchanges were operational.
* The Medicaid expansion has also had a significant impact on spending, with 27 states reporting spending a total of $36.7 billion on newly eligible adults in calendar year 2014, all of which was paid for with federal funds.
* The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) estimates that gross spending on insurance coverage expansion under the ACA will total $1.938 trillion over the 10-year period FY2017 through FY2026.
* The ACA also includes numerous appropriations that provide billions of dollars in mandatory funds to support new and existing grant programs and other activities.
* Several provisions in the ACA require the Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) to transfer amounts from the Medicare Part A and Part B trust funds for specified purposes.
* The ACA funded a broad range of new and existing programs, including short-term health care programs for targeted groups prior to the health insurance exchanges becoming operational in 2014.
* The law established the Center for Medicare and Medicaid Innovation (CMMI) and appropriated $10 billion for the FY2011-FY2019 period, and $10 billion for each subsequent 10-year period, for CMMI to test and implement innovative payment and service delivery models.
* The ACA created four special funds and appropriated substantial amounts to each one, including the Community Health Center Fund (CHCF), the Prevention and Public Health Fund (PPHF), the Patient-Centered Outcomes Research Trust Fund (PCORTF), and the Health Insurance Reform Implementation Fund (HIRIF).
</summary>

• The presence of foreign students in U.S. graduate science and engineering programs has raised concerns about job opportunities and wages for U.S. citizens.
• Foreign students often use these programs as a stepping stone to immigration through sponsorships for legal permanent residence.
• Approximately 56% of foreign doctorate degree earners on temporary visas remain in the U.S., with many eventually becoming citizens.
• The H-1B temporary admissions program has been a source of debate, with some arguing that it displaces U.S. workers and depresses wages.
• The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics projects that employment in science and engineering fields will increase faster than other professional groups between 2006 and 2016.
• The number of foreign-born students in U.S. colleges and universities increased by 8.0% in 2008-2009, with China and India being the top countries of origin.
• In 2006, foreign students earned approximately 36.2% of the doctorate degrees in the sciences and approximately 63.6% of the doctorate degrees in engineering.
• Universities provide a significant amount of support to foreign students on temporary and permanent resident visas, often through research and teaching assistantships.
• Some argue that foreign student teaching assistants may not communicate well with American students due to language barriers.
• The debate on the presence of foreign students in graduate science and engineering programs and the workforce has intensified since the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks, with concerns about national security and the impact on U.S. competitiveness.

* The U.S. Department of Energy's Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy (EERE) is seeking a significant reduction in funding for FY2018, with a request of $636 million, compared to the FY2017 enacted level of $2.0 billion.
* The EERE request focuses on early-stage research and development (R&D) and eliminates several programs, including the Weatherization Assistance Program and the State Energy Program.
* The House and Senate appropriations bills for FY2018 provide funding for EERE at levels above the Administration's request, with the Senate bill providing $1.9 billion and the House bill providing $1.1 billion.
* Both the House and Senate bills continue to support several programs that the Administration's request would terminate, such as SuperTruck II, the Clean Cities program, and efforts to reduce energy consumption of the commercial off-road vehicle sector.
* The House and Senate bills also provide funding for later-stage R&D and deployment projects in renewable energy, energy efficiency, and other areas, in contrast to the Administration's request.

• Cryptocurrencies are digital money in an electronic payment system validated by a decentralized network of system users and cryptographic protocols.
• They have the potential to provide increased economic efficiency, privacy, and independence from centralized institutions and authorities.
• However, they face challenges in widespread adoption due to technological limitations and obstacles to adoption.
• Skeptics argue that cryptocurrencies do not effectively perform the functions of money and will not be a valuable, widely used form of money in the future.
• Policymakers will need to address concerns about cryptocurrency's alleged facilitation of crime, the adequacy of consumer protections, the level of appropriate regulation, and its potential effect on monetary policy.
• The future role and value of cryptocurrencies remain highly uncertain.

<summary>
* H.R. 3652 aims to modify several sections of the Bankruptcy Code, including § 1113, which governs the rejection of collective bargaining agreements (CBAs) in business bankruptcies.
* The bill seeks to address perceived inequities in the bankruptcy process, where workers and retirees bear a disproportionate burden of bankruptcy costs.
* The bill proposes changes to § 1113 to limit the modifications that a debtor can propose to a CBA, requiring them to be no more than necessary for reorganization and not overly burdensome to the labor group compared to other groups, including management.
* The bill would require the court to find that the parties are at an impasse before approving rejection of a CBA, and would consider alternative proposals by the authorized representative.
* The bill would establish a presumption that the debtor has overly burdened the labor group if it has implemented incentive pay, bonuses, or other financial returns for insiders or senior management personnel during the bankruptcy or within 180 days before the case began.
* The bill would allow labor groups to strike or engage in other self-help methods in response to court-ordered modifications to a CBA.
* The bill would require the court to grant a request for future modifications to a CBA if the change would result in the new provisions being no more than the minimum savings needed for the debtor to reorganize successfully.
* The bill would allow arbitration in lieu of a court hearing to rule on a motion for rejection of a CBA if requested by the authorized representative and found to be helpful by the court.
* The bill would make reasonable costs and fees incurred by the authorized representative in complying with the requirements of § 1113 reimbursable as administrative expenses.
* The bill would require the debtor and authorized representative to meet to determine the effects on the labor group when a debtor's reorganization plan involves selling all or part of the business or ceasing some or all of the business.
</summary>
